story:
Short Summary

Tomorrows Forest's is a new 'start up' company in Great Britain. For the last ten years, our team has been learning different techniques related to silviculture and it's impacts on our forests. Our team has been working in British Columbia, Canada but is now ready to take a new step and bring our knowledge to Great Britain. 
In the long term, our goal is to re-establish the native woodlands that once thrived in the UK. Over the years, we have been able to witness the effects of mono-culture on the Canadian and UK forests. We want to make changes in the reforestation process that are in place, as we believe a diverse forest Eco-system is the correct way to achieve long term successful reforestation management goals.
With your help, our team will be able to establish our business in the UK as we have just aquired our first contract which will allow us to plant a 125,000 trees in the Suffolk region of England.

What We Need & What You Get

We are in the process of getting the business off the ground. Which as many of you will know is a costly and rigorous challenge. We have spent all summer planting trees in Canada to try and help fund the start up costs in the UK. With our first project fast approaching, we are looking for help to cover the biggest start up cost, a commercial Van, to transport the trees and crew to the new forest work site. This first project is very important for us as we will use it as a launch platform for our future projects.

With the funds, every spare dollar will go towards putting trees in the ground. You are not only helping us with our initial start up costs. You are also contributing to the future forests of Great Britain.

story:
Help build climate resilience in the outdoor athlete and adventure community.

Thanks so much for taking the time to find out more about Kjölur Run and Athletes for Climate Resilience. This campaign seeks funding to support two main initiatives:

  1. To support a 275 km, 3-day solo run across Iceland from the Atlantic to the Arctic in June 2015 to leverage media attention on the role that athletes and adventurers play in building climate resilience.
  2. To fund scholarships for students to study the relationship between outdoor recreation / athletics and climate change. The project aims to fund two separate scholarships for students at colleges in the U.S. and in Iceland.

Climate change impacts all of us--from changing rain patterns to shorter winters, longer droughts, melting glaciers, and rising sea levels--and athletes have a unique relationship to the outdoors and connection to the changing climate through our choices of where to travel, what equipment to use, where to spend the night, and so on. In so many ways, we depend upon a continuing and resilient relationship with the larger environment of which we are a part. 

It is in the best interest of the planet and of our own goals as an outdoor community to invest in building climate resilience. The future of our ability to adapt to and engage with climate change and our hope to build climate resilience is in education, and my hope is that we can make real change by funding scholarships for students to focus on these important issues.

How You Can Help

This project depends on your help. The goal is to raise a total of at least $25,000 in order to fund (1) the logistics and support associated with running across Iceland next June and (2) enough for two substantial scholarships to support the study of climate resilience through programs at Vermont's Sterling College and the University Centre of the Westfjords in Ísafjörður, Iceland. 


   


As a flexibly-funded campaign, any money raised will be allocated to the mission of this project. The more that is raised, the greater the available funding for student research, networking, and educational opportunity. 

Since outreach and media attention are key to the success of this campaign, the perks will help supporters spread the word about Kjölur Run and Climate Resilience. Check out the perks on the right--they include sustainably sourced lifestyle and technical t-shirts, eco-friendly stickers, and rewards from project friends and supporters, including Petzl and PocketFuel, as well as photos from the run in Iceland, and an invitation to follow along with exclusive access to training and nutrition info throughout the winter and spring.

A veteran of twenty years of racing and mountain running projects from 5k to 50 miles, I'm not only an avid outdoor athlete, as a faculty member and athletic director at Vermont's Sterling College, I founded the U.S.'s first collegiate Mountain, Trail, Ultra Running Team. I have also been personally involved in issues of sustainability, outdoor education, athletics, and climate change for nearly two decades at schools across the Northeast.

The Route

The 275 km (170 mile)route starts southeast of Reykjavik along the Atlantic coast and follows a route past Gullfoss and Geyser into the Kjölur Plateau. After traversing this highland region, the route descends to the north coast to the town of Blönduós along the Greenland Sea (see the Map My Run route here).


I have been steadily ramping up my training regimen to train specifically for a multi-day run. I will also be working alongside students and faculty at Sterling researching the latest sports nutrition and endurance training. I'm really pretty stoked! 

Risk

There is an inherent risk to any outdoor endeavor, and this one is certainly no different. The route may need to change because of weather conditions, snowpack, or volcanic activity (this is Iceland, after all!); I may become injured in training or during the run itself; or virtually anything else could happen. 

Honestly, risk and uncertainty is one of the reasons that I chose to put myself out there and run across Iceland. If by even attempting this run, I motivate others to think about similar adventures and/or to think about their actions in the outdoors with regard to the climate, then I think I've done something worthwhile. 

In the unlikely event that I won't be able to complete the run itself, however, all of the money raised will go to the scholarship funds. 

Even if you're unable to donate right now, please help spread the word about this campaign, about the Kjölur Run, and about climate resilience.

Thank you!

story:
Atlantis last place on earth

The human race faces many future challenges. Global warming, religious conflict, war, 2 billion unemployed by 2030 and imminent biological attack just to name a few. We don't have the technology to get off this dying planet. So we are doing the next best thing. Were moving to the country to build a technologically advanced self sustaining safe zone (sanctuary for humans) in New Zealand.

New Zealand a land mass similar to England but only a population of 4.6 million compared to their over 60 million. Surrounded by water sitting in the southern hemisphere and far away from the rest of the world. So sheltered that a shortage of marmite or a penguin showing up on the beach from Antarctica is headline news for weeks. And she is beautiful just search New Zealand landscapes on the net.   

Raise funds to contribute to the purchase of cropping land with accommodation. The more raised the more options available the sky's the limit. We can start small and build the sanctuary in stages.

Fund this stage by becoming a citizen of the sanctuary or come stay with us for a week accommodation and food is on us. And while here go fishing, bush walking, snowboarding, mountain biking, search for hobbits or just lie on the beach and relax. 

Goals

To provide asstance to those who want to get to and build a new life in New Zealand.

To provide a safe enviroment which is unaffected by the outside world.

The enviroment to be self sustaining its own power supply and food and water supply.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell people about us.

story:
The April Hill Park Wetland Story

Tucked away in a corner of SW Portland just west of Multnomah Village, there is a special place that is home to salamanders, newts, frogs, sixty-nine species of birds, and several species of wetland plants that are uncommon in urban areas.  Many park visitors don't know this wetland exists.  The natural area doesn't have any official trails or signage. Steep, muddy slopes with blackberry thickets make the approach challenging for all but the most adventurous souls.

For several years, Maplewood neighbors, local students, park managers and other visitors have wanted clearer, safer access to the wetland.  However, park budgets have been cut by about 20% over the last several years.  Recently we received a significant award of funding -- and we have the opportunity to make it happen!


The Need

Right now, people entering the wetland trudge through dense vegetation and standing water.  Because there aren't any defined trails, narrow and muddy paths criss-cross through the wetland.  Some park visitors also use the area for illegal dog off-leash activity.  This has increased the spread of invasive plants, which frequently outcompete wetland natives.  It has also compacted the soil and increased sediment and bacteria in the water.  Finally, local elementary, preschool and after school program leaders have stated that they would like to be able to bring youth to the wetland, but have concerns about safe access.  

Beyond the wetland, people enjoy seeing the creek.  However, the only way across is a fallen log.  The lack of a trail has resulted in foot traffic suppressing vegetation along the creek bank and increasing bank erosion, which makes the water in Woods Creek even worse.


The Plan

If the campaign is funded, we will be able to apply for permits in winter 2013-14 and expect to construct the project in summer 2014.  The concept, subject to final design and review, is for:

  • 2,000 feet of sustainable soft surface trail 
  • About 900 feet of low-profile boardwalk with handrail
  • Two bridges across Woods Creek that will help protect the banks from erosion
  • A wetland observation platform with benches, large enough to accommodate a classroom of students
  • Signs that tell the story of the wetland, its uniqueness in the urban setting, and who lives there

Rendering by Joanne Hogarth


The Results

Since 2005, Friends of April Hill Park have served as volunteer stewards of the wetland.  We've held work parties, taught local youth about this area, and helped Portland Parks & Recreation improve management of the natural area.  When the final fundraising is complete, we'll be ready to implement this project that was planned in 2010.  Construction of the boardwalk, bridges and observation platform will:

  • Provide a place for elementary school youth to get outside, and learn science from nature.
  • New soft surface trails will be more sustainable, minimize erosion and other impacts to water quality, and create a new access point from a dead-end street into the park and natural area.
  • The boardwalk will alleviate the negative impacts of social trails that currently criss-cross the wetland and degrade habitat.
  • Bridges will allow vegetation along the creek to regrow and increase the stability of the bank.
  • Signage will help underscore to park visitors why off-trail and dog off-leash activity introduces bacteria and invasive plants, which are harmful to the wetland.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not able to contribute, you can help in other ways:

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools below to spread the word on Facebook, Twitter or email.  Tell your friends!
  • Take the young people you know outside to spend time in nature!  As urban development increases pressure on these areas, we need to know, value and protect them more than ever before.
  • Email aprilhillpark@gmail.com to receive quarterly updates about work parties and other events.

story:
This campaign is raising funds on behalf of Lake Baikal Heritage Foundation, a verified nonprofit. The campaign does not necessarily reflect the views of the nonprofit or have any formal association with it. All contributions are considered unrestricted gifts and can't be specified for any particular purpose.

This ride is different...

Many of you have followed my motorcycling adventures over the past few years - the Sierras, Alaska, Wild West Tour - and now...Mongolia??!!  But this one is different. While I will get to enjoy the very things that make adventure motorcycling dear to my heart - scenery, back-country adventure, mountains, meeting people along the way - this one has a cause.
Lake Hovsgol is an ecological crown jewel and a newly established national park in Mongolia. It is one of a handful of "ancient lakes" millions of years old and providing a large percentage of Mongolia's fresh water.  But it's in trouble...illegal poaching, mining, development...and a band of park rangers that have put everything - including their lives at times - on the line to protect it. They patrol an area larger than Yellowstone National Park on dilapidated Chinese motorcycles...the few they have...or horses which are even less effective against poachers making getaways in 4-wheel drive land cruisers.

Here's what I am asking

I am raising funds to buy one motorcycle and safety gear to outfit a ranger.  On my own dime I am going to go to Mongolia to deliver it to the ranger in person. Entire airfare comes out of my own pocket, and I am volunteering my time both here with fundraising and coordination, and in Mongolia with coordination and delivery.

Why it matters

The Lake and surrounding wildlife area is a National Park bigger than Yellowstone and strictly protected as a transition zone between Central Asian Steppe and the Siberian Taiga.  It's one of 17 ancient lakes that are more than 2 million years old, and the water is so clean you can drink it without any treatment.  There are a number of indigenous people that live around it and depend on it for their water supply.  In fact  it contains 70% of all the surface freshwater supply for the whole country of Mongolia.  There is no body of water this clean and this large in America. None.  Imagine what Lake Tahoe was like 400 years ago...thats what Lake Hovsgol is now and its 4 times as big.

So what's threatening it?

Illegal poaching, including illegal drift net fishing, illegal logging: The lake has fish, including two endemic species, and since it's a lake, those fish can easily become overfished as every other fish population in the world has become.  The surrounding parklands are home to a number of really awesome animals, including ibex, argali, elk, wolf, wolverine, musk deer, brown bear, Siberian moose, and sable.

Mongolia has done a good job designating this area as a wildlife preserve to protect the survival of these animals, but enforcement is challenging.  Rangers have been stabbed and injured trying to enforce the law against poachers, who stand to make a great deal of money in the short term.

Illegal development and tourism: It shouldn't be news to Americans that people in and from outside Mongolia are eager to develop properties around the lake.  Rangers have caught individuals simply building around it without permits. Run-off and pollution from illegal development and road building is certain to pollute the lake, as well as impact wildlife habitat.  Additionally outsiders have come in and started developing environmental tourism projects without necessarily caring for the habitat or obtaining permission.

But they have rangers to enforce the laws, right?

Yes, the whole park is about 4,600 square miles (1.2mm hectares) and there are 15 permanent rangers and a few seasonal ones.  Each ranger patrols over 300 square miles of park, which is about the same size as all the boroughs in New York City.  And they do it mostly on horseback.  For reference, Yellowstone is smaller and has 300 permanent Park Rangers.  Imagine if there was only one policeman in a space as big as the five boroughs of New York City, and he was on horseback chasing bad guys in jeeps.

The poachers and illegal users in the park tool around in jeeps, 4x4's, and other vehicles.  Did I also mention the poachers are armed?

The rangers have asked for help in the form of offroad motorcycles, gear, and training.  With modern offroad motorcycles, they could patrol more effectively and discourage lawbreakers.

So why do I care, and how can I help?

It's true, Mongolia is halfway around the world, but I care, and here's why:

  • We don't have that many wild places left in the world.  
  • We don't have that much wildlife left in the world.
  • I love nature, I spend a lot of time in nature, and it's not often that I get to actually do hands-on volunteering to not only help protect one of the last pristine natural places in the world, but at the same time help improve the work life of an individual who is protecting this area. That's just awesome!

Even if you aren't moved by this situation, I ask that you support me in my effort to keep this wild area as pristine as possible. You can help by donating to help cover the cost of a motorcycle and equipment.

Where does the money go?

100% of the money you donate is tax-deductible, and goes to buy and ship the motorcycle and equipment. I am paying my own ticket over, and the Mongol Ecology Center is not taking any of it for administration, it all goes directly to equipment for the rangers! 

I am trying to fund one motorcycle and equipment.  I am trying to raise enough to outfit one ranger.  Any additional money goes to buying a second motorcycle if I exceed my fundraising goal.  

If I raise additional funds, but not enough for an entire motorcycle and gear, the Mongol Ecology Center has agreed to pool it with the funds raised by other volunteers to fund another complete motorcycle.

100% of the money you donate is tax-deductible, and goes to buy and ship the motorcycle and equipment. I am paying my own ticket over, and the Mongol Ecology Center is not taking any of it for administration, it all goes directly to equipment for the rangers! 
I am trying to fund one motorcycle and equipment.  I am trying to raise enough to outfit one ranger.  Any additional money goes to buying a second motorcycle if I exceed my fundraising goal.  
If I raise additional funds, but not enough for an entire motorcycle and gear, the Mongol Ecology Center has agreed to pool it with the funds raised by other volunteers to fund another complete motorcycle.

story:
Zero-emission farming in West Africa

Be apart of establishing a new sustainable model of holistic community farming. 

Our goal is to establish a new model, reliant on the use renewable energy equipment that will increase agricultural productivity while reducing carbon footprint, as well as develop local entrepreneurship. 

9.8 acres of farmland in Burkina Faso run by local social enterprise, Burkina Énergie & Technologies Appropriées  (BETA) has been designated for the development of innovative green farming.  The farm will be used to raise chickens, guinea fowl, quails and turkeys.  Also there will be a botanical garden to preserve natural species.  The farm will integrate a training program to teach innovative farming techniques to women from the local community so they may develop efficient techniques to raise poultry to be sold in local markets.

The goal of the present project is to set up initial operations of the farm including:

  • Cost of solar powered water pump
  • Cost of fence to surround 9.8 acres
  • Expanding an existing training center and initiate a program to support training of women in modern farming techniques using sustainable energy equipment. 
  • Testing of a Biodigester - Innovative Renewable Energy Equipment

 A biodigester developed by Titilope Fadipe, Founder of D.I.Y Renewables provides an innovative means of converting household waste to electricity 

Biodigester

o   The biodigester will be tested in new farming techniques

o  Revenue will be generated by selling of slurry as compost.

o  We will train women from the community on how to assemble a Biodigester and use the biogas for cooking at home instead of using firewood, kerosine and charcoal.


Expected Results of our pilot project:

Efficient and innovative green farming 

Job development

Entrepreneurship 


History of BETA and ÉnergieRich:

Boureima Kabré's organization, BETA has been successful in introducing widespread use of solar panels, portable solar lamps etc. that has sparked the establishment of innovative enterprises such as cell phone charging stations and allowed for expanded business hours for local shops.  Since it inception, BETA has installed over 400 solar panels and solar lighting in homes, businesses, schools, health care and women’s centers, in the provinces of Kourittenga, Boulgou and Namentenga, situated in the Center East and Center North Regions of Burkina Faso.  Children use solar powered lanterns to do their homework at night, use of solar panels allows for nighttime entertainment and recreation for youth. Local employment is created through programs, which train people to install solar panels in homes, businesses and schools.  A solar powered internet café was established in Koupela which attracts local residents and students from surrounding communities, sometimes travelling miles to use the internet café.

Very rapidly the work of BETA has generated employment on the ground, notably through paid services such as, recharging cell phone batteries, recharging solar lamps, video clubs, etc. This initial experience demonstrates to local actors immediate economic opportunities with positive social and environmental impacts.

ÉnergieRich was established to scale the current operations of BETA. The goal of the present pilot project is to implement a more ambitious project capable of integrating new economic activities, to create employment and an overall reduction of costs of renewable energy products.


BETA's successful model which introduces solar energy to rural areas is being scaled up to integrate renewable energy use in agricultural techniques.  80% percent of the population in Burkina Faso is engaged in subsistence farming. Ultimately we envision increased agricultural productivity and an established model for profitable local entrepreneurship through the introduction of locally produced renewable energy equipment.

story:
"Water is the most critical resource issue of our lifetime and our children's lifetime. The health of our waters is the principal measure of how we live on the land." - Luna Leopold

The Los Angeles River is a crucial resource for the City that many Angelenos are completely unaware of; neglected and abused, yet still vital and beautiful. At The River Project, we have always made community education and empowerment central to any project we undertake.

The Paddle The LA River Program

We believe that getting people out IN the river is the most visceral and compelling way to create an educated constituency for the Los Angeles River and its watershed. This belief inspired The River Project to develop an educational boating program for the Los Angeles River so that all Angelenos would be able to experience the river as a river and come to appreciate it as much as we do.

In 2011, the Los Angeles Conservation Corps, the MRCA, Urban Semillas, and the City of Los Angeles got on board - and together, with the blessing of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers, 'Paddle the LA River' was born. The 2012 Paddle program runs July 21 through September 26, with more trips scheduled and more opportunity for education.

Our 2012 Educational Goal:

This summer we have the chance to sponsor paddle trips for up to 200 underserved youth, including transportation and a day of Los Angeles River Watershed education both before and after the paddle. We are focusing on local at-risk and differently-abled kids:

  • Giving kids real scientific understanding of the river, its history, and its potential as a resource for the City.
  • Empowering kids to embrace their environment and effect change, through the projects they plan and design.
  • Leading them on an exciting afternoon adventure that most Angelenos probably haven’t even imagined.

Our educational curriculum meets California State Science Standards, and includes the history of the river, the science of the watershed ecosystem, and future possibilities for sustainable watershed management. In-class instruction is dynamic and hands-on.

Why The River Project?

Since 2001, The River Project has provided watershed education in elementary classes as an important part of each of our major projects. Kids who've come through our programs have accomplished some amazing things, like the design of the Great Toad Gate at at Valleyheart Greenway in Studio City, and the interpretive bench at Rio de Los Angeles State Park.

Kids who experience our hands-on curriculum learn why and how to advocate for a healthy Los Angeles watershed. They write letters, volunteer, and teach their families to make healthy changes that nurture our river.

What your contributions will do:

We want to take this adventure to 20 groups of kids, and the costs are considerable: transportation and equipment, in-class instruction and materials. Each $1000 we raise will sponsor one group.

Help us raise $20,000 to grow the next generation of watershed stewards!

The River Project is a 501(c)3 organization that advocates for a healthier Los Angeles River Watershed through scientific research, hands-on education, and community-based projects. Visit us any time on Facebook or at our website, theriverproject.org

story:
Who am I?

My name is Anna. I am a senior at Cornell University majoring in Food Science. I am interested in food product development and have experience working in this feild with various big food companies in the United States. This year, I was chosen to be a part of Cornell's Student Multidisciplinary Applied Research Team (SMART) Learn More:  http://ciifad.cornell.edu/engagement.cfm, http://ciifad.tumblr.com/ 

The COMACO team will be going to Zambia, Africa for 3 weeks in January to help expand the company's IT'S WILD! food brand. (See Below)

Our team has been in communication with COMACO representatives to begin preparation for the projects that we will be working on during our time in Zambia. Some of the products that they have asked for our help on are:

- Fruit Jams, Dried Mango, Breakfast Cereal, and Healthy Energy Bars

In addition to product development work, we will be working on food chemistry issues such as preservation and storage of the jams, uses of unripe or damaged mangoes in a microbibiologically safe way, preventing oxidation of the breakfast cereal, and packaging of the energy bars to promote extended shelf life. 

We will also be helping COMACO in creating process development and business strategy plans for their IT'S WILD! brand. After returning from Africa, we will be writing a comprehensive study to report back to COMACO with our suggestions of how to proceed with their brand.

What is the funding for?

I was already chosen to be a part of the COMACO SMART team. However, as a member of the team, I need to find my own funding for the trip. The project has been partially funded by the Cornell International Institute for Food, Agriculture, and Development and by the Cornell Food Science Department. I need to raise additional funds to pay for airfare, vaccines, in-country travel, and lodging. 

Every contribution you make will help me get closer to making this project a reality. I have already begun planning great ideas to help solve the food science challenges they have requested our help with and have collected food analytical supplies to bring along that will be donated to COMACO. Now I just need to get there!

If you are not able to make a monetary contribution you can still help out in a much needed way - you can forward this page on to all your friends! Post this page to your facebook or Twitter!!

What is COMACO?

http://www.itswild.org/ 

Community Markets for Conservation (COMACO), is a non-profit foundation that works along with the Wildlife Conservation Society (WCS) to reduce human hunger and poverty while saving wild animals and ecosystems.

Poachers were killing thousands of animals a year, putting many of them onto the endangered species list. It was found that the poachers were hunting the animals as a source of food to feed their starving families. The agricultural products on which they based their livlihood were failing - whether because of bad weather conditions, ineffective planting techniques, or the inability to transport the products to trading areas. Environmentalist groups recognized this issue and sought to fix it. This is how COMACO came about. 

A program has been set up where poachers can trade in their guns and snares for lessons in sustainable agriculture. They are trained in the skills and given the supplies they need to grow a variety of crops that will flourish in the conditions of the Luangwa Valley. Because a major issue had been that there was no one to sell the agricultural products to, COMACO also set up a system of buying many of these raw materials. The company then turns these materials into value added food products, which are sold throughout Africa under their personal brand IT'S WILD!.

What is IT'S WILD!?

http://www.itswild.org/its-wild-natural-foods 

IT'S WILD! is COMACO's own food brand under which they sell the value added foods made from the local farmer's agricultural products. Their main products currently include: Honey, Rice, Peanut Butter, Yummy Soy, and Ground Nuts. They recently launched their first Breakfast Cereal! 

The company, with our help, is now looking to move to produce fruit jams, dried fruit products, energy bars, quick-cooking bean products, as well as more cereal varieties.

story:
Sunplugged-on-Hudson

Greetings! My name is james dean conklin and i'm part of a solar-powered band called Solar Punch. We have been using solar-energy exclusively to power our gear and sing about climate challenges and environmental issues since 2007. We work in New York and India, learning about new and old green tech as we go, and sharing solutions whenever and wherever we find them.

This coming May 18th, we will join with many of our local green entrepreneurs and activists in Hastings-on-Hudson, New York, to communicate, celebrate and share the positive, real-world examples of where these solutions are in place and working right now.  On a beautiful park next to the mighty Hudson River, artists, musicians, scientists, technologists, environmentalists and activists will bring the good news - there is a green future on the horizon and we're headed towards it!

Bio-gas & bio-digesters, waste-to-energy schemes, composting, solar electric, solar cooking, recycling, up-cycling, organic gardening - mostly simple yet effective modes and methods to reduce energy consumption, remediate environmental insults and ensure best practices for safe, happy, healthful lives.

We believe providing positive models and examples to answer these intense eco and climate challenges is the most effective way to inspire and motivate. We hope you do too!

What We're Asking for and How we'll use it

We're asking for a modest $3,500 to help pay the musicians, pay for a small bank of batteries for our off-grid solar set-up and help defray the cost of our raffle prizes and 'give-aways'

  • A major component of this event is music.
    • We know from experience that music is one of the best ways to gather people together, transmit information and celebrate.
    • We are working with local Folk Music collective Tribes Hill to bring some of the area's top talent to our solar-stage. This stage will have plenty of capacity for the random Marshall stack and / or sensitive keyboardist!
  • Musicians
    • Hope Machine featuring Fred Gillen Jr. & Steve Kirkman - activism, optimism, ism, ism, ism.
    • Solar Punch, original music about the environment and Bollywood hits! Bhot Acha!
    • Roshni, featuring meditations, Sanskrit Mantras and devotional folk music. Ohm Shanti.
    • More to be announced soon...
  • Perks
    • Copies of CDs from our musical entertainers
    • Posters with unique art designed for our event
    • Solar Lanterns for your next camping trek or power-outage
  • To Goal or not to Goal
    • If we reach our goal, Huzzah!! Thank You!
    • If we DON'T reach our goal - Huzzah!! We'll take whatever we can get! 

Look, this is going forward and its important.

We see and hear an unbalanced mix of negative and pessimistic news & opinions about our country's renewable energy prospects. We are going to change the tenor and tone of the conversation by providing models of how these things work, stories and evidence from individuals involved in solutions-based livelihoods and a delicious blanket of warm and hopeful songs and sounds from our beautiful musicians.

This event is meant to showcase the positive. And it Will!

And to repeat our main sentiment from above = We believe providing positive models and examples to answer these intense eco and climate challenges is the most effective way to inspire and motivate. We want to be the change we hope to see in others. 

We hope you do too!

story:
Resumen

El bosque de Wawashang, y la reserva natural de Kahka Creek, es un proyecto ecologico de la ong FADCANIC. 
Se construyo un hotel para ecoturismo, y recibir estudiantes, visitantes y sientificos. El objetivo es proteger 600 hectareas de bosque tropical
EL proyecto se encuentra alejado de las grandes ciudades, por eso no llega lo suficiente de turismo, para hacer sostenible economicamente al proyecto.
Sin los guarda bosques, los ganaderos va a convertir esta maravilla de la naturaleza, donde viven monos y tigres, en pastizales para vacas. 
Que necesitamos
Tenemos 5 guarda bosques, que cuidan la reserva natural. Tambien se ocupan de un proyecto de reforestacion, ademas de guiar a los turistas que visitan el bosque. 
Los ingresos del hotel no son suficientes para pagar los salarios de los guarda bosques. 

 El impacto

El bosque de Kahka Creek tiene tucanes, aves, monos, tigres, pumas y una gran variedad de animales y plantas.
Ademas se cuida un Tapir, un animal en peligro de extinsion. 
Salvando este bosque, es un regalo para el futuro.

story:
On Wednesday October 15 2014 the Wolf trapping Season will start and in December 2014 "hunting" with hounds season will open in the State of Wisconsin. The only State allowing this form of "Hunting".
 This means hounds that have been trained by "huntsman" will be used to chase down Wolves and their pups. Wolves will naturally defend areas near their dens, pups, fresh kills and rendezvous sites.

We're gearing up for a long haul to be in the changing weather within the States of Montana, Wisconsin, Wyoming and Idaho.

Info about hunting Wolves with hounds-

Rendezvous site (Courtesy of the WI DNR site)-

"Adult wolves are very defensive of pups at rendezvous sites and will attack other predators, including dogs, that get too close to the rendezvous site or the pups. Wolves are probably most aggressive toward strange wolves and dogs at den and rendezvous sites when their pups are small, during the breeding season in January and February and when they are protecting a fresh kill.

Found within a wolf pack's territory, den and rendezvous sites are specific locations used for breeding and other pack activities. Wolves begin moving their young pups from dens to rendezvous sites from mid-March to mid-May. Rendezvous sites are actively used from mid-May to mid-October."

         

         The WI wolf season, approved unanimously by the Natural Resources Board, is egregious in the extreme on many counts: high kill quota, night hunting, baiting, electronic calls, more. But the primitive cruelty of hunting wolves with dogs sets the stage for what dog expert Patricia McConnell says is "state sanctioned dog fighting"

This is cruel and completely unnecessary! The season hasn't even started and due to Hunting Hounds being run through Wolf territory on Public lands in the previous months this year of 2014, there's already been 27 dog depredations. 

* http://dnr.wi.gov/topic/wildlifehabitat/wolf/dogdeps.html

This Season of 2014/2015 we need your help with donations (monetary and supplies) so we can again remain active in the field.
    The Funding we need go's directly towards monitoring several Hunting areas, fuel, vehicle maintenance, none perishable food, basic supplies, two way radios, cameras, camping gear and warm clothing.
We'd also be quite happy to receive any of these items as gifts towards the campaign and future campaigns, below is a list of items we need.

1) Non perishable Vegan food.
2)Gas cards. *
3) Hand held water proof video camera or GoPro. *
4) Food cards. *
5) Vehicle maintenance.
6) Telescope.
7) GPS device. *
8) Binoculars.

  *-Priority items

The Hunt Saboteurs have been active for years in the United States and for over 50 years in the UK & EU. Defending wildlife, standing between hunter and hunted.
  This year of 2014/15 Wisconsin has opened hunting Wolves with hounds, already hounds are being trained. Many Dogs, Wolves and Wolf pups will lose their lives in this barbaric act of so called "hunting"!
    With your help we hope to have a stronger presence in the field and minimal to zero Wolves (or hounds) will be killed.
  We also realize not everyone is able to make a donation, so we ask that you use your Facebook pages or any online social media to make aware of this ongoing Wolf slaughter. We ask that you educate yourselves on the situation, share our request for donations, take the time to write emails and make phone calls sharing your disappointment in this senseless and unnecessary killing of Americas Wild Wolves.
     We're a mixed group of concerned citizens, coming from several backgrounds who plan to remain legally within our rights to be on public lands, taking a stand for these essential wild animals.
story_txt:
On Wednesday October 15 2014 the Wolf trapping Season will start and in December 2014 "hunting" with hounds season will open in the State of Wisconsin. The only State allowing this form of "Hunting".  This means hounds that have been trained by "huntsman" will be used to chase down Wolves and their pups. Wolves will naturally defend areas near their dens, pups, fresh kills and rendezvous sites. We're gearing up for a long haul to be in the changing weather within the States of Montana, Wisconsin, Wyoming and Idaho.Info about hunting Wolves with hounds-Rendezvous site (Courtesy of the WI DNR site)-"Adult wolves are very defensive of pups at rendezvous sites and will attack 
        other predators, including dogs, that get too close to the rendezvous 
        site or the pups. Wolves are probably most aggressive toward strange wolves and dogs at den and 
        rendezvous sites when their pups are small, during the breeding season 
        in January and February and when they are protecting a fresh kill.  
Found within a wolf pack's territory, den and rendezvous sites are 
        specific locations used for breeding and other pack activities. Wolves 
        begin moving their young pups from dens to rendezvous sites from mid-March 
        to mid-May. Rendezvous sites are actively used from mid-May to mid-October."
          
         The WI wolf season, approved unanimously by the Natural Resources Board,
 is egregious in the extreme on many counts: high kill quota, night 
hunting, baiting, electronic calls, more. But the primitive cruelty of 
hunting wolves with dogs sets the stage for what dog expert Patricia 
McConnell says is "state sanctioned dog fighting"
This is cruel and completely unnecessary! The season hasn't even started and due to Hunting Hounds being run through Wolf territory on Public lands in the previous months this year of 2014, there's already been 27 dog depredations. 
* http://dnr.wi.gov/topic/wildlifehabitat/wolf/dogdeps.html
 This Season of 2014/2015 we need your help with donations (monetary and supplies) so we can again remain active in the field.    The Funding we need go's directly towards monitoring several Hunting areas, 
fuel, vehicle maintenance, none perishable food, basic supplies, two way
 radios, cameras, camping gear and warm clothing. 
We'd also be quite happy to receive any of these items as gifts 
towards the campaign and future campaigns, below is a list of items we 
need.1) Non perishable Vegan food.2)Gas cards. *3) Hand held water proof video camera or GoPro. *4) Food cards. *5) Vehicle maintenance.6) Telescope.7) GPS device. *8) Binoculars.  *-Priority itemsThe Hunt 
Saboteurs have been active for years in the United States and for over 50 years
 in the UK & EU. Defending wildlife, standing between hunter and hunted.  
 This year of 2014/15 Wisconsin has opened hunting Wolves with hounds, already 
hounds are being trained. Many Dogs, Wolves and Wolf pups will lose 
their lives in this barbaric act of so called "hunting"!

 We also realize not everyone is able to make a donation, so we ask that
 you use your Facebook pages or any online social media to make aware 
of this ongoing Wolf slaughter. We ask that you educate yourselves on the situation, share our request for 
donations, take the time to write emails and make phone calls sharing 
your disappointment in this senseless and unnecessary killing of Americas Wild Wolves.      We're a mixed group of concerned citizens, coming from several backgrounds who plan to remain legally within our rights to be on public lands, taking a stand for these essential wild animals.

story:
The Niue Whale Research Project

The Niue Whale Research Project is a partnership between local and international researchers who volunteer their time and expertise to help the tiny island country of Niue to protect some of the world's most endangered whales. 

In order to continue this vital conservation work, however, we need your help. 


Background 

Niue is a small Pacific Island country, but an extremely important place for some of the world’s great whales – namely, the Oceania Humpback Whale. While humpback whale populations in Australia and North America have grown steadily in recent decades, those in Niue and the Pacific Islands region are not recovering from past exploitation.

Humpbacks are the most charismatic of the large whales, known for their acrobatic behaviours and haunting whale song, and many stop by Niue each year to rest, mate and nurse their young as they make their annual migration through the tropics. The Government of Niue declared a national whale sanctuary in 2003; however, the impacts of pollution, fishing practices and an expanding tourism industry continue to burden these amazing creatures here and elsewhere.

As their numbers are not increasing over time, the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN) recently upgraded the Oceania Humpback Whale’s conservation status, identifying them as a species of greater international concern.  

What We Do

The NWRP has been active since 2008, combining science and research with government and community outreach to support Niue's National Whale Sanctuary. Our small volunteer team collects valuable data in the waters surrounding Niue island, but also ensures that this data is shared with all stakeholders by consulting government on policy and management strategies, training tourism and water-based industries and delivering educational programs throughout the local community.

Since beginning, our work has helped to develop Niue’s first whale and dolphin catalogue – a vital first step to identifying animals and populations across the region – and our team have been instrumental in helping to establish a greater understanding of conservation strategies and goals in the country. The NWRP has also empowered many Niuean volunteers and partners with research skills and knowledge, to increase local ownership of the Project and move toward a time when our programs may be delivered independently by the Niuean community.

It is rare that such a depth of experience and skills comes together to protect endangered species while also empowering local communities to do the same in the long term. Ultimately though, we believe that Niueans are best placed to help Niuean whales, and it is only by engaging the whole community positively and productively that they will be protected appropriately for future generations.

Budget Breakdown

Our Project has always relied on fundraising efforts from our supporters, our team members and the community.  We have already secured funding for two team members' airfares to Niue, as well as a boat charter for the entire field season however, in order to continue our vital work, we need additional funding. 

None of our volunteer researchers are paid for their contributions or time. Rather, pledges will support the team to conduct a targeted research season in September 2014 and to deliver the extensive community and government engagement activities explained above. Funds are needed for:

  • Final airfare to Niue:       $800
  • Boat fuel:                           $2000
  • Accommodation:             $1500
  • Ground Transportation:  $300
  • Provisions:                         $1000
  • Indiegogo fee:                   $400
Total:                                         $6000

The Research Team - Who Are We?

Fiafia Rex, Director, Oma Tafua

Fiafia Rex is the founder and current Director of Oma Tafua ("to treasure whales"), a Niuean non-government organisation dedicated to protecting marine mammals in Niue, and the Pacific Islands' only locally run whale conservation organisation. Fiafia is a graduate of the University of the South Pacific (USP) with a background in Marine Affairs, and has attended and participated in several regional workshops and meetings, including for the South Pacific Regional Environment Programme (SPREP), pertinent to the conservation of marine mammals in the Pacific. Fiafia has been involved in the Niue Whale Research Project since its inception, and has assisted in the development of Niue's Plan of Management for its Whale Sanctuary. 

Olive Andrews, Marine Scientist, Whaleology

Olive Andrews is a research scientist of the South Pacific Whale Research Consortium (SPWRC), and Director of the consultancy Whaleology. Olive holds a degree in Marine Science and Management from Southern Cross University/The National Marine Science Centre and a Marine Coxswain Ticket and leads international research and conservation programs for whales and the management of whale watching industries. 

She has been involved in photo ID, acoustic and behavioural research on marine mammals in Australia, Hawaii, Canada and extensively across the Pacific Islands for more than 20 years. Since 1999 Olive has developed and provided specialised training and technical advice on marine mammal conservation and management to governments and industry of the South Pacific. This work has seen the development of Pacific regional whale watching guidelines and National whale sanctuaries in Tonga, Niue, Samoa, Vanuatu,Tokelau and Palau.

Ben Parangi, Research and Education

Ben Parangi has a degree in International Community Development and has worked extensively on whale conservation, climate change and health issues in Pacific Island countries, including Niue, Palau and Samoa. He has been a member of the Niue Whale Research Project since 2010, conducting research and delivering whale and dolphin educational programs to Australian and Pacific communities. Ben has also been involved with training whale watching operators and has consulted the Australian government on issues of cetacean (whale and dolphin) and whale watching management.

You can read more from Ben and the NWRP at:

http://commongroundaustralia.com/byronbay/commu...

story: Thank You for backing us!
story_txt: Thank You for backing us!

story:
The International Women’s Earth and Climate Initiative (IWECI) is hosting the International Women’s Earth and Climate Summit (September 20 through 23, 2013) bringing together global leaders ranging from grassroots activists, economists, scientists, businesswomen, indigenous leaders, policy-makers, faith leaders, cultural professionals in a major gathering to collectively work on climate change and sustainability solutions. We need your support to raise the remaining $20,000 to fund this event!

Our goals include drafting a Women’s Climate Action Agenda - a blueprint for action that can be implemented from the grassroots to the UN policy levels.
http://www.iweci.org/summit

Believing in the power of women to change the world, we are especially excited that the Summit will allow us to hear from local, grassroots and indigenous women leaders. These women, usually the most directly impacted by climate change are also at the forefront of finding immediate and creative working solutions. 

IWECI has been supporting a growing women’s action movement around climate change and sustainability solutions. We are working in coalition to stop the escalation of these problems, while accelerating the implementation of solutions through women’s empowerment, organizational partnerships, hands-on trainings, advocacy campaigns, and political, economic, social and environmental action. 

Some of Summit delegates include: Dr. Jane Goodall, best known for her work to save the chimpanzees; Hon. Christiana Figueres, Executive Secretary of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC); and, Hon. Mary Robinson, former United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. Delegates from the grassroots and indigenous communities include Melina Laboucan-Massimo, a first nations woman from Canada who is a key activist working on the Tar Sands issue; Hon. Marina Silva, originally an organizer of rubber tappers in the Amazon, eventually becoming the Environmental Minister of Brazil; and, Neema Namadau working in the Congo for the promotion of women’s rights and forest protection.

We are still actively seeking funds to cover the hosting of all of these amazing women. Additionally, since many women around the world do not have internet access we are making it a priority to set up "IWECI Summit Vision Hubs" world-wide. These are designated sites with internet access where women (and men!) can gather to collectively watch and participate in the plenary sessions of the Summit via interactive media.

Our goal is to raise $20,000 by September 20th, the opening day of the Summit. With your support we are hopeful that we can make this Summit a historic one - both for the on-site delegates and for those participating from afar through our Vision Hubs. We assure you - every dollar you donate will go directly to supporting these women and promise to make the most of your donation!

All donations over $25 will be thanked publicly on the IWECI International Summit website.

For a $50 donation we will send you a commemorative photo of the gathered Summit delegates.

For donations of $100 and above you will also receive a copy of the Summit Declaration.

For donations of $200 and above you will also receive a copy of the Women’s Climate Action Agenda.

For donations of $500 and above you will also receive a DVD with the Summit highlights, including the keynote speeches.

For donations of $1000 and above you will receive a DVD set of the Summit plenary and key sessions, including the keynote speeches, in addition to the photo and the Summit outcome documents.

Even if you cannot contribute at this time, spreading the word about our campaign would be a great help! We expect this International Summit to have a far reaching impact and make a real difference in mobilizing and increasing the collective work by women on climate change and sustainability solutions.

Please make use of the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Oil Drilling in the Amazon Rainforest

On August 15, 2013, Ecuador announced that it was opening protected land in the beautiful Yasuni basin to oil development. Just two days later, trucks began to roll into the rainforest, the "lungs of the world",  to begin drilling.  As I helplessly watched thousands of Ecuadorians demonstrate from a continent  away, I wondered what I could do to stop this environmental disaster.

I'm the owner of a small online clothing shop on the West Coast of the US, providing pretty dresses for weddings and prom.  I don't know how to save the world. I've never even been to Ecuador.  The enormity of making an impact seemed far out of my reach. It would take billions of dollars to reverse Ecuador's decision on oil drilling. How could I, on my own, make even the slightest ripple?  It seemed impossible.


And yet, as I watched thousands of Ecuadorian citizens passionately demonstrate against the oil rigs, I felt the insistent urge to be in that square with them.  After all, I thought, they're not just fighting for their own country's well being, they are fighting to protect us all.  I couldn't understand why, after all the accolades Ecuador's no-drill plan had initially received in 2007, we weren't already doing something.  I felt powerless, frustrated.  And I wondered, am I the only one who's listening?

But let's go back a bit. In 2007, in a landmark initiative after 30 years of severe oil-industry caused pollution, Ecuador offered to protect its Amazon rainforest lands from oil development, if the combined nations of the world would pay their share -  half the market value of the oil, approximately 3.6 billion US dollars.  In 2009 at the Copenhagen Climate Change Summit, the assembled nations voted to provide a Global Green Fund, which would provide 100 billion US dollars each year to developing countries to fund environmental issues.  But, by 2013, the Green Fund is still in the planning stages, and only a fraction of the money Ecuador needs to defray their costs has been raised.  In the meantime, Ecuador's foreign debt to other countries, especially China, has mounted.  To Ecuador's President, Rafael Correa, the only way forward seems to be to exploit the oil, and pay back the debt.


It's time we took action together to preserve this irreplaceable natural asset.  Every day of drilling in Yasuni leads us closer to the day when the most diverse habitat on Earth is gone forever.  We can't wait any longer for governments to band together to solve this problem.  Individuals are the catalysts of change, and our leaders won't prioritize the environment until we demand they do.  We've been waiting for a commonsense global change to environmental policy for far too long.  If the world's governments won't preserve the Earth's most important CO2 purifier, the world's citizens will simply have to show them how.  Let's act now to hold up our end of the bargain with Ecuador, and preserve the integrity of the most important habitat in the world.  Let's be part of real, tangible change.  Let's make the impossible possible, and be the largest crowd funded project in history to protect the most important habitat on earth.



What We Need & What You Get

Ecuador has asked for 3.6 billion dollars, roughly half the market value of the oil to prohibit oil development. That's alot of money - about 52 cents for every person on the planet.  But money talks. The top 5 oil companies reported profits of $100 billion in 2012 alone.  Until there's a global tax on those profits to pay for environmental projects, we'll have to lead the way. Let's aim to raise half that money, that's 1.8 billion dollars, and show our governments how it's done!

I want your contribution to make a real difference. I'm partnering with World Land Trust , who have a 20 year history of purchasing and protecting lands in conjunction with local peoples in Ecuador, Columbia, Bolivia, and throughout the Amazon. Your donation, no matter how small or large will make a real, tangible difference. It's also tax deductible, (so you can give a little more)!

Sir David Attenborough is their patron. Learn more about them here: http://www.worldlandtrust.org

As a contributor to the largest crowd funding project in history, you can breathe easy, knowing you've contributed to real, tangible change in the most important environment in the world. 

You will continue to benefit from the powerful C02 exchange the Amazon rainforest provides.

And you will know you have answered the call of thousands of Ecuadorians who are protesting the pollution to their water systems, the destruction of the delicate interlinked habitats of the rainforest, and the devastating human cost in lives lost to skin disease and cancer oil drilling has caused in Yasuni in the past 30 years.

We aim to raise enough money to get governments around the world to provide matching funds to convince Ecuador to reverse its decision on oil development.

We will work with the World Land Trust to purchase acreage in oil-rich Amazonian regions to protect biodiversity with the help of the World Land Trust.

Donating even a small amount adds your powerful voice to our campaign.  Let governments and oil companies know that we demand change.  Now.

The Impact

The Amazon Rainforest is the largest carbon dioxide exchange in the world, taking in C02, and turning it into oxygen.  Without tropical rainforests, climate change will accelerate out of control.



The rainforest also swaps vast amounts of water and energy with the atmosphere and is thought to be important in controlling both local and regional climates, as well as ocean currents.

Indigenous peoples in Ecuador have been hard-hit by oil development in recent times.  You are helping them protect an intensive, bio-diverse habitat, with more species of plants, birds, mammals and insects per square acre than anywhere else on the planet! 

Scientists believe that less than 1% of flowering plants located there have been studied for their medicinal potential.  Some of these plants might save lives in future, if they can be preserved now.


Other Ways You Can Help

We'd love you to add your voice, even if you can't contribute huge wads of cash. Please tell your friends and family by sharing on indiegogo, and get them to join the conversation by visiting us at:

No Drill Ecuador YouTube

No Drill Ecuador Facebook

Let's work to providing a solution for Ecuador's Yasuni, together, now.

No Action Is No Answer. No Drill Ecuador!

And you will know you have answered the call of thousands of Ecuadorians who are protesting the pollution to their water systems, the destruction of the delicate interlinked habitats of the rainforest, and the devastating human cost in lives lost to skin disease and cancer oil drilling has caused in Yasuni in the past 30 years.
We aim to raise enough money to get governments around the world to provide matching funds to convince Ecuador to reverse its decision on oil development. 
We will work with the World Land Trust to purchase acreage in oil-rich Amazonian regions to protect biodiversity with the help of the World Land Trust. 
Donating even a small amount adds your powerful voice to our campaign.  Let governments and oil companies know that we demand change.  Now.


The Impact

The Amazon Rainforest is the largest carbon dioxide exchange in the world, taking in C02, and turning it into oxygen.  Without tropical rainforests, climate change will accelerate out of control.




The rainforest also swaps vast amounts of 
water and energy with the atmosphere and is thought to be important in 
controlling both local and regional climates, as well as ocean currents.
Indigenous peoples in Ecuador have been hard-hit by oil development in recent times.  You are helping them protect an intensive, bio-diverse habitat, with more species of plants, birds, mammals and insects per square acre than anywhere else on the planet!  
Scientists believe that less than 1% of flowering plants located there have been studied for their medicinal potential.  Some of these plants might save lives in future, if they can be preserved now.










Other Ways You Can Help
We'd love you to add your voice, even if you can't contribute huge wads of cash. Please tell your friends and family by sharing on indiegogo, and get them to join the conversation by visiting us at:
No Drill Ecuador YouTube
 No Drill Ecuador Facebook
Let's work to providing a solution for Ecuador's Yasuni, together, now.
No Action Is No Answer. No Drill Ecuador!

story:
Offer Kids a True Taste of Summer at Owl Camp!




















Help us bring back a true taste of summer for all the kids— canoeing, splashing in a cool creek, looking under rocks, and building forts until exhaustion hits— by supporting LandPaths’ Owl Camp Scholarship Drive 2014. 


With your support, this summer, LandPaths will:


Outreach to the kids that need Owl Camp most. LandPaths reaches out to families, with special attention to communities where the idea of summer camp may be unheard of, or only an unattainable dream.  Scholarships bring Owl Camp, and an enriching summer experience within reach. 

Get kids to camp—literally.  The reality is that many scholarship families are one-car families, with that car dedicated to the wage- earner.  LandPaths provides a ride to camp; your donation supports a camp van picking up and dropping off at Bayer Farm in Roseland each day.

Model Diversity. In ecology diversity is a strength, it the same with our community.  Owl Camp is a place where all kids can experience the richness of difference and recognize our common connection to nature –while having fun!

Do what LandPaths does best!  Kids can listen to a story in cave, be amazed by what an ant can carry, ponder a hole in a tree, sit within a sunflower tee-pee, eat kale (yes!) from the garden, and meet a real live owl, all the while learning from talented environmental educators.  

Your donation of $350 provides one child with tuition and transportation to camp for a week.   Our goal is to provide a minimum of 50 camp scholarships this year. Help us meet our Owl Camp goal of $3,000 by April 22nd (Earth Day!).

story:
We are the Forest Restoration Research Unit, a research group within Chiang Mai University's Science Faculty (northern Thailand). We were founded in 1994, to develop methods to restore tropical forests to degraded sites - and we've been quite successful. We now know which tree species to select, when to collect their seeds and the best ways to grow them in nurseries. Our trial plots have yielded effective methods to plant and care for trees until canopy closure is achieved and wildlife returns. Our methods can transform denuded hillsides into rich native forest ecosystems within about 10 years. Although the science is proven and the demand for forest restoration has never been higher, implementing it on a scale wide enough to significantly reduce global climate change, rural poverty and biodiversity losses remains difficult because:

  • growing saplings in a nursery is expensive and time consuming, requiring well-trained staff,
  • deforested areas are often steep and inaccessible, making it difficult to transport saplings, materials and labour to restoration sites and 
  • the labour needed for tree planting, weeding, fertilizer application and monitoring etc. often exceeds the local labour pool. Local people are unwilling to do such arduous, temporary and low paid work in remote locations. 

This campaign is to fund a workshop to explore the potential for automating some of the more difficult forest restoration tasks - we're calling it "auto-restoration" - by improving drone and visual recognition technologies and combining them with proven forest restoration practices. Could a new generation of intelligent, autonomous "dendrones" locate seed trees and transmit their GPS co-ordinates to seed collectors? Or could they be fitted with robotic arms to collect seeds themselves? How about aerial seeding by drone or even auto-weeding and fertilizer application? Could a drone be programmed to spray a non-residual, systemic herbicide on weeds, without harming young trees? 

To explore the feasibility of these and many other ideas, we will bring together forest ecologists with technologists - drone experts with seed experts, those working on plant taxonomy with those working on visual recognition systems, in a workshop, to draft a research agenda that will turn some of these concepts into reality. The workshop will be at the Grand View Hotel, Chiang Mai, Northern Thailand, January 27-30th 2015.

Take a look at the workshop plan here

What We Need & What You Get

Here we ask for core funding to run the workshop. The money will be spent to hire the venue, run the workshop, attract key speakers and produce and distribute the proceedings, including the research agenda. We aim to raise matching funds from academic sources and a small registration fee, for those who can afford it, to cover catering. However, those who could benefit most from auto-restoration - community groups and NGO's - are unlikely to pay a registration fee, so for those groups we would like to sponsor them with the money raised from this campaign.

The Impact

Tropical forest restoration is a hot topic just now, especially since the UN global climate change committee recently recognized "enhancement of carbon stocks", i.e. planting trees to suck up carbon dioxide, as qualifying for carbon credits. But to restore enough forest to enable local communities to tap into carbon credits, we need to think beyond hauling basketfuls of saplings and 50-kg-bags of fertilizer 10's of kilometres on foot often across rugged terrain. 

Restored forests also provide a wealth of products and ecological services to local people - everything from mushrooms and medicinal plants to simply being able to take a shower in the dry season. Tropical forest restoration also helps to conserve the millions of plant and animal species that live in such forests. Therefore, it also has a major role to play in reducing species extinctions and maintaining global biodiversity.

Risks & Challenges

Automated forest restoration is an entirely new field and there's no guarantee that enough people will take it seriously. It's been a struggle to get people from such diverse backgrounds as aeronautics, seed technology, computer science and ecology to commit to a 4-day workshop in Thailand. But FORRU-CMU has a long track record of running successful workshops, so we are confident that this one will also be a success. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot afford to sponsor the workshop, but want to attend it, then please email us the "expression of interest" form and we will add you to the mailing list.

We are still looking for workshop participants. All you really need to contribute to the discussion is a passion for tropical forests and a vivid imagination. At this brainstorming stage, we need as many views on the table as possible. But if you have expertise in any of the following fields ... that would be a big plus: - drone technology, GPS/GIS, robotics, computer-aided visual recognition, seed technology, herbicides and forest ecology.

If you're interested but can’t come, we will miss you, but please let your contacts know about the workshop (use the Indiegogo share tools) and keep an eye on our website or Facebook page, for news from the event.

story:
!OYE! Celebrating Visions for the Future:  An Eco Festival of Awareness

WE HAVE CUT OUR BUDGET for Our Free-to-the Public Overnight Festival.  It is still free, but  we have had some in-kind help this past week! !Oye! Celebrating Visions for the Future  will  help  individuals realize that they can be an active part of climate change ...Join in  with your contribution.  Thanks.

SHORT SUMMARY

  It's Us--you and me.

Much  of Downtown  MAIN STREET will be closed  for a continuous thirty hours for environmental revelers to celebrate the Earth .

Saturday, OCTOBER  10th 1 PM – Sunday, OCTOBER  11th 8 PM

FREE ADMISSION, MUSIC, INTERACTIVE ART, GUEST SPEAKERS, WORKSHOPS, SEMINARS, EXHIBITS, PANEL DISCUSSIONS

The festival opens with symbolically blinded revelers striking out at the pinata of optimism spilling its contents of hope upon the streets to dissipate the turning of heads and sighs that arise from disbelief about the realness of climate change, 

THEN THE PARTY REALLY STARTS… with round-the-clock  activity.  Food, drink and utensils are BYO, but a few zero waste food trucks  will participate..

The challenge we face for this festival is to create a ZERO WASTE, minimal carbon footprint life. We want our event to inspire people to care about climate change and to realize the important responsibility each of us has in creating a positive future. When it comes to the Earth, it is always WE. There is you and there is me and he and she, but the Earth only knows us in plural.

story:
What we DO:

The Sacred Valley Honeybee Sanctuary is a Peruvian NGO dedicated to the practice and education of sustainable and holistic beekeeping through beekeeping workshops.

Drawing on more than 30 years of beekeeping experience, we want to make beekeeping a local and sustainable enterprise by utilizing local and low-cost materials in hive construction.

Our apiary is established on an organic farm in the stunning Andes mountains in The Sacred Valley of Peru. We are passionate about demonstrating the importance of practicing natural beekeeping methods as opposed to unsustainable, industrialized methods that contribute to the plight of the honeybee.

The Impact of YOUR Contribution:

Right now we are in the process of transforming our apiary into a Honeybee Sanctuary where visitors can connect with nature and learn about the art of natural beekeeping.

Your contribution will help us to continue and expand our project to reach a wider audience. Your contribution will directly fund:

  • Advertising for beekeeping workshops
  • Beekeeping workshops
  • New beekeeping equipment
  • Website development

The Impact of OUR Project

Honeybees polinate 40% of the food we consume. As industrialized beekeeping interferes with the bees' natural lifestyle patterns, our polinators are disappearing and dying off. We believe that by returning to a more natural style of beekeeping, and encouraging others to do the same, we can begin to reverse the damage done to the species worldwide.

At our Sanctuary, we have already held more than 20 beekeeping workshops, during which participants gain an understanding of the beehive as a superorganism, and practical hands-on experience in building and maintaining a natural top-bar hive.

Through our workshops, participants gain the knowledge and experience necessary to begin their own sustainable beehive at home.

Located on a main tourist route between Cusco and the Inca ruins of Machu Picchu and surrounded by the stunning Andes mountains, we are able to reach an international audience and expand our impact on a global level.

Other Ways You Can Help

Along with your contribution, here are some other ways you can help:

  • Get the word out! Share our Indigogo Campaign with your friends.
  • Visit and "Like" our facebook page.
  • Are you in The Sacred Valley? Contact us for a visit! We are always excited to share our space with anyone interested in learning more!

story:
FREE Online Permaculture Course

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!  The permaculture course is now live @ http://www.permaculturedesigntraining.com

First - please watch the video above - it tells you a LOT about what we're doing in a few short minutes.  We're putting a $2000 course online completely FREE and also making it available on DVD.

Want to support this incredible project?  Pre-order your full course on DVD with a pledge of $175 (regular rate will be $225 - you save $50 by supporting this campaign).

UPDATE:  We have been given access to 1000+ hours of footage about sustainable community  some of which we'd love to edit and include with the course.

For every hour of film we put online, we have to spend about three hours minimum editing.  The more we're able to raise, the more time our editor will be able to spend on this project.  

Help us make that possible by getting us to our stretch-goal!  Be sure to check the "updates" tab above for the latest news about this project - we've already began the editing process!!

We are the Regenerative Leadership Institute, an eight year old leadership, sustainable living and permaculture design school with courses in Oregon, California and Hawaii. We change people's lives by fundamentally reconnecting with nature, remembering our collective heritage and creating a beautiful, thriving future. 

We're seeking to film one of our in-person trainings and develop a free online permaculture design course, teaching principles of sustainable living and permaculture design.
 
Traditionally a permaculture design course costs between $1500 - $5000, involves taking several weeks off work and travel expenses.  We want to change all that by creating a completely free online course.  Make no mistake about it - this is absolutely unprecedented - but we can't do it without you!
 

What Is Permaculture?

Permaculture is the extension of the art of biomimicry - a sustainable living and design science rooted in observation of nature; permaculture is to sustainability what math is to physics.  Nature has long solved many of the environmental and social problems we're facing today, but we just have not been paying much attention.  

While many people think of permaculture as gardening, that’s a lot like thinking of math as being about building bridges. Permaculture is much larger than gardening. Permaculture is a sustainable design science rooted in observation of natural patterns. For example, the same branching pattern of a tree is present in every river, as well as in our own bodies — the pattern maximizes edge, increases diversity, and serves at least a dozen other functions. The very concepts of diversity increasing stability of natural living systems and edge increasing diversity are core permaculture teachings.

By observing the way nature works and then applying the same patterns and principles we learn to design truly sustainable, extremely resilient systems on any level – that can be a garden, a business or a whole city.

How Is Permaculture Changing Our World?

Check out this amazing video about how permaculturist Geoff Lawton turned a property in the desert of Jordan Valley into a food-producing forest in just a couple years.  Seriously, go watch the video - it's incredible.

Here are just some of the many things a permaculture course teaches:

  • Permaculture principles for smart design
  • Pattern observation and site analysis
  • Natural building construction
  • Renewable energy and appropriate technology
  • Rainwater harvesting and conservation
  • Passive and active solar design
  • Graywater considerations and system design
  • Waste recycling and treatment
  • Soil regeneration and land restoration
  • Food forests, trees and garden design
  • Cooperative economics and financial permaculture
  • Scale – designing sustainable, thriving cities
  • and much, much more.


Why We Are Raising Money

We want to make this work as accessible as possible while costs of filming, editing, web site development and promotion all add up.  For every hour of footage we film, we need to have a professional editor spend several hours editing and converting.  Then we also need to integrate a website platform to make the content truly coherent and allow us to create a very high quality online educational experience.

We estimate the costs of filming, editing, website programming and online promotion to be roughly $10,000.  We are hoping to greatly exceed that minimum with this campaign and the additional funds over that amount will enable us to not only develop the online course but also produce several interviews with our instructors plus additional e-books and a much more extensive online promotion. 

The world needs this knowledge made as accessible as possible.  Help us meet that need by supporting this game-changing campaign.

What You Get For Your Support

You are helping to make history.  Never before has a full permaculture design course been made available online completely free.  We're committed to making this knowledge available to absolutely everyone.

Check out the awesome perks we've listed on the right.  They include gift certificates to our trainings, delivery of physical course DVDs (we're talking about roughly seventy hours of film!), as well as access to our full in-person trainings.  

Even better, through our non-profit partner, we're going to plant at least one tree for every sponsor we get and quite literally make the earth a little bit greener.

Let's Change the World - PLEDGE Today and SHARE This INCREDIBLE Project on FaceBook and E-Mail!
