story:
Bristol Bay hosts the largest wild salmon run left on earth. It is threatened by the construction of what would be the largest open pit gold mine in the world. My son, Aube, and I decided to ride across America to draw attention to the struggle to keep the mine from being built.

My husband, Dan, and I are long-time Alaskans.  Our son, Aube, was born in Palmer.  Our family has fished for salmon for many years.  For 10 years we setnetted on the Egegik River in Bristol Bay.  Today three of our four sons fish the Bay commercially.  In the picture displayed on this site, our son, Luke, took the picture of his boat, the Mistral, and his wife, Adrianne, is on the bow of the center boat.  Our other son, Dunedin, holds the banner aboard the Mistral.

The region has been home to Native people for 10,000 years, and they are largely united in the fight to protect their homeland and keep foreign companies from developing this mine.  The stakes are huge – the largest open pit gold/copper/molybdenum mine in the world – and the potential destruction of a thriving ecosystem that has nurtured a culture for thousands of years.  The fishing industry provides not only nutrition for thousands, but jobs in Alaska, the Pacific Northwest, throughout the United States and beyond.  This is a huge and renewable resource that is managed responsibly, and is nothing less than a national treasure.

The Pebble Mine proponents say that they can protect the environment, but in the history of mountaintop mining, this has never been accomplished.  If you research the legacy of mines of this type, they leave a tale of destruction and contamination in their wake. 

The salmon fishery of Bristol Bay, along with other fisheries in the adjacent Bering Sea, comprises one of the richest resources in the world.  Together they provide over half of the seafood harvested in the States.  This is too valuable a resource to endanger by the construction of what could be an environmental disaster. Ten billion tons of toxic waste will be generated by this mine, and they hope to hold back this contamination by building a dam two miles wide.  This is an area renowned for its earthquakes and seismic activity.  They claim the dam will last for perpetuity, and will forever hold back the toxic waste from sensitive streams where the salmon spawn each year.

Many organizations, both national and Alaska-based, have joined forces to stop the mine and protect Bristol Bay.  The Pebble Partnership, the front organization behind Anglo America, headquartered in England, and their partner Northern Dynasty, operating out of Canada, have huge financial resources to push for construction of the mine.  We need grassroots funding to counter their propaganda, and so we are riding from coast to coast to highlight the battle taking place in southwest Alaska.

All monies received will go to the Renewable Resources Coalition, an Anchorage-based organization at the forefront of the fight.

My husband, Dan, co-founded a movement called Musicians United to Protect Bristol Bay (www.musiciansunited.info).  This has the same goal… to stop the mine… and is bringing the power and spirit of music to the fight.  The mining corporations have told us we cannot win, that they will, if nothing else, outlast us.  We don’t believe they have come up against the strength and dedication that Alaskan fishermen can bring to the battle, nor the same strength and dedication that environmentally conscious people across America can add.

As we ride, we will try to educate people to the issue, using radio and media to get the word out and explain the issues.  Please help!  It would be a travesty to allow the destruction of a productive healthy ecosystem that has existed for millennium, for short term profits going to foreign corporations.

We have set a goal of $10,000, and a time line of 100 days.  All of this money will go into fighting the Pebble Partnership.  Advertisements cost money.  Booths at fairs and conferences, staffed by educated caring individuals, require funds.  We don’t have the deep pockets that Anglo America or Northern Dynasty does, but with your help, we can use what money we do raise to lobby wisely and counter the lies and mistruths spread by the mine proponents.   Thank you so much for your interest and passion.

story:
The Tobago Cays Marine Park is one of the jewels of the Caribbean. Five palm tree islands are surrounded by turquoise waters and spectacular coral reefs.

The marine park is a sanctuary for tropical fish.

Guess where the greatest abundance of parrotfish in the Grenadines is found. That's right - Tobago Cays Marine Park! Parrotfish play a crucial role in keeping coral reefs healthy.

The Tobago Cays Marine Park is also very important for endangered green and hawksbill sea turtles, which feed in the coral reefs and seagrass beds and nest on the white sand beaches.

We are proud to share our natural paradise with thousands of visitors each year, who fly or sail here from all corners of the globe. The beach at Petite Bateau is one of the main attractions, and you can see why!

The park is not only important for marine life, but also for local communities. Over 200 people make their living as beach BBQ chefs, water taxi operators, tour guides and vendors.

 

The need for a ranger base and washroom

Sadly, our marine life is under threat. Illegal fishing and poaching of sea turtles is taking place, especially at night when the rangers are off duty. There is an urgent need for a base so that rangers can maintain 24-hour security.

There is also a need for an environmentally friendly washroom facility. The current latrine cannot meet the needs of the thousands of visitors and its waste eventually reaches the sea, threatening water quality and marine life. It is also far off in the bushes and a safety concern.

The solution

A facility containing eco-friendly composting toilets will provide a clean, sanitary experience for 100% of park users while causing zero discharge to the environment.

The building will contain living quarters for rangers and an information desk where visitors can obtain information and assistance.

The facility will enable rangers to maintain a 24-hour presence in the park for the first time, enabling night time patrols to reduce illegal poaching and fishing.

 

As a result of your support…

  • Everyone in the park – visitors, vendors, rangers – will benefit from a pleasant, safe, sanitary and environmentally friendly washroom.
  • The water of the Tobago Cays Marine Park will stay crystal clear.

  • Turtles, fish and other marine life will be safer from poaching.

  • Visitor safety will be improved through 24-hour park security.

 

Earn amazing perks

To show our appreciation, we are giving our donors some lovely perks. For donations of different sizes, we will...

Write your name in the sand at Petite Bateau and place a photo in our "Hall of Sponsors" in the finished facility!

Send you an official Tobago Cays Marine Park shirt!

Take you on an exclusive behind the scenes tour with the park rangers!

Paint your company name on the facility for tens of thousands to see!

For each level of perk, you also receive all the perks for smaller donations. So if you give $90, for example, you recieve the $90 perk and the $50 perk. Extra perkiness!

Who we are

The Tobago Cays Marine Park is managed by the Government of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines through a team of 19 park rangers and office staff based on Union Island. Sustainable Grenadines Inc. (SusGren) is a local non-profit organization that is empowering communities in the Grenadines to protect the environment. We are working together to construct this facility.


What we need

The total cost of our project is $76,500. We have already secured $61,000 from several funding agencies. We need $15,500 to complete the project. We are excited to have almost reached our goal and we are calling on local companies and park visitors to help us reach the finish line!

TABLE 1 – Funding needed.

Amount (USD)

Budget items

$40,000

To create architectural drawings and construct the washroom and ranger station building, including wheelchair access and rainwater collection, on the remote island of Petite Bateau.

$32,000

To purchase, ship and install two state-of-the-art composting toilet units, including solar power for the fan and pump. To train park rangers to maintain the facility.

$3,000

To purchase items for maintenance, and create art works to educate and inspire visitors to protect the marine environment.

$1,500

Fundraising costs: Indiegogo fee ($750), video production ($250) and printing fundraising materials ($500).

$76,500

TOTAL NEEDED

 

TABLE 2 – Funding sources.

Amount (USD)

Source of funds

$24,000

United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

$22,000

German Federal Ministry of the Environment

$10,000

Philip Stephenson Foundation

$5,000

Tobago Cays Marine Park

$15,500

 REMAINING TO BE RAISED - THIS CAMPAIGN

 

What if we don’t reach our target? We will keep going and going again until we do!

What if we beat our target? We will add extra features – screened changing rooms from bamboo fencing, information signs, artworks to inspire visitors to love the ocean. We will listen to you, our backers, on which features to include.

Show us your love

Please show your love and support by helping us to keep the Tobago Cays Marine Park pristine and safe now and for future generations.

 

Thank you!

campaign_city: Clifton, Union Island, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines

story:
Who We Are

We are five students from the University of Tennessee who have partnered with Dogwood Arts, a local nonprofit organization, to focus on the beautification of a historic Knoxville community: Island Home. to help raise donations for Island Home because we wanted to help enhance South Knoxville's beauty. Dogwood Arts was established in 1955 to shed light on Knoxville's natural beauty and to continue beautifying it . They are known for their annual Dogwood Arts Festival in the spring as well as many tree-planting events in the community. Our partnership focuses on updates to the Island Home dogwood trail, which includes new trees and updating signage.

What We Need and What You Get

Dogwood Arts is in need of donations to continue planting trees on the Island Home trail, one of the 12 sponsored trails throughout the city. We are accepting donations that will help Dogwood Arts continue offering their service to the community throughout the year.  By donating, you will help alleviate some financial barriers and help the organization branch out and do more to enhance the arts and beauty in the South Knoxville community.

By donating to Home Sweet Island Home,  you are personally pouring into the South Knoxville community and ensuring that its natural beauty doesn't go unnoticed. Perks for donating will include a Dogwood Arts Festival t-shirt with a donation of $30, $25 donation for Facebook and other social media shout-outs, a  Dogwood Arts cup with a $15 donation or a thank you video with a donation of $10.

 

How It Helps

Donating to Dogwood Arts allows you to be a part of the success its impact brings to the South Knoxville community. The organization plants dogwood trees and hosts events to help raise awareness in our community. Dogwood Arts boasts a year long celebration of thousands of artists who promote the region’s arts, culture, and natural beauty. Dogwood Arts helps Knoxville by pursuing local talents and beauty. You can help South Knoxville grow by first starting with the beauty around it.

  

 (Entrance to Island Home trail/neighborhood)

 (A couple enjoying the trail in the spring time)

 

How Else To Help

If you would like to help Dogwood Arts but are unable to make a monetary donation, there are other ways you can help. One is to submit an application if you are an artist, performer, or a vendor to help out with events. You can also donate by going to their website or joining their volunteer team.  Share the link to donate to this project on Facebook and other social media outlets, and be sure to tell your friends and family about us.

story:
Britain's Bio Reef Project

Hello, I'm Britain. I'm 13 years old and I live in Indonesia.

  • I'm fundraising to bring awareness and to do something about the dying coral reefs of Gili Air, a small island here. I will do this by analyzing and documenting bio reefs (artificial reef made of pipes with electric currents) and will install a small bio reef in the area.
  • Dying reefs are a major concern because "More than half of the Indonesian people depend on a healthy reef for food and income but only 6% of the reefs are thriving today." -Delphine Robbe, Gili Eco Trust
  • I am fortunate to have three experienced mentors who have already built and done research on bio reefs including Delphine Robbe, Manager of Gili Eco Trust,  and bio reef expert, Glen Chickering who is my Global Awareness teacher and has a lot of contacts to help me execute the project, and Noan Feshnock who is my science teacher and who has studied Marine Biology.
  • With your help we will help make the ocean a more healthy place for fish and all of us who benefit from it.

What I Need & What You Get

  • I'm seeking to raise $500 to cover the boat transportation to Gili Air, expenses of a diving license, documentation, and the bio reef supplies and equipment.
  • You will get the complete joy and satisfaction that you helped make thousands of fish happier and made the eco system better for everyone.

The Impact

  • Bio Reefs quicken the growth rate of coral through electrodes. It is like medicine in that it actually helps the ocean and the reef slowly, around five years. The ocean rejuvenates and because more beautiful as it starts to grow again and thrive. 
  • Eighty percent of all divers in Indonesia get certified in Gili Air so as the reefs become healthier again the appreciation of the colorful ocean life spreads. 
  • Eventually the coral will get so big that it will support many fish and will be unattached to the pipes and the coral will continue to grow on its own.
  • Remember that if reefs die then fish die and then there are consequences for not only Indonesia but for everyone. 
  • We can all do something to help the ocean thrive, thank you for supporting my efforts.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please share this video with others via social media
  • Send me all of the good luck vibes you can!
  • Keep our oceans clean by removing trash and be a good citizen
  • Don't hurt coral reefs while snorkeling or diving (don't step on them or remove)
story_txt:
Britain's Bio Reef ProjectHello, I'm Britain. I'm 13 years old and I live in Indonesia.

I'm fundraising to bring awareness and to do something about the dying coral reefs of Gili Air, a small island here. I will do this by analyzing and documenting bio reefs (artificial reef made of pipes with electric currents) and will install a small bio reef in the area.


Dying reefs are a major concern because "More than half of the Indonesian people depend on a healthy reef for food and income but only 6% of the reefs are thriving today." -Delphine Robbe, Gili Eco Trust


I am fortunate to have three experienced mentors who have already built and done research on bio reefs including Delphine Robbe, Manager of Gili Eco Trust,  and bio reef expert, Glen Chickering who is my Global Awareness teacher and has a lot of contacts to help me execute the project, and Noan Feshnock who is my science teacher and who has studied Marine Biology.


With your help we will help make the ocean a more healthy place for fish and all of us who benefit from it.

What I Need & What You Get

I'm seeking to raise $500 to cover the boat transportation to Gili Air, expenses of a diving license, documentation, and the bio reef supplies and equipment.


You will get the complete joy and satisfaction that you helped make thousands of fish happier and made the eco system better for everyone.

The Impact

Bio Reefs quicken the growth rate of coral through electrodes. It is like medicine in that it actually helps the ocean and the reef slowly, around five years. The ocean rejuvenates and because more beautiful as it starts to grow again and thrive. 


Eighty percent of all divers in Indonesia get certified in Gili Air so as the reefs become healthier again the appreciation of the colorful ocean life spreads. 


Eventually the coral will get so big that it will support many fish and will be unattached to the pipes and the coral will continue to grow on its own.


Remember that if reefs die then fish die and then there are consequences for not only Indonesia but for everyone. 


We can all do something to help the ocean thrive, thank you for supporting my efforts.

Other Ways You Can Help
Please share this video with others via social media
Send me all of the good luck vibes you can!
Keep our oceans clean by removing trash and be a good citizen
Don't hurt coral reefs while snorkeling or diving (don't step on them or remove)

story:
Help support Antarctic science and exploration

We are a public funded expedition and in need your help to support Antarctic science. 

2013-2014 marks the centenary of the Australasian Antarctic Expedition led by the great scientist and explorer Sir Douglas Mawson. The amazing tales of adventure, science and tragedy associated with Mawson’s endeavor rank alongside those of Scott, Shackleton and Amundsen and yet this was the most ambitious of them all: three bases, thirty-one land based members, seven major sledging journeys and a full oceanographic program across the Southern Ocean and Antarctica. Mawson’s expedition of 1911-1914 gave the world its first complete scientific snapshot  of a new continent. His team explored a vast stretch of eastern Antarctica; discovered new bays, mountains and glaciers; and linked up areas that were previously thought to be in isolation. The resulting 89 scientific reports described Antarctica’s violent and extreme weather, its flourishing plant and animal life, the ocean’s fickleness. 

In a celebration of this remarkable endeavour, the new Australasian Antarctic Expedition (or AAE for short) is following the route of its namesake. The three years’s worth of observations gleaned by Mawson and his men provide a unique dataset against which we can compare changes seen today. Drawing on the original datasets of the AAE, we are looking to meld science and adventure, to discover and communicate the changes that have taken place in this remote environment over the last hundred years. Led by Professor Chris Turney and Dr Chris Fogwill, from the University of New South Wales, Sydney, the 2013-2014 expedition is now working its way across the Southern Ocean. By mid-December, we will be attempting to cross the 60 kilometres of sea ice in Commonwealth Bay to reach Mawson’s Antarctic base at Cape Denison, the windiest place on Earth in the ‘Home of the Blizzard’.

We are going south to:

  1. gain new insights into the circulation of the Southern Ocean and its impact on the global carbon cycle;
  2. explore changes in ocean circulation caused by the growth of extensive fast ice and its impact on life in Commonwealth Bay;
  3. use the subantarctic islands as thermometers of climatic change by using peats, lakes, trees and remains of the last ice age to explore the past;
  4. investigate the impact of changing climate on the ecology of the subantarctic islands;
  5. discover the environmental influence on seabird populations across the Southern Ocean and in Commonwealth Bay;
  6. understand changes in seal populations and their feeding patterns in the Southern Ocean and Commonwealth Bay;
  7. produce the first underwater surveys of life in the subantarctic islands and Commonwealth Bay;
  8. determine the extent to which humans have had an impact on this remote region of Antarctica; and
  9. provide baseline data to improve the next generation of climate models and predictions for the future.

We are using the approach pioneered by the great explorers of a century ago to support Antarctic science. Just as Mawson appealed to the public for funds to help support the analysis and publication of his results, we need your assistance.  The aim of this Indiegogo campaign is to raise enough money to fund the scientific analysis of our samples and data so we can report what is happening in the south today!

What We Need & What You Get

Although we can cover the costs of supporting the expedition in the field, we are generating far more samples and data on the first leg of the voyage than we originally anticipated and need funds to support their full analysis. To keep the results of the expedition as relevant as possible, we want to get the majority of our key findings out into the public domain within 12 months of returning home on the 4 January 2014. In the first two days alone, we have already collected far more tree and peat sequences than we dared hope for, offering detailed insights into past environmental changes, potentially spanning thousands of years...and the full oceanographic and biological program has barely started! Our new samples require detailed analysis, dating and analysis on our return. We urgently need support for laboratory work and publication of the results in open access journals so everyone can have access to our findings. Our costings suggest we will need an extra $49,000 to make this happen. We really hope that you can help us reach our target, but if we undershoot at least we will be able to get more analyses undertaken than currently possible. 

The concept of crowd funding with Indiegogo harks back to Mawson‘s original Antarctic expedition one hundred years ago, where many expedition items — including huskies, tents and sleeping bags — were funded by public donations from across the world! To attract potential supporters we are able to offer a number of unique gifts and perks, ranging from limited edition t-shirts, exclusive photographic prints and signed books.

The Impact

The Australasian Antarctic Expedition 2013-2014 is all about adventure, exploration, scientific discovery, and communication. We are exploring one of the most remote regions on our planet. In spite of over a century of discovery – including aerial and satellite surveys – remarkably little has been explored. Crucially this pristine southern polar region is uniquely placed to monitor the health of our planet. The AAE has a team of scientists who are world experts in the natural and physical sciences while also being passionate about science communication. To help with this, the AAE is using the latest satellite technology to support a full range of social media, including Google+ Hangouts on Air, Twitter and YouTube, to report our first findings directly to you live from Antarctica and the Southern Ocean. We want our findings to reach the public and policy makers as soon as possible. 

By supporting our campaign you will be helping us support scientific observation in Antarctica’s Commonwealth Bay, the Southern Ocean and subantarctic islands to provide the first complete snapshot of this region for a century.

Other Ways You Can Help

Whilst not everyone can contribute directly to this campaign, we would love you to join us on the AAE. For more information of how to join the expedition virtually please go to www.spiritofmawson.com and watch out for the Hangouts on Air we are hosting during our voyage.  Please spread the word with your friends, either through our web page, or with the Indiegogo share tools!!!

Hi there!

I'm biking from Sweden to India. It's a magnificent trip.
Why by bike? Because it's environmentally friendly and the ultimate way of freedom.

The purpose of getting to India is for me to take a teacher training course in Yoga. Because I want to spread and raise awareness, I want to make people happy, I want to make people understand that world peace is possible if we all live in harmony and yoga is the perfect path.
If I can teach a hundred people and get them inspired, maybe at least one of them would also want to teach and probably lots of them will get other people interested in yoga and thereby we can spread the knowledge and the awareness together!

Unfortunately for me I just got stuck in Dubai, waiting for my Indian visa. The visa has no time frame and I really don't know how long I will have to stay here. But Dubai is an expensive city and I might not be able to pay for the course in India without some financial contributions. 
Every little donation means the world to me, if you're able to help I'd appreciate it so, so much!

Be well,
/Julia.

story:
Ain Bicycles exists to promote cycling in Cairo, to build bicycles, to support cyclists and shift the culture from four wheels to two.

We’ve been working for two years and we’ve built a lot of bikes already. But now we need your help to open up a community centre.  

We want to open a space where cyclists in Cairo can learn how to maintain their bikes, teach what they know about cycling. We want a space where you can learn how to maintain and repair your own bike with the right tools. We want a space where we can build tactics together about how to get more bikes on the streets of this city. 

Now, more than ever, the world needs clean, sustainable transport systems. And Cairo is no exception. 

Why cycle?

There are plenty reasons:

Clean the air. An increase in cycling will dramatically improve our environment.

Beat the zahma. Cairo is gridlock but a bike sails through the traffic.

Save money. Fuel prices are rising every day, save your money for things you actually want.

Secret exercise. Work your body on the pedals without having to go to the gym.

Live the city. Get out of the car’s metal box of emotion and experience the street.

Take control. Riding a bike is liberation. Imagine arriving everywhere with a smile on your face? 

Isn't cycling in Cairo impossible?

No. Cairo is basically a flat city.

The traffic is actually easy to navigate. The average speed during rush hour is around 16km an hour. So with a little sign language and the right attitude you’ll be dashing through those stagnant cars in no time.

Add to that the fact that the inner-city neighborhoods are relatively compact, and you'll start to see why a bicycle might be the answer to our collective traffic traumas.

There’s a reason the bread, gas and milk guys have always used bikes.


So who are we?

Ain Bicycles consists of Dirk Wanrooij and Karim Abbany. Two years ago we teamed up. We shared a love of bikes but could see there was a shortage in Cairo. The ones on offer were all either too flimsy or too flashy. So we built one. And it started. And after a while we decided to take it seriously.

With your support we can:

Rent a new place big enough to serve as a community centre.

Organise a series of work-shops on bike maintenance and basic repairs

Organise events to get people secure on their bikes.

Buy proper tools to teach people with.

Buy the parts that will withstand some of our tougher streets.

Begin our grass-roots campaign to promote the mighty bicycle.

Beyond that - just ride a bike! We can only reach critical mass together. 

Join us #BeatTheZa7ma and let's make Cairo a Cycling City!

ايه هى عين بايسكلز؟

عين بايسكلز شركة بتشجع الناس تستعمل العجلة بدل العربيات.

احنا عايزين ايه؟

عايزين نعمل مكان كل الناس اللى بتحب العجل تقدر تتقابل فيه، تسأل اى حاجة ليها علاقة بالعجل، تتعلم اى حاجة ليها علاقة بالعجل، او تعلم اى حاجة ليها علاقة بالعجل ، المكان الى احنا شايفينه فى دماغنا هو مكان هيكون فيه عدة، ستاند للعجل، ومكان كفاية للناس تيجى تشتغل على العجل بتاعها بايديها فى اى وقت.

المكان هيكون كمان علشان الناس تتقابل فيه وتفكر مع بعض ازاى يقدروا يحسنوا بيئة ركوب العجل فى مصر ، ازاى يقدروا يغيروا الصورة السلبية لاى حد راكب عجلة، وازاى نقدر نخلى العجل وسيلة نقل مقبولة لكل الناس" من غير ما يفرق معانا سنهم ، مستواهم الاجتماعى او هما ولاد ولا بنات.

مكان زى ده مش ممكن يتحقق غير بدعمكم، بما ان احنا حاليا موجودين فى اوضة فى شقة ودعمكم المادى هو الطريقة الوحيدة  اننا نقدر نغير الوضع ده، ونقدر نخلى تركيزنا ، مجهودنا  ووقتنا اكثر فى الخطوات الى احنا محتاجينها علشان نحقق الهدف بتاعنا.

احنا ليه عايزين نشجع استخدام العجل؟

لاسباب كتيرة اوى:

- كلنا مزنوقين فى زحمة العربيات، ومش فاهمين سبب الزحمة، والمشوار الى ممكن ياخد نص ساعة، فى الاخر بياخد اكثر من ساعة، وفى معظم الاحيان لو عندك ميعاد، يأما بيتأجل، او بيتلغى اساسا.

- العربيات مش بس بضيع وقت، و كمان بتاثر بطريقة جامدة على حالتنا المزاجية، تخيل شكل، احساس، وحالة الهوا فى شارع معظم اللى ماش فيه ناس راكبة عجل.

- والواحد محبوس جوة العربية، ولا بيبقى فيه فرصة انه يتفرج على الشوارع ولا المناظر الى حواليه، بالعكس، بيبقى قاعد متعصب من كل حاجة، حتى الناس اللى حواليه، والواحد راكب عجلة" طريقة التعامل والعلاقة مع كل حاجة حواليك بتختلف تماما.

- الركنة برضه من مشاكل ركوب العربيات، مش بس صعب انك تلاقى راكنة، انما فى ناس بتروح راكنة صف تانى، وده بيزود من مشكلة الزحمة، ودى حاجة مش ممكن تبقى مشكلة بالنسبة لك وانت راكب عجلة.

- ركوب العجل ما بيحتجش حرق بنزين، وده بيخليك فرد مش بتصرف فلوسك على البنزين، و كمان بتقلل من التلوث فى الجو

- ركوب العجل بيخليك تحس انك حر، عايز تعمل اى حاجة فى اى وقت ممكن تعملها، وانت مش قلقان من زحمة وغالبا بتوصل المكان اللى انت رايحه وانت مبتسم

مش ركوب العجل فى القاهرة مستحيل؟

- القاهرة مدينة ارض مسطحة بطبيعتها، باستثناء (هضبة المقطم) مطلع زينهم، مناطق فى مدينة نصر ، وضواحى القاهرة، غير كدة مفيش فى الشوارع اى منحدرات تقريبا.

- خلال وقت الذروة، معدل السرعة بتاع العربيات بيكون من ٦ لـ٢٥ كم/ساعة (البنك الدولى ٢٠١٤)

- معظم الزحمة فى شوارع العاصمة سببها العربيات الملاكى، اللى بتمثل  تلتين (٢/٣) الزحمة فى الشوارع، ومعظم الاوقات كل عربية بتكون بتنقل شخص واحد، يعنى باختصار تلتين الزحمة بينقل ٪١٤ من اجمالى الناس فى الشارع (ديفيد سبتمبر ٢٠١١)

حالة الفوضى فى شوارع العاصمة ممكن تكون مخيفة وعدائية لينا كلنا بس بالطريقة الصح للتعامل معاها، هتلاقى الشوارع سهل انك تتعامل معاها.

علاوة على كدة القاهرة عبارة عن احياء جنب بعض ومعظم شوارعها الداخلية والجانبية بتوصل لبعض" وده سبب كافى ان المنطق يخليك تتأكد ان العجلة هى الحل الوحيد لمشاكل المرور الى بتقابلنا كلها

معدل سرعتك وانت راكب عجلة بيكون من ١٠ - ٢٠ كم/ساعة.

كلنا شفنا بتاع العيش، بتاع انابيب البوتاجاز، بتاع اللبن، وساعات حتى دليفرى الانتقال راكب عجلة، وده معناه ان فى ناس كتيرة بتعتمد على العجل كوسيلة مواصلاتها الاولية، وده دليل ان ثقافة العجل موجودة اصلا فى مصر.

العجلة فى مصر دايما بيتبصلها انها وسيلة مواصلات الراجل العادى وبكل المشاكل الى طرحناها فى النقط اللى فاتت، لازم نبتدى نبص للعجل بنظرة مختلفة ونبتدى نحسن من قيمة العجل فى مصر.

مين عين بايسكلز؟

عين بايسكلز كونها درك وانروى وكريم عبدالله اتقابلنا من سنتين، وكنا احنا الاتنين مش راضيين عن الجل اللى فى السوق المصرى لانه كان مش مناسب علشان نستعمله كوسيلة مواصلات. دايما ياما العجل جودته مش عالية، او مليان حاجات الواحد مش محتاجها وعمره ما هيستعملها.

عرضنا على واحد صاحبنا نعمله عجلة، ودى كانت البداية. صاحب جاب صاحب ، صاحب جاب صاحب ... وبعد فترة قررنا ناخد الموضوع جد.

دلوقتى، بنعمل ونبيع عجل، مصمم علشان يستحمل شوارع القاهرة ويفوت فى زحمتها بسهولة.

بس هدفنا اكبر من كدة ، اكبر من اننا نكون محل عجل.

ازاى ممكن تكون جزء من هدفنا؟

ساند حملتنا علشان ننشىء اول مركز اجتماعى للناس اللى بتركب عجل، وبدعمكم المادى:-

- هنأجر مكان مناسب علشان نعمل المركز الاجتماعى 

- هنستثمر فى عدة مخصوصة للعجل هتبقى متاحة للناس الى عندها عجل ، والناس اللى مهتمة بالجل، فى ورشتنا.

- هننظم حملات لتشجيع واستخدام العجل

- هنجيب قطع غيار مناسبة لشوارع القاهرة

- هنعمل ورش عمل للصيانة الكاملة، والمهارات الاساسية اللى هتسمح للناس تعتمد على العجل بتاعها وتكون واثقة فيه كوسيلة مواصلات.

ازاى ممكن تساعدنا

- اركب عجلة، مش مهم انت فين، استثمر جزء من فلوسك فى عجلة وابتدى اتحرك بيها.

الطريقة الوحيدة اللى ممكن تخلينا نعمل فرق هو ان يكون فى ناس كفاية وتبتدى تستعمل العجل بتاعها كطريقة مواصلاتهم اليومية.

- شارك حكايتنا وانشرها على قد ما تقدر وشجع الناس تركب عجل.


انضم لنا على BeatTheZa7ma# ويلا نحاول نخلى القاهرة مدينة لركوب العجل

story:
Short Summary

Hello, my name is Colby and I'm from Salt Lake City, Utah. I started the GiveSTONG Foundation 5 years ago with the goal to provide a Thanksgiving or Christmas meal to families in need. We deliver the baskets all across the Wasatch Front covering 50 to 60 miles. I started with two families, and I have doubled the number of families I help each year; which brings the family total for this year to 64. 

I started this charity because giving back and family are important to me. It is my mission to provide a meal to underprivileged families, so they can focus on family and enjoy this time of the year. Up to this point I have self funded these meals along with close friends and family; with your help, we can reach the goal for this year, and bring the holiday spirit to 64 families.

What We Need 

I am asking for $4,000 to feed 64 families. This is the breakdown for each family meal:

Turkey            
Stuffing
Pie
Rolls
Bag of Potatoes
Chocolate Orange Sticks
Bag of Green Beans
Bag of Corn
Sweet Potato Casserole
Sparkling Cider
Whipped Cream
Cranberry Sauce
Turkey Pan and Bag
Olives
Butter
Hot Chocolate
Gravy
Jello

If I don't reach the goal I will still put all of the money towards the dinners and feed as many families as I can.

Impact
In the previous years, when the families open the door and see the dinners their eyes light up with joy. The kids help me unpack with smiles on their faces, and the holiday spirit fills the room. The families always express how grateful and humbled they are by this act of service. Many times, this is what makes their Thanksgiving or Christmas dinner possible. I have learned that helping other families through the holidays, and seeing their smiles, is the best gift I can give. This year you can be part of it, and feel the joy that helping others brings to your life.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are not in a position to donate, I appreciate you looking at my organization. I challenge you to do the same in your community or help me raise awareness about the GiveSTRONG Foundation. 

Thank you,

Colby Horn
Director
GiveSTRONG Foundation

story:
This campaign has finished and more information can be found at our WEBSITE

ON AVERAGE, GREEN RAIN USERS HAVE USED 35% LESS WATER TO WATER THEIR LAWN!

Green Rain takes sprinkler systems out of the 20th Century and utilizes modern technology. The system pulls historical, current and future weather data to determine when to run your sprinklers and for how long.  Current systems don’t take into account rainfall or predict whether it is going to rain shortly after they run.  The complex algorithm built into Green Rain ensures that you are saving the maximum amount of water you can while still being able to brag to your neighbors about having the lushest lawn on the block.


Interest Piqued. Why do I need a sprinkler system smarter than me?

Green Rain will save you time, money, and help the planet, too! I have 5 live prototypes and the data from them shows an average of 35% savings off of their water bills!  Did you know each sprinkler zone can use up to 15 gallons per minute?  The amount of water and money saved is going to be dependent on the number of zones you have and the climate you live in.  The more zones, the more you save!  Also, you will be thrilled when it rains.  


Sounds cool. Who thought this up?

I grew up with a number of physical disabilities and people telling me I could not do things.  Being 26 years old and already sporting a fake hip and a spine held up by titanium, a lot of people would probably side with the nay-sayers.  I’ve earned a Bachelor’s in Computer Science and Engineering from the University of Notre Dame, been a web and systems developer, and now in my career have moved into a position where I am in front of the client and working with more real-world application of products.  

But technology isn’t just my job. My entire house is automated by a system I built and is controlled based on where my phone is.  If my phone gets close to the door, it unlocks.  If I walk into the bedroom, the lights turn on.  My coffee maker turns on when my alarm goes off.  No user interaction is the name of the game.  It made so much sense that our sprinkler systems should do the same.  Smart systems are way cooler than smart people!


How well has this been working?

There are 5 live prototypes who have been gathering data and working really well.  I have worked through a number of issues with keeping WiFi connected and sorted out some issues with the Weather API.

Click here to view a graph of prototype data!

You will notice in the above link that the amount of rain drastically decreases the amount of water used by the sprinklers.  If this person put their sprinklers on a typical schedule, they would run it for 1.5 inches per week.  BUT, with Green Rain installed, you will notice it only ran a full cycle ONCE in the last 3 months!


You got me!  Full details, please!

Green Rain has a number of features that make it invaluable to your lawn:

  • It's built to last.  A Raspberry Pi is the system driving the brains of the system. The IO ports are converted to 24V so they can properly start and stop the sprinkler heads.  The system can be on at all times with very little energy consumption. This system is capped off by a simple Wifi dongle built in. There is also an SD Card holding the brains which makes it very easy for me to  duplicate. All of this is wrapped in an enclosure which can be mounted near your sprinkler controller.


  • It’s smart.  It uses historical weather data, present weather conditions, and future forecasts to read the condition of the lawn and what weather is coming. If the lawn is saturated, or if rain is coming, Green Rain holds off watering. Likewise, if the lawn is thirsty, it turns on to keep the lawn perfectly hydrated.
  • It adapts. It pulls the weather results from yesterday and the prediction for the current day.  In time, it will start to learn which predictions are most accurate.  An 80% chance of rain may mean something completely different in Seattle than it does in Las Vegas. 

  • It communicates. You will get emails notifying you of the lawn’s status and why the sprinklers did or did not run.  

    The Algorithm embedded in Green Rain has been filed for a US Patent


Beautiful. How hard is the set up?

You will need the following to hook it up

  • An existing, installed in-ground sprinkler system
  • WiFi, but if you don’t have it, it does support a wired Ethernet connection to your router
  • A zip code

But from there, setup is super simple

  • Connect Green Rain to your zones and power on the system
  • Search for networks on your tablet or laptop and find the access point “Green Rain”
  • Connect to that access point and navigate your browser to connect to the system
    Green Rain will then guide you through the existing zone schedule and connecting to your home Wifi.
  • YOU WILL NEVER NEED TO TOUCH IT AGAIN!


So what’s the plan? What will you do with my money?

I need a little help to move this from a prototype to a final product.  I have all of the coding done and an awesome prototype but it will be hard to distribute 500 units if I am sitting in my spare bedroom building each unit by hand.  This thing looks exactly like you would expect it to having been produced in my home office.  I want to turn this into a smooth-looking injection molded unit that you would be proud to mount on your wall.  The brains of the system are there - the design around it is not.  Unfortunately, that is the expensive part.


Where I want to take this

I would love to see Green Rain in thousands of households.  At that point, we will see a significant water consumption impact made. A couple of ideas...

  • An online login where you can easily view the amount of water and money you are saving.  Share this with your friends and compare to other homes in your region and outside your region.
  • A manufactured board that has the Raspberry Pi, Wifi and Sprinkler board built into one unit.

Enough questions. My promise to you

If setbacks arise, I will work through them. I really believe in this idea and am willing to work tirelessly or recruit whoever I need to jump any hurdles.

The main challenge here will be manufacturing and quality control. Currently, I pay a great amount of attention to make sure each prototype I create is working perfectly. I run a gambit of unit tests and do physical tests where I connect it to test sprinkler heads.

I currently build each one and just mirror the SD card to bring them all to the same state. I am not afraid of producing this on a large scale and think it will be a lot of fun!


Please share my project if you made it this far!  If you don't want to contribute, please let me know why!

To show you my appreciation

$20 - Umbrella to protect you from rogue sprinklers


$30 - Awesome T-Shirt to help spread the word


$225 - Green Rain Sprinkler Controller for up to 8 zones

$250 - Green Rain Controller for up to 16 zones


$500 - Green Rain Controller capable of 48 zones

story:
Friar West and Edward Campbell are travelling in a van with a large canoe and two outriggers on top, plus survival equipment overland from Devon in South West England to Greece. They hope to go to Athens and mend another broken canoe which Friar made some years ago to use as back up in an earlier attempt to do this. It is an attempt by Friar to repeat, in part or whole, a 1986 long and dangerous journey with a home made open “Indian type” wooden Canadian canoe. It is not a kayak .

The reason for doing this is to promote and advertise ICAN by inviting the media to publicise the venture. Please see the accompanying video giving examples of activities held over a 28 year period. ICAN is The International Conservation Action Network. (Formerly Awareness Network) ICAN is a voluntary none-profit social enterprise categorised as an unincorporated association.

The aim of ICAN is to open a permanent visitor centre inviting the public to contribute to or benefit from conservation related activities. Or hold activities which although may not be directly related to conservation, will benefit it somehow, like music or martial arts fund-raising events.

Events such as these were carried out for 28 years at our annual camp so we have a long and successful track record. Despite a big name ICAN is quite small and needs to grow. Any money given for this canoe venture is going to be used only towards travel cots. Ferries from Dover and Italy plus fuel. £800 is all that is asked but more would help. Friar will try to make up any short fall.

Therefore any donations would be of genuine help. In the event of this not being filmed anything over £800 could help get a “GoPro” camera to at least get something on film. The intended departure date is late April or early May 2014. There might be a slight delay due to the death of Friar's mother.

Anybody who donates is welcome to have some free entry to events held on our proposed site and will be put on the email list to be kept updated on future ICAN developments. Some activities do take place without us having a permanent site such as solar panel and canoe making, international food evenings and Sunday coast and Dartmoor walks with people from other countries, in fact this is the 20th year of these walks and many of the walkers came to the camps. You are welcome to join us when possible. Also I will send you photographs of the canoe journey after it is completed.

Please look at our web site www.ican21.org.uk which is done by volunteers, especially Geoff when he has time. Please forgive some lack of updating, we all do our best. Thank you on behalf of ICAN. To join our mailing list to be kept in touch with further developments, please email mailing@ican21.org.uk.

story:
Հայերենն այստեղ

Версия на русском 

Currently 22 of the over 400 active mines in Armenia are metal mines. These mines deposit heavy-metal pollutants into the environment affecting the land, water, and air in nearby communities. Poor monitoring and enforcement of regulations leaves these communities exposed to toxic pollution. Independent monitoring will empower these communities to take the first step in making mining more accountable and responsible.

Your donation will help purchase urgently needed ENVIRONMENTAL LABORATORY EQUIPMENT that will enable scientists at the American University of Armenia’s Center for Responsible Mining to survey the impacts of mining in Armenia, to inform affected citizens of these impacts and to find solutions that preserve the health and quality of communities and their environment.


Heavy Metals, Heavy Damage

Mining and mineral processing can be important sources of economic growth and development. In order to ensure that Armenia fully maximizes the benefits from developing these industries, the environmental and public health risks associated with mining must be identified, measured and adequately assessed.

Today, Armenia is facing a crucial choice. It can continue on mining path that gives no consideration to its environmental and public health consequences or it can begin a new chapter. It can begin a chapter where environmental impacts are measured, public health risks in communities are properly assessed and international best practices are introduced to ensure the environmental, social and economic well-being of communities all over Armenia. 

To do this, WE NEED YOUR HELP.

Irresponsible Mining is Undermining Our Health

Impacts resulting from mineral extraction and processing include: heavy metals contamination, acid rock drainage (ARD), tailings deposits and harmful particulate emissions. These may all impact the soil, water, plants, animals and air that communities rely on for their welfare and livelihood. These pollutants also often enter people’s organisms, with dire health consequences.

Take lead, for example: overexposure to this common metal can cause diminished IQ’s in children, fertility problems in both men and women, as well as digestive issues and serious nervous system ailments. Other heavy metals such as Mercury, Cadmium, Chromium VI, act as carcinogens. These also negatively impact fertility and cause respiratory and digestive ailments—a pretty heavy legacy to leave, especially in such a small country.

The Project

The AUA Center for Responsible Mining is asking for your help in equipping our environmental laboratory with instruments that will detect the presence and concentration of major pollutants, such as lead, mercury, arsenic, cadmium and copper, in soil, water and inside people’s bodies. This will allow the AUA and its team of leading environmental scientists to carry out precise and accurate tests in all affected communities on a regular basis, thus providing an important evidence-based advocacy and compliance tool. The AUA Center for Responsible Mining will also train and engage civil society organizations to participate in independent monitoring of pollution in affected communities.

Phase I: ONEArmenia will crowdfund in order to raise the first $29,664 ($24,000 goes to AUA and $5,664 are fees for developing this campaign) of the total $75,000 that is needed. These funds will enable the AUA Environmental Center to purchase portable equipment for the rapid on-site assessment of 5 of the toxic heavy metals found in soil and water: arsenic, cadmium, copper, mercury and lead. These portable instruments have a detection range of parts per million (ppm), which is sufficient to detect medium to high levels of contamination. Phase I also includes the acquisition of a portable analyzer that will measure lead concentrations in blood.

Phase 2: $51,000 will be raised through matching grants.  If you add the $24,000 raised + the matching grants it gives us the $75,000 needed. These funds will go towards completing the purchase of all the basic instruments identified in Phase I, as well as a powerful stationary instrument known as the graphite furnace atomic absorption spectrophotometer (GFAAS).   This spectrophotometer will enable the detection of 50 toxic heavy metals, in both the soil and water with a high degree of accuracy and reliability, in the range of parts per billion (ppb). This is the level of detection sensitivity specified in the World Health Organization guidelines and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The AUA lab will carry out advanced fieldwork and educational, community outreach.

About AUA CRM

Through research, training, and advocacy, AUA CRM promotes the creation and adoption of global best practices on environmentally and economically responsible mining in Armenia and the surrounding region. To achieve this, AUA CRM engages with all key stakeholders including industry, civil society, environmental advocacy groups, financial institutions, and the public sector.

Learn more at CRM.aua.am. 

---------------

The ONEArmenia Mission

Our goal is to set a new standard for transparent giving and develop culture and technology in Armenia.  We are a for-purpose platform that connects the global community with organizations and individuals who are committed to making a difference in Armenia.

Learn more at ONEArmenia.org.
