story:
Summary


Why your supports are needed

  One of the most dreadful catastrophe for modern society is water pollution with radioactive poisons, which causes the increases of gene abnormalities and cancers.

Conventional separation technologies (e.g., chemical precipitation or ion-exchange) can remove radioactive nuclides such as 137Cs, 90Sr, 144Ce, 106Ru, and 95Zr from  effluents produced at atomic power plants.

However, there are no effective conventional methods for separating tritium (T) forming a water molecule (HTO) from huge volume of water (H2O) at room temperature due to the similarity of physicochemical properties between HTO and H2O. Even if mass concentration of T in water is an extremely low level (e.g., nano grams per liter), its radioactive concentration of T corresponds to a level of million-becquerels (Bq) per liter (L). The EU standard vale of T for drinking water is 100 Bq/L.

  At present, radioactive effluents containing T are drained to the ocean from over 400 of atomic power plants in the world. However, the post-accident Fukushima atomic power plant (PAFAP) is currently producing T-containing effluents that have radioactive concentrations of 1000000 ~ 5000000Bq/L. This concentration is 10 ~ 50 thousandfold higher than the EU standard value for drinking water. Over 600000 tons of the T-containing effluents had already been haphazardly stored in tanks built beside the seacoast up to now. 

Before the serious accident, Fukushima atomic power plant had drained about 2 trillion Bq of T per one year within the regulation (3700 billion Bq/year) to the ocean with the normal operation of the power plant. Since the accident, over 900 trillion Bq of T produced from the accident reactors is being stored in tanks by April 2015. This quantity of T in tanks is equivalent to the quantity of T from the normal plant operation for 450 years! Japanese government is planning to dilute the effluent and drain it into the Pacific Ocean. Can you accept the releasing such huge volume of effluents containing T to the ocean?

Moreover, the production of effluent from the PAFAP has been forecast to continue for at least 20-30 years, until the finish of the operation for collecting meltdown  fuels. Therefore, the effluents produced in future must be treated for maintaining the safe quality of seawater.

  The final goal of our research project is the development of a pilot system for treating actual effluents containing T through collaborations with potential universities and industries, to solve this serious problem. 
By your support to this campaign, we can develop a system for extracting T from water and can make constructive collaborations with potential universities and industries in the world. From autumn 2013, we have been continuing this research project without any financial supports in Japan.

What is the major risk of tritium

We must minimize tritium contamination for drinking water or food, by removing tritium from radioactive effluents at atomic power plants, before releasing the effluents to the river or ocean.

Tritium diffuses easily in the seawater because tritium does not form precipitation in seawater unlike other radioactive nuclides. Accordingly, tritium water (HTO) released to the ocean and river, behaves as water (H2O) to evaporate and to circulate in our environment.

Especially, the worst scenario regarding the spreading of contaminated waters from Fukushima over the next decade was reported by German oceanographers, on Environmental Research Letters, 7. Their simulation showed the radioactive water from Fukushima could reach the US West Coast in the next 5–6 years.

http://environmentalresearchweb.org/cws/article/news/50176

 http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1748-9326/7/3/034004


How to remove tritium from water in our strategy

  • We recently found a novel function of a manganese oxide for absorbing T in water at room temperature.
    Thus, this method provides a major breakthrough in the separation technology for extracting T from water.     The product package and the electron-micrograph are shown below. 

  • By adding this manganese oxide powder to a test water containing T at room temperature, the radioactive concentration of T in the test water showed a remarkable decrease of 2.74 million Bq/L during the first 30 min on the reaction time as shown below. However, a subsequent increase after a minimum concentration was reached on the curve.
  • Accordingly, using a flow-type liquid scintillation system to perform in-situ measurements for monitoring the changes in the radioactive concentration of T is necessary. The system can indicate the correct timing for separating the absorbent from the treated water before reaching the saturation of the T extraction.

This research result is currently in production by Taylor & Francis publisher,  as an original article on a journal, Separation Science and Technology.  The doi of the paper is http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/01496395.2015.1018440.

  • As the next step, we are now developing and testing a membrane electrode made from the powdered manganese oxide absorbent, for decreasing the subsequent increase of the radioactive concentration of T.
  • By connecting the membrane electrode to the ground, decreasing the dissolution of Mn from the absorbent was confirmed. Moreover, a novel mechanism for extracting T from water by the absorbent is proposed as shown below.


What is the role of Indiegogo

  We would like to remarkably progress the phase 2, using the fund donated from this campaign. The achievement of subjects in the phase 2 is expected within 12 months from the May 2015. At the same time, several international collaborations should be constructed for early starting the phase 3.


How your donation will be spent 

The fund estimated as $80,000 will be divided like the pie chart below.

Perks


Details of perks

$20: Thank you email with Japanese snapshots . You can choose  a) or b). The data size of each photograph is about 2 ~ 5 MB. We want to maintain these cultures through this campaign.


$50: Monthly newsletter attached on email for 6 months from June 2015.


$150: FSL original papercraft of bald eagle that is a symbol of this campaign. 

You can enjoy the handmade-assembling. Including the shipping cost.

    

Bald eagle (size: height 180, width 186, depth 110 mm, color: blue) designed by d-torso (d-torsoshop.com).  All of the parts are packaged in an envelope.


$500: E-paper A (Recent research report and Supplementary data of T-absorbent, such as electron micrographs and X-ray diffraction data). You can observe the surface  of the T-absorbent and analyze the crystal structure on your computer.

      


$1000: Product of T-absorbent  (5 g) for 10 times batch test available in  your laboratory. Including the shipping cost. Plus, E-paper B (Instruction manual of the T-absorbent for the synthesis and usage).

       


$1500: E-paper A, E-paper B, and Product of T-absorbent  (5 g) . Including the shipping cost. 


$10000: Collaboration with our team, for sharing the latest experimental results and know-how. The joint development of a pilot  system for treating actual effluent of T under a formal contract. Conflict of interest among collaborators will be considered.


Message from founder

  We believe that this method is the most effective and inexpensive one compared with any conventional treatment. Through this campaign, we appeal for the necessity of global networks constructed by people who are not controlled by specific organizations, to prevent the large scale environmental pollution. We will not ever give up this project supported by your kindness.

Sincerely yours,

H. Koyanaka, Ph. D


Other ways you can help

Introducing this campaign to your friends, appropriate institutions, and social media (Newspapers, FaceBook, Twitter, etc.) will be very helpful.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Although this campaign can not gather enough people attentions until the deadline (May 19), 

we open the full text of our article to everybody with our best thanks. You can use a free download service with up to 50 people by the following link. 

http://www.tandfonline.com/eprint/RvrrAIGW6pRnczNhsHeH/full

From H. K.

May 17, 2015
story_txt:
Summary














Why your supports are needed

  One of the most dreadful catastrophe for modern society is water pollution with radioactive poisons, which causes the increases of gene abnormalities and cancers.
Conventional separation technologies (e.g., chemical precipitation or ion-exchange) can remove radioactive nuclides such as 137Cs, 90Sr, 144Ce, 106Ru, and 95Zr from  effluents produced at atomic power plants.

However, there are no effective conventional methods for separating tritium (T) forming a water molecule (HTO) from huge volume of water (H2O) at room temperature due to the similarity of physicochemical properties between HTO and H2O. Even if mass concentration of T in water is an extremely low level (e.g., nano grams per liter), its radioactive concentration of T corresponds to a level of million-becquerels (Bq) per liter (L). The EU standard vale of T for drinking water is 100 Bq/L.
  At present, radioactive effluents containing T are drained to the ocean from over 400 of atomic power plants in the world. However, the post-accident Fukushima atomic power plant (PAFAP) is currently producing T-containing effluents that have radioactive concentrations of 1000000 ~ 5000000Bq/L. This concentration is 10 ~ 50 thousandfold higher than the EU standard value for drinking water. Over 600000 tons of the T-containing effluents had already been haphazardly stored in tanks built beside the seacoast up to now. 

Before the serious accident, Fukushima atomic power plant had drained about 2 trillion Bq of T per one year within the regulation (3700 billion Bq/year) to the ocean with the normal operation of the power plant. Since the accident, over 900 trillion Bq of T produced from the accident reactors is being stored in tanks by April 2015. This quantity of T in tanks is equivalent to the quantity of T from the normal plant operation for 450 years! Japanese government is planning to dilute the effluent and drain it into the Pacific Ocean. Can you accept the releasing such huge volume of effluents containing T to the ocean?

Moreover, the production of effluent from the PAFAP has been forecast to continue for at least 20-30 years, until the finish of the operation for collecting meltdown  fuels. Therefore, the effluents produced in future must be treated for maintaining the safe quality of seawater.

  The final goal of our research project is the development of a pilot system for treating actual effluents containing T through collaborations with potential universities and industries, to solve this serious problem. 


By your support to this campaign, we can develop a system for extracting T from water and can make constructive collaborations with potential universities and industries in the world. From autumn 2013, we have been continuing this research project without any financial supports in Japan.

Especially, the worst scenario regarding the spreading of contaminated waters from Fukushima over the next decade was reported by German oceanographers, on Environmental Research Letters, 7. Their simulation showed the radioactive water from Fukushima could reach the US West Coast in the next 5–6 years.
http://environmentalresearchweb.org/cws/article/news/50176
 http://dx.doi.org/10.1088/1748-9326/7/3/034004

By adding this manganese oxide powder to a test water containing T at room temperature, the radioactive concentration of T in the test water showed a remarkable decrease of 2.74 million Bq/L during the first 30 min on the reaction time as shown below. However, a subsequent increase after a minimum concentration
was reached on the curve.

Accordingly, using a flow-type liquid scintillation system to perform in-situ measurements for monitoring the changes in the radioactive concentration of T is
necessary. The system can indicate the correct timing for separating the absorbent from
the treated water before reaching the saturation of the T extraction.


This research result is currently in production by Taylor & Francis publisher,  as an original article on a journal, Separation Science and Technology.  The doi of the paper is http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/01496395.2015.1018440.




As the next step, we are now developing and testing a membrane electrode made from the powdered manganese oxide absorbent, for decreasing the subsequent increase of the radioactive concentration of T.

By connecting the membrane electrode to the ground, decreasing the dissolution of Mn from the absorbent was confirmed. Moreover, a novel mechanism for extracting T from water by the absorbent is proposed as shown below.

story:
Meet the Folks Fighting the Cheay Areng Dam

Help send Earth First! Journal's Kat Eng to the Areng Valley in the Cardamoms Protected Forest in southwest Cambodia to interview frontline environmental activists about their struggle to protect their home from the Chinese-funded Sinohydro, a hydropower dam that threatens to destroy the pristine ecosystem and displace 1,500 indigenous people. This interview will be featured in the upcoming Eostar 2015 Earth First! Journal.

What is the Areng Valley?

The remote Areng Valley is located in the 400,000-hectare Central Cardamoms Protected Forest, one the country’s last pristine natural forests in Koh Kong province. The valley is home to an ethnic Chong community that has resided in the area for centuries. It also contains the habitats of rare and endangered animal and fish species, including the Asian Arowana, Asian Elephant and Siamese Crocodile. The people of Areng Valley have come together to organize against Sinohydro's dam using groundbreaking community-based forms of resistance including mass protests and road blockades.

Who is Kat Eng?

Kat Eng is a Khmer-American activist and multimedia artist. Her work ranges from covering the exploitative work practices in Cambodian garment factories to the environmental destruction of the Briger Forest in Palm Beach, Florida. Kat runs Up Srei Media, an independent media project that aggregates daily news from Cambodia through an anti-capitalist and feminist lens. Her design and performance portfolio can be viewed at www.inkateng.com. She currently lives in South Florida, where she is employed by Earth First! Journal.

What We Need Funded

  • Transportation expenses: plane ticket (round-trip), bus and motodop fare
  • Recording equipment: camera, voice recorder
  • Hiring an interpreter during the 2-week project
  • Room/board for Kat and aforementioned interpreter

 If we don't raise sufficient funds, part of the money will be used to conduct this interview from abroad through a hired an interpreter, and the rest will be donated to Mother Nature Cambodia NGO and used directly by on the ground activists in Areng Valley to continue their campaign.

Thanks for your support!

story:
What is DC Gardens.com?

  • Images and videos of DC-area gardens by month, enticing people to visit year-round.  (Here's August.)
  • Deep Local Resources turning more residents into gardeners.
  • Using digital images donated by volunteers, DC Gardens is inexpensive. Managed and funded independently from the gardens, it can be nimble and very, very useful.  

Why Gardens (and Gardening) Matter

The Washington, D.C. area is blessed with fabulous gardens that are open to the public, most of them free. Sadly, they're largely unknown and lack the funds to get the word out. If people could just see what they look like - throughout the year - more would visit and that matters because:
  • Gardens bring visitors close to plants and to all of nature, which benefits them mentally, spiritually and physically.
  • Visiting gardens is a gateway experience to taking up gardening at home and in the community.
  • Public gardens are the primary teaching facilities for turning residents into gardeners, with classes and workshops on growing food, providing for wildlife, protecting our waterways from polluting run-off, and creating beauty in our home gardens or balconies.
  • Turning people on to gardening results in more beauty for all of us to enjoy and better stewardship of our land - without nagging.

How the Money Will be Used  

  • $25,000 will fund DC Gardens for all of 2015, our "demonstration year." Results from 2015 will attract long-term sponsors so that the DC Gardens is self-sustaining.  
  • Most of the funds ($18,000) will be used to hire a digital communications expert (Washington Gardener Magazine editor and social media whiz Kathy Jentz) to regularly get the word out to general, travel and gardening audiences locally, nationally and internationally.
  • Monthly Updates will include major garden-related events in our region and images showing what the gardens will look like in the coming month.
  • Our other demonstration-year expenses are graphic design and web design services.
  • If we don't reach our goal, the campaign will still begin in March of 2015 but may not find long-term sponsors before the funds run out.
  • If more than $25,000 is raised, we can do more, as ideas arise. Examples include in-garden events, helping to bring national garden writers to D.C. to spread the word, printing, etc. 
  • Indiegogo will keep 4% if we meet our goal, 9% if we don't.

Impacts

  • More visitors and residents will discover and enjoy the benefits of visiting our beautiful gardens.  
  • More visitors will learn to garden - in their own yard or in the neighborhood. New gardeners benefit physically and mentally, and neighborhoods become more beautiful. 
  • More plants will be grown that provide for pollinators and birds. Stormwater runoff will be reduced and the Chesapeake Bay will be healthier.
  • More food will be grown locally in back yards and community gardens.
  • Locals with learn and network like crazy through our Deep Local Resources. They'll discover clubs, email groups, where to learn in person and online, where to volunteer, find plants, become Master Gardeners, etc. 
  • Visitors to DC will stay longer to see our gardens. More business visitors will bring their gardening spouses with them. As our gardens become better known, more people will come to Washington, D.C.  Good for business!
  • The Public Garden Association and the Garden Tourism Conference will be spreading the word about what DC is doing to promote gardens and gardening. Other cities will learn what works well and cost-efficiently to increase garden visitorship and turn residents into gardeners.
  • Garden writers and photographers in other cities will be hired to customize for their city what DC Gardens is doing. 
  • The gardens that need more public support just to stay open and keep the plants alive will get the support they need.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute, please spread the word by sharing the link to this campaign. Indiegogo share tools are available to make that easy.
  • If you're local to DC and enjoy photography or videography, email DCGardens to volunteer!

How DC Gardens.com Started

Prof. Richard Benfield gave an inspiring talk in DC about the value of gardens for tourism, which led to some local gardens brainstorming about a collective marketing campaign.  Garden blogger and volunteer Susan Harris was in on the brainstorming and began photographing gardens several times a month, through November. More photographers have joined the cause and their garden shots will be added to DC Gardens in 2015.

Photo credits: John Boggan, Tom Stovall, You-yen Yang, Susan Harris, Jim Sohn,  Gaynell and Junko Catherine.

story:
Introductions!

Hello, we are Alice and Ceri.  We are seeking your help to fund the start-up of a new Eco Pantry shop in York.  We want to offer shoppers in York the opportunity to buy a wide range of store cupboard and household essentials, without any horrible throw-away plastic packaging!

(Don’t worry, we’re going to spare you the lecture about ocean plastics.)

(Alice made Sir David Attenborough's 85th birthday cake!)

What We Need...

In order to provide a large range of waste-free products to our customers, there are a number of start-up expenditures that go over and above everything necessary to open a ‘normal’ shop.  We need to buy a lot of gravity dispensers, scoop dispensers, liquid dispensers, jars and caddies, as well as specialist ‘weigh and pay’ digital scales with labelling systems to make sure our customers always have a smooth and easy shopping experience with us.

We want to open the shop that our customers and our beloved Bishy Road High Street deserve; not a meagre attempt.  We want to offer a wealth of choice of pantry goods and household essentials that take care of all our customers needs.

The specialist scales are vital in making the shopping experience for you as easy as possible, but with the funding we have, something will have to give if we want them. Realistically, the amount of products we can offer will take a large hit, and we have already had loads of requests from excited customers; we'd hate to let anyone down. This is why we're asking for a contribution of £5000 so that we are able to open the store exactly how we want to, starting as we mean to go on.

...And What You Get

To the right you can see all the lovely perks we have to offer as a way of saying thank you for your contributions. We only had so many characters to fit in those boxes so here's some proper descriptions of what we have to offer! All the items will be available to collect from the shop when we open.

£10 - By getting this perk you'll get a personalised thank you from Alice and Ceri, and a voucher that will get you 10% off your first ten shops at The Bishy Weigh.

£15 - Along with a lovely thank you, and a cheeky discount, you also get a handy, reusable shopping bag with our logo on. This is a great start in helping avoid those pesky plastic carrier bags.

£25 - Not only do you get the thanks, discount, and canvas bag, you also get 3 produce bags (small, medium, and large) to use for your zero-waste dry goodies. Great for things like pasta, rice, and fresh fruit and veg. Between uses you can even chuck them in with the laundry.

£50 - With a big thank you, and 10% discounts, we upgrade the canvas bag to a larger, more robust jute shopping bag with our logo on it, setting you up great for zero-waste shopping. But wait, there's more! You still get the set of three produce bags, as well as a set of three (small, medium, and large) storage tins and a Husk Cup, which is a reusable takeaway cup made from rice husks!

£75 - Along with everything you get at the £50 perk, you also get a VIP +1 ticket to our exclusive launch party! Come along and be the first to see the new shop and team, with VIP treatment, and special offers on the day! We're hoping that this will be mid-late November, which we think might just be a great time to throw in some festive spirit too.

£100 - Not only do you get your zero-waste shopping starter kit and VIP entry to our launch party, you also get an entire tray of White Rose Bakes' infamous Sea-Salted Caramel Millionaire's Shortbread! We know you'll want to keep the whole tray to yourself...

£150 - You still get your zero-waste shopping starter kit and VIP entry to our launch party, but this is where you can have a little bit of choice! Either you can also get 3 month's supply of White Rose Bakes' gorgeous Millionaire's Shortbread OR  a bespoke celebration cake for up to 40 people. Great for if you've got a birthday, work do, or just a good ol' knees up.

£200 - This perk is almost the same as the £150 one, except you get even more cake! You can choose from a 5 month's supply of that almost addictive shortbread OR a bespoke celebration cake for up to 60 people.

£500 - First of all, if you go for this perk: wow! Thank you so much. We're so grateful that this time, in addition to the zero-waste shopping goodies, discount, and VIP party, you get a choice of a whole year's supply of Millionaire's shortbread OR a bespoke celebration cake for up to 120 people. Perhaps you have a wedding or special celebration coming up, or you could throw yourself a party for being such a generous person! (This perk can only be delivered in the Yorkshire area)

£750 - This is super generous and we'll be super grateful if you go for this perk. You'll still get your zero-waste shopping goodies, discount, and VIP party, and we'll put together a beautiful, bespoke dessert buffet table for you and up to 150 people. Again, we think this should be in celebration of you, but it will also give any wedding or big celebration the WOW factor! (This perk can only be delivered in the Yorkshire area)

£1000 - This is the godly perk! If you are so kind as to grab this perk you will get all your zero-waste starter kit and discount, you'll be the most VIP at the launch party, and we'll create you the best bespoke dessert table for you and up to 250 people. Oh, and because you've helped so much, we'll also name our scales in honour of you and your help.(This perk can only be delivered in the Yorkshire area)

 

How will you benefit from this venture?

You will get a richly stocked pantry store, offering all its goods to customers with either no packaging at all, or in some cases (such as our fully biodegradable bamboo toothbrushes) minimal recyclable/compostable cardboard packaging.

You will have peace of mind, knowing that your dedicated shop owner and manager will choose suppliers carefully to make sure that we have great quality products, and that we receive our bulk goods in recyclable/compostable sacks wherever possible.

You will have the opportunity to reduce your plastic waste, and be part of a great community while you’re at it!

You will be able to shop for what you need, when you need it.  Need a little bit of an unusual ingredient for a recipe, or fancy trying out something new?  Just buy the quantity you need, with no more part-packs getting left sitting idly in the cupboard.

You will get great customer service when you visit, with our team always happy to help or to chat recipes with you.

You will get a great addition to the existing family of wonderful independent food retailers on Bishy Road High Street.

 

Why are we the right people to do this?

Alice is already a business owner.  She started a small bakery business with next-to-no start-up capital 5 years ago.  Initially the business only supported Alice working part-time from home, but she has grown it steadily and White Rose Bakes now operates from a commercial premises and supports both Alice and Ceri full-time.

Prior to White Rose Bakes, both Ceri and Alice have vast experience working in food business management, retail management and customer service, giving them both the right skill sets to carry this venture forward.

Alice lives in York’s South Bank neighbourhood where the shop will be located, and is an active member of the community; volunteering for local events and helping out at the community garden.

We care deeply about the environment and regularly participate in beach cleans on the Yorkshire Coast, organised by Waves of Waste. We are also practical thinkers who want to bring about opportunities for easy, affordable, environmentally-friendly lifestyle changes in our community.

We love food!  As keen foodies and accomplished bakers, we are confident we can assemble a pantry store that will offer everything you are looking for.

 

Why Bishy Road?

York has a reputation for its love of food and independent businesses. In particular, Bishopthorpe Road is the hub of York’s South Bank neighbourhood, and is privileged to have a strong residential community who are loyal customers to Bishy Road High Street and its independent traders.

The local community are already demonstrating their readiness to adapt to a greener lifestyle through the efforts of Planet South Bank, the local voluntary litter-picking walks, and the customer demand for green lifestyle products in the existing shops.

We feel that our offering will compliment those of the other independent traders on Bishy Road High Street, and enhance the already strong attraction of the street to shoppers.

 

Then what?

We've already started some great conversations with other local businesses, looking into some ideas like a recipe book, click-and-collect, and home delivery services. These are certainly a little way off, but we already have them as goals in mind that we would like to achieve as soon as we can.

Along with our own ideas, we also think it's important to draw on what the community would like to see from us, so we're always open to suggestions and we hope you're as excited as we are in seeing what we can grow The Bishy Weigh into.

 

Risks & Challenges

To be blunt, the biggest risk and challenge we face is running this crowdfunding campaign. We've worked hard to gather the funding we have, and just need this last extra push to make sure we can open The Bishy Weigh in the best way possible. Luckily, we'll still be able to open the store, but only with a basic range. We want to encourage more people to take up a more eco-friendly lifestyle, and a magnificent range of products will certainly help. By getting any of our lovely perks you will help us open an eco-friendly superstore York can be proud of!

This is where you can help!

Any contribution, big or small, will get us closer to our target amount, and closer to opening the best zero-waste store we can give York. 

Don’t worry if you can’t make a contribution! Get the word out, talk to everyone you know about it, share the campaign on social media using the handy tools IndieGoGo has to help with that. Anything at all will be the greatest help, and much appreciated!
story_txt: Introductions!Hello, we are Alice and Ceri.  We are seeking your help to fund the start-up of a new Eco Pantry shop in York.  We want to offer shoppers in York the opportunity to buy a wide range of store cupboard and household essentials, without any horrible throw-away plastic packaging!(Don’t worry, we’re going to spare you the lecture about ocean plastics.)(Alice made Sir David Attenborough's 85th birthday cake!)What We Need...In order to provide a large range of waste-free products to our customers, there are a number of start-up expenditures that go over and above everything necessary to open a ‘normal’ shop.  We need to buy a lot of gravity dispensers, scoop dispensers, liquid dispensers, jars and caddies, as well as specialist ‘weigh and pay’ digital scales with labelling systems to make sure our customers always have a smooth and easy shopping experience with us.We want to open the shop that our customers and our beloved Bishy Road High Street deserve; not a meagre attempt.  We want to offer a wealth of choice of pantry goods and household essentials that take care of all our customers needs.The specialist scales are vital in making the shopping experience for you as easy as possible, but with the funding we have, something will have to give if we want them. Realistically, the amount of products we can offer will take a large hit, and we have already had loads of requests from excited customers; we'd hate to let anyone down. This is why we're asking for a contribution of £5000 so that we are able to open the store exactly how we want to, starting as we mean to go on....And What You GetTo the right you can see all the lovely perks we have to offer as a way of saying thank you for your contributions. We only had so many characters to fit in those boxes so here's some proper descriptions of what we have to offer! All the items will be available to collect from the shop when we open.£10 - By getting this perk you'll get a personalised thank you from Alice and Ceri, and a voucher that will get you 10% off your first ten shops at The Bishy Weigh.£15 - Along with a lovely thank you, and a cheeky discount, you also get a handy, reusable shopping bag with our logo on. This is a great start in helping avoid those pesky plastic carrier bags.£25 - Not only do you get the thanks, discount, and canvas bag, you also get 3 produce bags (small, medium, and large) to use for your zero-waste dry goodies. Great for things like pasta, rice, and fresh fruit and veg. Between uses you can even chuck them in with the laundry.£50 - With a big thank you, and 10% discounts, we upgrade the canvas bag to a larger, more robust jute shopping bag with our logo on it, setting you up great for zero-waste shopping. But wait, there's more! You still get the set of three produce bags, as well as a set of three (small, medium, and large) storage tins and a Husk Cup, which is a reusable takeaway cup made from rice husks!£75 - Along with everything you get at the £50 perk, you also get a VIP +1 ticket to our exclusive launch party! Come along and be the first to see the new shop and team, with VIP treatment, and special offers on the day! We're hoping that this will be mid-late November, which we think might just be a great time to throw in some festive spirit too.£100 - Not only do you get your zero-waste shopping starter kit and VIP entry to our launch party, you also get an entire tray of White Rose Bakes' infamous Sea-Salted Caramel Millionaire's Shortbread! We know you'll want to keep the whole tray to yourself...£150 - You still get your zero-waste shopping starter kit and VIP entry to our launch party, but this is where you can have a little bit of choice! Either you can also get 3 month's supply of White Rose Bakes' gorgeous Millionaire's Shortbread OR  a bespoke celebration cake for up to 40 people. Great for if you've got a birthday, work do, or just a good ol' knees up.£200 - This perk is almost the same as the £150 one, except you get even more cake! You can choose from a 5 month's supply of that almost addictive shortbread OR a bespoke celebration cake for up to 60 people.£500 - First of all, if you go for this perk: wow! Thank you so much. We're so grateful that this time, in addition to the zero-waste shopping goodies, discount, and VIP party, you get a choice of a whole year's supply of Millionaire's shortbread OR a bespoke celebration cake for up to 120 people. Perhaps you have a wedding or special celebration coming up, or you could throw yourself a party for being such a generous person! (This perk can only be delivered in the Yorkshire area)£750 - This is super generous and we'll be super grateful if you go for this perk. You'll still get your zero-waste shopping goodies, discount, and VIP party, and we'll put together a beautiful, bespoke dessert buffet table for you and up to 150 people. Again, we think this should be in celebration of you, but it will also give any wedding or big celebration the WOW factor! (This perk can only be delivered in the Yorkshire area)£1000 - This is the godly perk! If you are so kind as to grab this perk you will get all your zero-waste starter kit and discount, you'll be the most VIP at the launch party, and we'll create you the best bespoke dessert table for you and up to 250 people. Oh, and because you've helped so much, we'll also name our scales in honour of you and your help.(This perk can only be delivered in the Yorkshire area) How will you benefit from this venture?You will get a richly stocked pantry store, offering all its goods to customers with either no packaging at all, or in some cases (such as our fully biodegradable bamboo toothbrushes) minimal recyclable/compostable cardboard packaging.You will have peace of mind, knowing that your dedicated shop owner and manager will choose suppliers carefully to make sure that we have great quality products, and that we receive our bulk goods in recyclable/compostable sacks wherever possible.You will have the opportunity to reduce your plastic waste, and be part of a great community while you’re at it!You will be able to shop for what you need, when you need it.  Need a little bit of an unusual ingredient for a recipe, or fancy trying out something new?  Just buy the quantity you need, with no more part-packs getting left sitting idly in the cupboard.You will get great customer service when you visit, with our team always happy to help or to chat recipes with you.You will get a great addition to the existing family of wonderful independent food retailers on Bishy Road High Street. Why are we the right people to do this?Alice is already a business owner.  She started a small bakery business with next-to-no start-up capital 5 years ago.  Initially the business only supported Alice working part-time from home, but she has grown it steadily and White Rose Bakes now operates from a commercial premises and supports both Alice and Ceri full-time.Prior to White Rose Bakes, both Ceri and Alice have vast experience working in food business management, retail management and customer service, giving them both the right skill sets to carry this venture forward.Alice lives in York’s South Bank neighbourhood where the shop will be located, and is an active member of the community; volunteering for local events and helping out at the community garden.We care deeply about the environment and regularly participate in beach cleans on the Yorkshire Coast, organised by Waves of Waste. We are also practical thinkers who want to bring about opportunities for easy, affordable, environmentally-friendly lifestyle changes in our community.We love food!  As keen foodies and accomplished bakers, we are confident we can assemble a pantry store that will offer everything you are looking for. Why Bishy Road?York has a reputation for its love of food and independent businesses. story:
We are a small group of socially-conscious Pilipinos, Balikbayans, Filipino Americans and mixed heritage Native American/Filipino who reside in the San Francisco Bay Area. Our “Balik Sa Dagat” (Return to the Sea) campaign is to learn about how to create Cross-Cultural waterway traditions. 

Follow Our Story at:

http://bangkajourney.com/2012/11/22/intro-to-bangka-journey-northern-califas/

We will carve paddles as we build our “Bangka Journey’s Family” over a two-day workshop on Dec 15-16, 2012. Bangka building design consultation with Lorenzo II Acompananda, a boat builder from Samal Island, Davao, Philippines. Reviving our waterway traditions across cultures uniquely empowers Pilipinos to connect with California Indians such as the Pomo, Ohlone, Chumash, and the Pacific Northwest Indians, as a unifying force that makes a significant impact on our families, communities, environment and future generations. 

“Bangka Journeys” contributes a valuable step as a decolonizing socially-conscious balikbayan (American born Pilipinos who return to the Philippines) to bridge the global connection of Pilipinos around the world with other Pacific peoples and the indigenous peoples of Turtle Island (Americas). 

In 1989, Elaine Streitberger (Potawatomie Prairie Band) in The Ecology of Media writes, "Paddle to Seattle," which saw traditional canoes paddled by Indians from several Northwest tribes converge on Puget Sound in July of 1989, reawakened old traditions and brought renewed attention to the Indians and their unique relationship to the Earth.” ( http://www.context.org/iclib/ic23/strtbrgr/) 

Building sustainable bangkas sets an example for future generations’ ability to respect and use the waterways for transportation without polluting our beautiful San Francisco Bay Waters.  “Bangka Journeys” will reawaken our sensibilities to our relationship with the San Francisco Bay, which needs our protection, our love, our prayers and our Bangkas.

What We Need & What You Get

100% of your funds help us begin the “Bangka Journey” towards the bangka building and paddle-making costs, and by providing travel, accommodations and food for Philip Red Eagle via train from Tacoma, Washington to Santa Rosa, California, where the cultural exchange will take place to receive knowledge and training on December 15-16, 2012. Philip H. Red Eagle will provide expert cross-cultural consultation of canoe building, paddle making, and a background of canoe traditions of Pacific Northwest. He will participate in a cross-cultural hands-on exchange between California Indian and Pilipinos/Filipino-Americans about canoe journeys. While many “Indi-pinos” have participated in different Canoe Journeys over the years, a Pilipino Bangka has yet to join the journeys. This orientation will help us build a bangka (outrigger canoe) from a log which represents a unique and historical collaboration of Native Americans/Pilipinos and mixed heritage “Indipinos” in North America.  Through Alexis Canillo (Pomo/Pilipino), a log was gifted via L. Frank Manriquez, a tribal scholar and decolonizationist of the Tongva and Ajachmem tribes, while envisioning making our “Bangka Dreams” a reality in our bay waters. All this was inspired by Philip H. Red Eagle’s question, “Where is the Filipino canoe?” during our visit to Paddle to Swinomish 2011 Canoe Journey held at Anacortes, Washington. (See: http://paddletoswinomish.com/); as well as the recent visit of the Pacific Voyagers to the San Francisco Bay Area that same summer. Mylene (Leng Leng) Amoguis Cahambing returned to the Philippine Islands to learn about seafaring traditions -- See http://bangkajourney.com. Holly Calica, artist and educator, has been networking to locate a team of carvers, who will join the Bangka Journey by continuing to carve paddles. (http://pinaymujer.blogspot.com/).

Money you contribute helps us in many ways. For example:

$10 dollars pays for one meal for one carver

$30 dollars pays for one carpool of carvers from Oakland/San Francisco to Santa Rosa

$38 dollars pays for a plank

$45 dollars pays for a day of meals for one carver

$93 dollars pays for bamboo pole (need 4 poles)

$140-175 pays for a wood carving adz

$285 dollars pays for gas and transportation costs

$500 dollars provides roundtrip Amtrak transportation for Philip H. Red Eagle

$300-1000 dollars pays for a drill press

$300-1000 dollars pays for a band saw and band saw kit                             

The Impact

  • “Bangka Journeys” is part of a healing process of decolonization from the 400+ years of Spanish and 50 years of American colonization. Contributors to this cultural and environmental development activity help us revive our heritage that was lost in the westernization of the Philippines and the Diaspora to the United States. As a researcher, and planner for the building of a Bangka, Mylene Amoguis Cahambing (Bisayan-Chinese-Portuguese-Spanish-Mexican-Otomi), leads our team. Alexis Canillo (Pomo/Bisayan) and Holly Calica (Ilocano/Pangasinan) join her in gathering resources and carving power to help the Bangka Journey materialize. They have connected with local California Indians who share a vision to build a bridge of our roots and to ‘pull’ a community together via seafaring traditions. Many Filipino-Americans have joined L. Frank Manriquez and others in water ceremonies in Marin County to honor the sacred waters of our bay. As Datu (Chief) Vic Saway, Taalandig Tribal Chief of the School of Living Traditions in the Philippines instructs, “Everything is sacred… we are a bridge for younger generations to walk across…” Our campaign builds bridges, united by sacred waters.   

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out and make waves with our “Bangka Journeys” by sharing our fundraising campaign on Facebook, Twitter and other social media. Use the Indiegogo share tools and see you on the next Wave!

story:
I am making an urgent crowdsourcing request for the $250-400 necessary to raise the bar on the future of green development in our region:

The proposed Wheaton Town Center development will house the new Park & Planning headquarters and offices for Department of Environmental Protection and DPS.

The project's current design is not just far from a green showcase that reflects the green mission of these agencies - it is in direct contradiction with years of civic input and promises the County made to my community.  Instead of leading by example, the County is placating us with "creative" graphics of fake greenery, and we are about to lose our last piece of leverage - the money.  The County Council will take the straw vote next Tuesday, March 25th, so we are asking to delay the appropriation of CIP budget funds for this project until our concerns are addressed.

We have a creative vision for an iconic green showcase building that will raise the bar on green construction in our region for decades to come, but a picture is worth a thousand words, and I need help raising the money for a graphic artist willing to do the job by next Monday.

Any financial assistance would be much appreciated.

story:
Free The Deschutes!

The once healthy and vital Deschutes estuary is now a public and environmental health hazard known as Capitol Lake. Recreational access is closed until the area is restored, and the water is of poor quality and full of invasive species - unhealthy for people and wildlife.

But it doesn't have to stay that way. By removing Olympia's 5th Avenue dam (constructed in 1951) and restoring the southernmost tip of Puget Sound, we can bring this place back to life. Removing the dam is the first step towards replacing the stagnant "lake" next to downtown Olympia with a vibrant, healthy ecosystem. It will create jobs in the restoration field, open public recreation access, and return the beauty of the marine water environment -  Puget Sound's natural place.

The Deschutes Estuary Restoration Team (DERT) has been the only group bold enough to take on the work to restore the mouth of the Deschutes River. Since 2009, we have given the estuary a voice at public meetings and advisory groups, and raised awareness in the community through outreach and education with regular newsletters, media and events. We have covered a lot of ground in the past five years, and we need your help to carry and build the momentum.

When you become a member and contribute to DERT, you help bring us one step closer to removing the dam and restoring the estuary.

What We Need

Your contribution to DERT helps up pay for:

  • Outreach and education on the functions of estuaries in healthy watersheds and the importance of removing the dam to restore the Deschutes estuary.
  • The return of public access and recreation to a vibrant urban estuary.
  • Continued operations of the Deschutes Estuary Restoration Team and our outspoken advocates for clean water, a restored environment and a robust economy.

What You Get

When you donate to DERT - you can choose between an enticing set of perks  which, either produced by us or gifted by local businesses that love what we are doing and support estuary restoration. DERT is a 501(c)3, and your contribution is tax-deductible!

  • Membership: With a membership to DERT, you show your support for restoration, and receive regular updates on our work and the Deschutes estuary.
  • Stickers: YES + estuary = YEStuary! Join in our messaging campaign so that more and more people (and governments) will say YES!
  • T-shirt: Designed by Spin Tees. Design posted below!
  • Local Businesses that support this campaign include Tamale Fusion, Traditions Café, Blue Heron Bakery, Dino’s Coffee Roasters, Spin Tees, Fertile Ground Guesthouse, the Warehouse Rock Gym and individuals who offer services in massage, acupuncture and astrology.
  • The Squaxin Island Tribe supports this campaign by offering 18 holes for four at their world class Salish Cliffs golf course, two 1-night stays at the Salish Cliffs Spa resort and passes to their amazing museum.
  • An estuary supporters Paula Connelley and Ann Butler offer a four-night stay at a cabin at  Lake Tahoe.
  • Poster: This poster, pictured below, shows one vision of a restored estuary, designed by Carrie Zielger.

The Impact

One of our biggest challenges is that many people do not understand the benefits of a healthy, functioning estuary. Some do not know what an estuary is.  And, others can’t visualize what the estuary will look like.  DERT has been working on a program called ‘Imagine the Deschutes Estuary,’ where we are helping people visualize an urban estuary and its social, economic and ecological landscape. We have been working with various artists (as demonstrated in our video) to create imagery of the estuary. What animals will we see? What will the tides looks like? Where are the people? Walking, kayaking, fishing, watching? Working as a scientist, laborer, or educator?

Last year, DERT received a grant from the Rose Foundation to develop advocacy programs and recruit volunteers.  These funds have helped us create a stronger presence in the community.  We just received another grant and we are using it to build our capacity. Just imagine how much more impact we will have with more opportunities to reach out to people. We are also focused on long-term strategic goals that ensure the livelihood of our nonprofit organization.  This includes bringing in additional funds - Indiegogo is our first attempt at an on-line fundraising effort!

Other Ways You Can Help

Don’t have the means to contribute to the campaign? You can still help!

  • Share this event with you friends through social media, e-mails and word-of-mouth!
  • Volunteer with DERT! We have a variety of opportunities.  Shoot us a line at olydert@gmail.com
  • Do you have something you could offer as a perk for this campaign? An item, service, or experience? Let us know!

Thanks to all of you - for your contributions and for your dedication to restoring the Deschutes estuary!!

But
it doesn't have to stay that way. By removing Olympia's 5th Avenue dam (constructed in 1951) and restoring
the southernmost tip of Puget Sound, we can bring this place back to life.
Removing the dam is the first step towards replacing the stagnant "lake" next to
downtown Olympia with a vibrant, healthy ecosystem. It will create jobs in the
restoration field, open public recreation access, and return the beauty of the marine water environment -  Puget Sound's natural place.
The
Deschutes Estuary Restoration Team (DERT) has been the only group bold enough
to take on the work to restore the mouth of the Deschutes River. Since 2009, we
have given the estuary a voice at public meetings and advisory groups,
and raised awareness in the community through outreach and education with
regular newsletters, media and events. We have covered a lot of ground in the
past five years, and we need your help to carry and build the momentum.
When you become a member and contribute to DERT, you help
bring us one step closer to removing the dam and restoring the estuary.
What
We Need 
Your
contribution to DERT helps up pay for: 
Outreach and education on the functions of
estuaries in healthy watersheds and the importance of removing the dam to
restore the Deschutes estuary.
The return of public access and recreation to a
vibrant urban estuary.
Continued operations of the Deschutes Estuary
Restoration Team and our outspoken advocates for clean water, a restored
environment and a robust economy.



What
You Get
When you donate to DERT - you can choose between an enticing set of perks  which, either produced by us or gifted by
local businesses that love what we are doing and support estuary restoration. DERT is a 501(c)3, and your contribution is tax-deductible!


Membership: With a membership to DERT, you show your support for restoration, and receive
     regular updates on our work and the Deschutes estuary.

Stickers: YES + estuary = YEStuary! Join in
     our messaging campaign so that more and more people (and governments) will
     say YES!

T-shirt: Designed by Spin Tees. Design posted below!


Local Businesses
     that support
     this campaign include Tamale Fusion, Traditions Café,
     Blue Heron Bakery, Dino’s Coffee Roasters, Spin Tees, Fertile Ground Guesthouse, the Warehouse Rock Gym and
     individuals who offer services in massage, acupuncture and astrology.
The Squaxin
     Island Tribe supports this campaign by offering 18 holes for four at their world class Salish Cliffs golf course, two 1-night stays at the Salish Cliffs Spa resort and passes to their amazing museum. 

An estuary supporters Paula Connelley and Ann Butler offer a four-night stay at a cabin at  Lake Tahoe.

Poster: This poster, pictured below, shows
     one vision of a restored estuary, designed by Carrie Zielger.

The
Impact
One of our biggest challenges is that
many people do not understand the benefits of a healthy, functioning estuary. Some do not know what an estuary is.  And, others can’t visualize what the estuary will look like.  DERT has been working
on a program called ‘Imagine the Deschutes Estuary,’ where we are helping people
visualize an urban estuary and its social, economic and ecological landscape. We have been working
with various artists (as demonstrated in our video) to create imagery of the
estuary. What animals will we see? What will the tides looks like? Where are
the people? Walking, kayaking, fishing, watching? Working as a scientist, laborer, or
educator?
Last year, DERT received a grant from
the Rose Foundation to develop advocacy programs and recruit volunteers.  These funds have helped us create a stronger presence in the community.  We just received another grant and we are using it to build our capacity. Just imagine how much
more impact we will have with more opportunities to reach out to people. We are
also focused on long-term strategic goals that ensure the livelihood of our
nonprofit organization.  This includes bringing in additional funds - Indiegogo is our first attempt at an on-line fundraising effort!
Other
Ways You Can Help
Don’t
have the means to contribute to the campaign? You can still help!

Share this event with you friends through
     social media, e-mails and word-of-mouth!
Volunteer with DERT! We have a variety of
     opportunities.  Shoot us a line at olydert@gmail.com

Do you have something you could offer as a perk for
     this campaign? An item, service, or experience? Let us know!
Thanks to all of you - for your contributions and for your dedication to restoring the Deschutes estuary!!

story:
There are about 60 to 200 million spaces along our city streets where trees could be planted. This translates to the potential to absorb 33 million more tons of CO2 every year, and saving four billion dollars in energy costs. - National Wildlife Federation 

Hello!

Welcome to our campaign page. We are Neighborhood Forest.

We give free trees to schoolchildren every Earth Day.

We have three goals.  We want to...

1) Give children a way to connect with the Earth

2) Beautify our neighborhoods

3) Help families put a small dent in their carbon foot-print

Here's a few facts about us:

  • Neighborhood Forest is run by two brothers with unique names. Vikas, the founder, captain and visionary, and Vivek, the guy who oversees the daily running of the organization.
  • We were founded in Minneapolis, Minnesota in 2010.
  • Since then we have reached thousands of schoolchildren that have helped plant over 2500 trees across the Twin Cities of Minneapolis / St. Paul and beyond.
  • This year we reached 11 schools and gave away close to 1000 trees.  
  • We give away free trees by way of generous contributions from businesses and individuals.
  • We executed this year's giveaway on top of a new technology platform we developed to help scale our operations using little or no paper.
  • This platform will help us grow our efforts significantly. 

For Earth Day 2014 we want to increase our impact and reach significantly.

With your help, we believe we can do it. Would you be willing to sponsor a child, a classroom or a school for Earth Day 2014?

Any amount you contribute will help us get closer to our goal.

We currently serve schools in Minnesota, but we are open to growing beyond our state's borders. A positive response from the Indiegogo community will give us the impetus to expand our program nationwide and eventually internationally.

But what's in it for you?

Feel good. Put a dent in your own carbon / pollution footprint.  Give back. Green our communities and give kids a way to do something proactive on Earth Day.

What's more, if you sponsor a school your name will seen by every parent who registers for a tree with their child. You'll also get other unique perks based on your contribution level.

Schools are always happy to get trees. Here's what they've said to us recently: 

"Thanks for this opportunity to celebrate Earth Day as a school and to add more GREEN to the environment!" – Dowling Urban Environmental School

"Thanks for giving us the opportunity to be part of this wonderful program." – Highlands Elementary School

"I can't tell you enough how impressed I am by your organization and how user friendly you made this for both me and the parents. This is such a wonderful endeavor." – Teacher, St. Anthony Park Elementary 



Want to learn some more?  Check out our video.

If you like what we are doing, another way to help out is to help us spread the word! Tweet about it. Facebook it. Tell your friends, family, strangers in the grocery aisle, anyone you think might be interested in knowing more about Neighborhood Forest. It will help us out tremendously. Come be part of our community on Facebook and Twitter too. Stay in touch. We'll keep you updated on our big plans.

Lastly, thank you for visiting our Indiegogo page. With your support, we know we'll be able to get more trees into the little hands of many more children on Earth Day.

Warmest regards,

Your friends at Neighborhood Forest (Vikas and Vivek)

The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The next best time is now. - Chinese Proverb

story:
English explanation is below. 

Amaç

Soma'da tam 6000 ağaç Termik Santral yapılması için kesildi. Danıştay iş işten geçtikten sonra yürütmeyi durdurdu. Şimdi orası boş. Tam 6000 ağaç yok yere gitti! Gelin birlik olup zaten maden kazasında yeterince zarar görmüş Soma'nın yok yere gitmiş 6000 ağacını biz dikelim. Hedef 6000 fidanı alıp Soma'nın Yırca köyüne dikilmesini sağlayalım.. Akmasak da birlik olup damlayalım. 15-20 yılda büyüyecek ağaçlar için hemen harekete geçelim!

 

 

Gereken Nedir?

Kişi başı sadece 11.50 TL veya 5$
Çünkü bir zeytin ağacı 11.50 TL Örneğin: http://www.e-fidancim.com/Gemlik-Trilye-1-Yasli-Zeytin-Fidani60-70-cm,PR-30.html
11.50TL x 6.000 Zeytin Ağacı Fidanı= 69.000 TL 
69.000 TL = $30.000 + ortalama 1.000 dolar ağaç dikim malzemeleri, indiegogo site ve para transfer ücretleri.
(69.000 TL'lik bir zeytin fidanı alınacağı için  kargo masrafı olmayacaktır.)
Yani kişi başı 11.50 TL ile Soma'nın gelecek kuşaklara aktarılacak 6000 ağacını kurtarabiliriz! Soma'da senin de bir ağacın olabilir! 
 

Proje Başarıya Ulaşamazsa Ne Olacak?

Projede 6000 fidanlık meblağ toplanamazsa, bağışlar bugün köyün muhtarının CNN Türk'e bağlanıp anlattığı güvencesi olmayan ve madenden yeterince zarar gören ve ağaç kalmasa da nöbet tutmaya hala devam eden köylülere aynen aktarılacaktır. 
 

Ben Kimim? Bana Neden Güvenesiniz?

Adım Eren Caner. Özel sektörde dijital reklamcı olarak çalışıyorum. Galatasaray Üniversitesi'nde master yapıyorum. Bir dönem üniversitede sosyal medyada marka yönetimi dersi verdim. Aşağıdaki bilgilerden hakkımda yeterince bilgi sahibi olabilir, gerektiğinde bana ulaşabilirsiniz. 
 
Hakkımda: http://erencaner.com.tr/bi-arkadasa-bakip-cikicam/ 
Blog: http://erencaner.com.tr
Facebook: http://facebook.com/erenocanero 
Twitter: http://twitter.com/erencaner
LinkedIn: http://tr.linkedin.com/in/erencaner 
 
2009 yılında lisans eğitimimde Turkcell, Teknosa, Arkas, Koç Akademi ve Bersay İletişim Grubu'ndan 26 üst düzey konuğun İstanbul'dan Eskişehir'e Eti gibi markalarla sponsorluk anlaşmaları imzalayarak sağlanan meblağ ile gelerek konuk olarak yer aldığı ve 300 kişinin bilet satın alarak katıldığı, çalışmalarının 9 ay, etkinliğin ise 2 tam gün sürdüğü Akademiler Zirvesi adlı organizasyonun genel koordinatörü olarak başında yer almıştım. Detaylar burada: http://e-gazete.anadolu.edu.tr/ayrinti.php?no=7693
 

Projenin Değerleri:

  • Bu zeytin ağaçları kesilmesin diye bir süredir nöbet tutan, ağaçların kesilmesini istemeyen köylülere moral olacak ve gelecek kuşaklara 6000 zeytin ağacı armağan edilecektir.
  • Proje amacına ulaşamazsa toplanan para bölgede zeytincilik yapan ve şimdi işsiz kalan köylülere aynen verilecektir. 
  • 6000 ağaç en kısa sürede yerine dikileceği için Türkiye'nin termik santral sebebiyle eksik kalan ciğerleri yerine iade edilecektir.
  • Zeytin ağacı dikimi için en uygun zaman Ekim-Mart ayları arasıdır. Bağışlar kısa zamanda toplandığı taktirde 6000 yeni ağacın dikimi için hemen harekete geçilecektir. 
  • Proje başarıya ulaştığı taktirde medyada yer bulacağından projenin her adımı kolayca TV ve sosyal medyadan takip edilebilecektir. Ayrıca projenin Twitter hesabı: https://twitter.com/6000_Yeni_Agac 
 

Riskler & Zorluklar

  • 6000 fidanı bir anda temin etmek zor olabilir. 6000 fidanın temin edilme süresine bağlı olarak 1-2 haftalık aralıklarla yapılabilir.
  • 6000 ağacın dikiminde bir zorluk yaşanmaması için Soma'daki köylülerden ve TEMA'dan destek alınacaktır.

    English:

    6000 Oliver Tree Has Been Removed in #Soma  / Turkey to create thermal reactor unduly!

    State council cancelled the desicion today. It means no thermal reactor will be there. However no longer available 6000 oliver trees. :(

    We gonna plant 6000 new oliver trees again!

    All needed is just min. $5 from everyone to plant 6000 new oliver trees!

    Because an oliver tree is $5 (means 11.50 TL) For instance; http://www.e-fidancim.com/Gemlik-Trilye-1-Yasli-Zeytin-Fidani60-70-cm,PR-30.html 

     

    $5 x 6.000 Oliver Trees Seedlings + $1.000 tree planting staffs, indiegogo and money transfer fees = $31.000 

    ortalama 1.000 dolar ağaç dikim malzemeleri, indiegogo site ve para transfer ücretleri.

    (At this amount, no payment for shipment) 

     

    Who Am I and Why You Trust Me?

    My name is Eren Caner. I'm working for a digital marketing agency as social media group head.  Furthermore, taking master education in Galatasaray University and also was  lecturer for Brand Management in Social Media for a limited time. You can reach my personal details by using below English links. 

    About me: http://bit.ly/AboutErenCaner 

    Blog: http://bit.ly/Eren_Caner 

    Facebook: http://facebook.com/erenocanero 

    Twitter: http://twitter.com/erencaner

    LinkedIn: http://tr.linkedin.com/in/erencaner

    In 2009, I was general coordinator for a big event which 300 students attended by paying money as visitor. Also 26 high level people working for big companies like Turkcell, Teknosa attended as guest to transfer their business life experiences. It was for 2 days nonetheless we worked during 9 months. Here the details:  http://bit.ly/AcademiesSummit

     

     

    What If The Project Fails?

    Villagers keeped guard so as to keep alive these trees and still. Most of them were earning money thanks to these trees :( That means they are unemployed from now on. If this project fails, whole amount will be going to these villagers directly.

    We must take action urgently. Since only one tree is growing up within 15-20 years...

     

    Thank your for your patience and donations.

story:
Hi my name is Alex and I'm a Masters student making a wildlife documentary about Madagascar.

I'm studying cinematography at Bournemouth University where I specialise in natural history film-making. I have been obsessed with wildlife ever since I can remember and started photographing it as soon as I could get my hands on a camera.

What’s it all about?

I'm heading out to the incredible island of Madagascar for one month to make a wildlife documentary about the unique species that live there and why it is so important to conserve them.

This island has fascinated me for so long because of its outstanding wildlife and remarkable and diverse ecosystems. 90% of the species there live nowhere else on earth!

Most people have seen the wonderful Disney cartoon Madagascar, but I would like to show people the real Madagascar where many of the endemic species are endangered, with some on the verge of extinction. 

While I’m making this documentary I will be travelling from the Capital 500 miles to work on a conservation site in Andava, on the Southwest coast. While I’m there I will be helping to protect the coral reefs, tortoises and assist with sustainable fishing. I hope to document Lemurs, Chameleons, butterflies, Fossa, tortoises, fish, plant life, insects and birds etc.

I will have my cameras on me at all times and will even be filming underwater!

Why am I making it?

With your help I want to use this film to show people how important and special the wildlife of Madagascar is and why it needs to be protected and saved. 

I want to get this film seen in as many places as possible. I hope to enter my film into documentary film festivals to raise awareness and also to get it shown at schools in Madagascar to help educate children about the special wildlife around them.

What We Need & What You Get for helping

It’s not cheap to make a documentary but I’ve done my very best to keep costs to a minimum! The money raised will go towards the conservation project I am working on, travel expenses and basic provisions.

In return, depending on how much you donate, you can get a digital copy or hard case DVD of the final documentary, a wildlife photograph from the expedition, an invitation to the screening in London, special thanks in the credits, special thanks on the IMDB page or you can even be an associate producer!

Every little donation helps! Please spread the word and make a donation.

Please help make this documentary a success!

THANK YOU!

Cinematographer and producer: Alex Walters

Editor:Scott Loitsch

Special thanks to Jasmine Bendell and Loren Featherstone for helping me make the fund raising video.

tortoises, fish, plant life, insects and birds etc.
I
will have my cameras on me at all times and will even be filming underwater!
Why am I making it?
With your help I want to use this film to
show people how important and special the wildlife of Madagascar is and why it
needs to be protected and saved. 
I
want to get this film seen in as many places as possible. I hope to enter my
film into documentary film festivals to raise awareness and also to get it
shown at schools in Madagascar to help educate children about the special
wildlife around them.
What We Need & What You Get for helping
It’s
not cheap to make a documentary but I’ve done my very best to keep costs to a
minimum! The money raised will go towards the conservation project I am working
on, travel expenses and basic provisions.
In
return, depending on how much you donate, you can get a digital copy or hard
case DVD of the final documentary, a wildlife photograph from the expedition,
an invitation to the screening in London, special thanks in the credits, special
thanks on the IMDB page or you can even be an associate producer!
Every little donation helps! Please spread
the word and make a donation.
Please help make this documentary a
success!
THANK YOU!
Cinematographer
and producer: Alex Walters
Editor:Scott Loitsch
Special thanks to Jasmine Bendell and Loren
Featherstone for helping me make the fund raising video.

story:
Exploration For Hydration

  • Hi. My name is Spencer Vanderheide. I'm a high school special education teacher & local musician. I'm just trying to live a good story that is worth telling.
  • You know how some people walk or run for a good cause? I'm hiking for a good cause. I'll be backpacking throughout Europe for 6 weeks, I hope you'll join in on this journey with me.
  • Over the past few years, I've been saving all my pennies for a trip to Europe. I've been eating grass, drinking pond water, and returning pop-cans in order to afford this adventure. (The money for my trip is already raised, meaning 100% of whatever we raise goes straight to providing clean water for families in the Dominican Republic.)
  • By supporting, you are partnering with myself and Kenowa Hills High School's TOG (The Opportunity Group) to help bring clean water to those in need.
  • EVERY.DOLLAR.HELPS.

What We Need & What You Get

We're hoping to raise a minimum of $1,500 towards providing clean water. 

100% of the proceeds go to The Opportunity Group. 

INCENTIVES:

If $100+ is raised, Spencer will swim with the Loch Ness Monster in Scotland.

If $250+ is raised, Spencer will go as fast as possible on the Autobahn in Germany

If $500+ is raised, Spencer will skydive over the Swiss Alps in Switzerland.

If $1,000+ is raised, Spencer will Run with the Bulls in Pamplona, Spain on July 8th.

The Impact

We take clean drinking water for granted every day. Let's partner together to provide clean drinking water for families in the Dominican Republic.

We're just trying to make this world a better place. You in?

Other Ways You Can Help

1) DONATE ONLINE 

2) SENDING A CHECK TO:

KENOWA HILLS HIGH SCHOOL  MEMO: THE OPPORTUNITY GROUP

3825 Hendershot Ave NW, Grand Rapids Charter Township, MI 49544

  **ALL ONLINE DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE!**

3) SPREAD THE WORD. LET'S MAKE SOME NOISE. THE MORE PEOPLE THAT JOIN US, THE MORE PEOPLE WE CAN PROVIDE CLEAN DRINKING WATER.


Follow the adventure by searching #KHHSTOG on Instagram.


TWEET IT.  RETWEET IT. FACEBOOK IT. INSTAGRAM IT.

story:
El 17 de Mayo, mi esposo y yo participaremos en la competencia NADO POR LA LIBRE de Cancún a Isla Mujeres en la categoría de 3K. A este reto se ha unido Edmundo Ortíz, gran nadador y amigo y el conductor más famoso del Cerro del Rebote: Raymundo Zopilote. 

Nuestra meta, además de no ahogarnos, es apoyar la campaña 1,2 3 por mí y por todos mis amigos. Campaña que busca apoyar la conservación del último gran remanente de bosque de niebla de México: La Reserva de la Biosfera El Triunfo. 

El Triunfo es un sitio mágico, en donde viven quetzales, pavones, jaguares, olmos de más de 70 metros de altura, helechos arborescentes y miles de aves que migran todos los años a esta región. Es un sitio que capturó nuestros corazones desde que lo visitamos hace 9 años y por el cual hemos trabajado. Por una parte, desde entonces yo he dirigido una asociación civil que apoya la conservación de la zona: El Fondo de Conservación El Triunfo, y Paco, mi esposo, ha sido donante y mi más grande apoyo. 

Paco, hasta hace 3 meses, sufría para nadar 100 metros seguidos y yo, aunque he nadado desde hace 10 años a raíz de una historia larga de operaciones y lesiones de rodilla, nunca he participado en una competencia y mucho menos nadado en aguas abiertas. Edmundo ya es todo un profesional y amante de estos retos, y para nuestro querido amigo Zopy, el conductor del programa infantil Radiombligo, también será su primera carrera.

Así que aquí estamos, pidiendo que la gente se sume a nuestra causa, cada brazada y cada metro nadado lo haremos pensando en las comunidades de El Triunfo, de las más marginadas del país, en donde hay mucho por hacer para que se pueda conservar este bosque de niebla sin el que no tendríamos agua.

Apóyanos patrocinando los metros que avancemos, compartiendo esta campaña o adoptando nuestra causa en tu próxima competencia.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Andrea. I am a Pacific Northwest native and my family was greatly effected by the events of Typhoon Yolanda/Haiyan in the Philippines. My relatives and ancestral family are located on the Island of Leyte which was severely hit by the force of this storm. We have been able to be in contact with our family and everyone has been found, but living in poor conditions. There is a great lack of clean water, food supply and shelter. I am choosing to revamp my previous campaign for my travels to Bali, Indonesia and donate all the proceeds to help the loved ones living in Leyte, Philippines.

I will also be traveling to see my family in the Philippines this coming February and am grateful to be able to be apart of this deeply rooted culture and ancient ancestry. I will be helping out the communities in Tocloban, Tolosa, Inopacan, and wherever else there is love, strength and unity to be shared!

What We Need & What You Get

These funds will be donated to supplement whatever is needed to bring a healthy and sustainable atmosphere of living back into balance for Leyte; i.e. food, water, medical attention, materials to build homes or clothes.

In return, I am happily honored to offer handmade Gifts of Gratitude to those who can contribute to this cause! Each item is weaved with Love and Appreciation for your support and existence here on Earth Mother! Thank you, thank you, thank you!

The Impact

This will directly help the peoples of Leyte, Philippines. Many people here are already living very simply and with not a lot of resources, and now they are struggling to survive with the basics. The impact of these donations will provide these families with the tools they need to live comfortably again and support their families and children. The simple necessities of life can do such great wonder to bring abundance back into play for these peoples. I am offering my assistance in bridging this gap at this time and taking proper action to do so! Thank you for your prayers, support and love during this time of healing!

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you, thank you, thank you, or in Tagalog 'SALAMAT', for supporting my path of healing, not only in my life, but thru all peoples and all levels, and living the dream! The best way you can help is to share this campaign with friends and family! The more the merry and to share Love and Happiness with!

To True Love, True Happiness and Peace!
I LOVE MYSELF! I Love You!

story:
About The RE Store and "Keep The RE Store Rolling"

The RE Store is a program of RE Sources which, under a previous name, Bellingham Community Recycling, pioneered local curbside recycling 30 years ago. These early efforts made Whatcom County the first in Washington State to offer recycling throughout the county at one's home. 

The RE Store started 20 years ago from a partnership between contractors and RE Sources, with start up assistance from Whatcom County Solid Waste. As a part of our celebration this year, we are asking you to help us get a new, used truck with a lift gate. Our fleet is getting very old. The trucks with names like Clutch, Lilly and Herman have between 150,000 and 200,000 miles on them. Repairs are costing us more each year than they are worth selling for.

Our goal is to bring in $5,000 and complete the last of 7 months of fundraising. This will allow us to buy a used box truck for our field services. Would you like to donate 10, 25 or more? Be sure to check out the 3.5 minute video.

What We Will Do With The Money & What Do You Get?

The money will go towards the purchase of a used 16-foot box truck with a lift gate. This will keep our crews rolling. Every day, they help home owners, builders and businesses to save money, reduce waste and steward precious reusable materials.We turn that trash into jobs and savings for people who buy in our stores.

Our perks include mentions to our almost 5000 Facebook fans, almost 1000 Twitter followers, and over 1000 visitors each month to our blog. Go bigger and get recognition in our stores on our video displays.

Go really big in your suppport and get things like shirts, stickers and a chance to name the new, used truck that we will be getting. 

If we don't reach our goal, we will have to delay the purchase of this truck until next year, and our trucks are costing us more in repairs right now that they are worth! Aaaaarrrrgh!

Why Bother?

The building and demolition industry creates a wall of trash every year in the U.S. that would run the entire length of the coastline from Canada to Mexico, 30 feet high and 30 feet wide. 

The RE Store is an award-winning non-profit organization, creating solutions to this wall of waste. Our efforts reduce disposal of reusable building materials, decor and furniture. Two stores save customers over 1 million dollars each year in the cost of their construction supplies. Our workshops and educational videos are helping move the reuse revolution forward, inspiring a culture of can-do-it-yourself attitudes. Our green job training programs in Seattle and Bellingham give displaced workers or young people valuable skills and experience.

Awards include:

1994 "Most Innovative Waste
Reduction and Recycling Program" Washington State Department of Ecology

1999 "Most Innovative Waste
Reduction and Recycling Program" Washington State Department of Ecology

1999 "Founder of a New Northwest" Sustainable Northwest, Portland, OR

2000 "Governor's Award for
Pollution Prevention" Governor Gary Locke, Olympia, WA

2002 "Community Catalyst Award" Environmental Education
Association of Washington

2003 "Sustainable Communities:
Leadership in Business Award" Sustainable Seattle, Seattle, WA

2005 NW Source People's Picks Winner Voted Seattle's favorite
Salvage/eco-friendly store

2005 "Green Globe Award" Leader
in Recycling, Waste Prevention and
Use of Recycled Materials Award King County Department
of Natural Resources

2008 "Best Way to Responsibly
Update Your Home"
Seattle Weekly's Best of Seattle Issue

2010 "Best for Reclaimed Home Materials" Sunset Magazine

2010 "Best Online Presence in
Home Decor Category"
Seattle Weekly

2013 Recycler of the Year Award
Best Reuse Category
Washington State Recycling Association

Help Us Even If You Don't Give Money!

Help us to spread the word of this campaign. We have until June 22nd, so post, tweet, and otherwise get your promoter hat on, because we love your support and would be nowhere without you! Indiegogo makes it really easy to spread the goodness.

From all of us at The RE Store,
