story:
We're Paying a Higher Price for Gasoline than we Realize

For every gallon we buy, additional costs are being imposed. Estimates of the true cost of gasoline range from $6 to $20, compared to the average U.S. price of $3.59 per gallon. Who’s footing the bill? The environment, our public health, taxpayers, developing countries, the military and future generations.

Take a quick look at the short video Center for Investigative Reporting (CIR) produced outlining the issue.


What is FullGallon?

FullGallon is a growing social enterprise that empowers individuals and organizations to voluntarily claim these "external gasoline costs"–the costs we impose on our environment, health, and future generations, but don't pay while we're filling up at the pump.

This indiegogo campaign is striving to connect with passionate individuals to continue to build the community, form partnerships and to scale up the organization–all while beginning to claim gasoline's true costs to fund alternatives and offset damage.

Ultimately, FullGallon is raising awareness of artificially low gas prices, facilitating public discourse and empowering passionate citizens to fuel change.


How it Works

Upon contributing to the campaign you'll receive an email asking for your input on the recipient organization(s) you would like to vote for in the campaign, including an overview description of each organization and its use of funds. Feel free to vote for more than one, but your vote will be split between the organizations you choose.

The final list of proposed recipient organizations (funders get to vote on) includes one or two organizations from each of the following categories:


1) Clean energy research, development and support (e.g. a clean tech incubator)


2) Specific clean energy projects (e.g. a solar panel project for a school)


3) Smart growth and mass transit organizations (e.g. Smart Growth America)


4) Environmental remediation (e.g. carbon offsets and the Environmental Defense Fund)


5) Public health organizations (e.g. asthma support for low income families)


6) Veterans support (e.g. nonprofits dedicated to health of service members returning home from overseas)


Upon completion of the campaign, the three organizations that receive the most "votes" will receive 50%, 30% and 10%, respectively, of the total amount the campaign raised. The remaining 10% will be used to scale up FullGallon as described below (primarily web development). 

Note that upon the launch of the FullGallon website, we anticipate allowing participants to choose the level of funding they would like to provide to FullGallon for its operating costs, ranging from 0% to 10% of their total contribution (rather than a fixed rate).


Claim the True Cost of Gasoline

FullGallon's indiegogo campaign enables participants to select a desired amount of costs to claim vs. defer onto others. Claim as little as five cents per gallon (which equates to $2.28 for the average American driver over a one month period) all the way up to $5 per gallon ($228 for the average driver over one month).

Each perk is based on an average American's driving habits–about 13,000 miles per year in a vehicle that averages 25 miles per gallon. Feel free to adjust your contribution if you drive more or less than the average driver (or contact us if you need help!).


Fund Alternatives, Offset Damage, Grow FullGallon

90% of contributions will be donated directly to three registered 501(c)3 nonprofit organizations, similar nonprofits, or social enterprises that you help choose based on what you care about most. The three organizations will be decided on by compiling all votes from the campaign's funders (each funder = one vote).

The available recipient organizations fall into two categories:

  • Funding fossil fuel alternatives–clean energy, mass transportation, public policy and urban planning;
  • Offsetting gasoline’s damage–environmental restoration, carbon offsets, public health and veterans’ support.

The remaining 10% of funds will be utilized to enable FullGallon to grow through the following means:

  • Web development (currently underway and self-funded; estimated $20k);
  • Infographics -- a specialized infographic team will clearly, dynamically convey Full Gallon's cause (in contract stage; cost of $5k);  
  • Marketing and branding -- broaden awareness of artificially low gasoline prices and grow FullGallon's audience to fuel change;
  • Research to expand and update knowledge of gasoline's true costs -- stage 1 costs will cover travel to meet with economists specializing in the subject and relevant consulting fees from experts; stage 2 costs will fund primary research to develop the most comprehensive, independent and up-to-date estimate of the True Cost of Gasoline yet;  

More on Gas Prices...

The study (pdf) referenced in CIR's video above estimates the true cost of gasoline could be up to $15, according to findings by the International Center for Technology Assessment (ICTA) in 1998.

More recently, in 2007 the Earth Policy Institute compiled an updated estimate (pdf) of the True Price of Gasoline using the ICTA's previous study, as well as more recent updates from them and other sources. The Earth Policy Institute estimates the following hidden gasoline cost breakdowns:

Category of Cost We Do Not Pay at the Pump Cost per Gallon
Environment, Health and Social Costs $5.98
Subsidies - Production and Consumption $0.42
Supply and Shipment Protection Costs $0.48
Other Externalities - dependence & price shock risk, etc. $3.35
Total Additional Costs (that we don't pay at the pump) $10.23


A visualization of the Earth Policy Institute's estimated ranges of the True Price of Gasoline is seen below based on four categories of hidden costs (as shown above). An aggressive estimate is seen in red, a conservative estimate in orange and the average in green. The blue bar represents the average retail price Americans currently pay ($3.59).


Exploring prices in other countries offers additional perspective on estimates of gasoline's true cost. For example, Norway pays close to $10 per gallon (despite being a major oil producer), while the Netherlands pays around $9. Europe on the whole averages $7.44 per gallon.

Moving further east, Australia and New Zealand hover around $6.50, the Japanese and South Koreans pay around $6.75, while Hong Kong pays a full $8.15 per gallon of gas.

On the other end of the spectrum, it's primarily the Middle East and Venezuela that pay less than the average price in the United States. The mere six cents per gallon paid by Venezuelans demonstrates just how subjective gasoline prices have become. 


A Few Examples of Potential Recipient Organizations Funders Vote For:

Transparency

All funders will receive formal documentation that 90% of the campaign's total funds raised were provided to the three organizations you help choose within 15 days after the close of the campaign (we are happy to make such documentation publicly available). Formal documentation of the 10% of the campaign's total funds being utilized to scale up FullGallon will be provided within 60 days of the campaign's close.

FullGallon, nor anyone involved in FullGallon, has any pre-existing relationships with any of the organizations that will be offered as potential recipient organizations (relative to the 90% of the campaign's funds being allocated to recipient organizations).

Please don't hesitate to reach out with any questions of any kind! Thanks for your support!

Note that upon the launch of the FullGallon website, we anticipate allowing participants to choose the level of funding they would like to provide to FullGallon for its operating costs, ranging from 0% to 10% of their total contribution (rather than a fixed rate).



Claim the True Cost of Gasoline

FullGallon's indiegogo campaign enables participants to select a desired amount of costs to claim vs. defer onto others. Claim as little as five cents per gallon (which equates to $2.28 for the average American driver over a one month period) all the way up to $5 per gallon ($228 for the average driver over one month).
Each perk is based on an average American's driving habits–about 13,000 miles per year in a vehicle that averages 25 miles per gallon. Feel free to adjust your contribution if you drive more or less than the average driver (or contact us if you need help!).

Fund Alternatives, Offset Damage, Grow FullGallon

90% of contributions will be donated directly to three registered 501(c)3 nonprofit organizations, similar nonprofits, or social enterprises that you help choose based on what you care about most. The three organizations will be decided on by compiling all votes from the campaign's funders (each funder = one vote).
The available recipient organizations fall into two categories:
Funding fossil fuel alternatives–clean energy, mass transportation, public policy and urban planning;
Offsetting gasoline’s damage–environmental restoration, carbon offsets, public health and veterans’ support.
The remaining 10% of funds will be utilized to enable FullGallon to grow through the following means:

Web development (currently underway and self-funded; estimated $20k);
Infographics -- a specialized infographic team will clearly, dynamically convey Full Gallon's cause (in contract stage; cost of $5k);  
Marketing and branding -- broaden awareness of artificially low gasoline prices and grow FullGallon's audience to fuel change;
Research to expand and update knowledge of gasoline's true costs -- stage 1 costs will cover travel to meet with economists specializing in the subject and relevant consulting fees from experts; stage 2 costs will fund primary research to develop the most comprehensive, independent and up-to-date estimate of the True Cost of Gasoline yet;  


More on Gas Prices...


The study (pdf) referenced in CIR's video above estimates the true cost of gasoline could be up to $15, according to findings by the International Center for Technology Assessment (ICTA) in 1998.
More recently, in 2007 the Earth Policy Institute compiled an updated estimate (pdf) of the True Price of Gasoline using the ICTA's previous study, as well as more recent updates from them and other sources. The Earth Policy Institute estimates the following hidden gasoline cost breakdowns:





Category of Cost We
  Do Not Pay at the Pump
Cost per Gallon


Environment, Health and Social Costs
$5.98


Subsidies - Production and Consumption
$0.42


Supply and Shipment Protection Costs
$0.48


Other Externalities - dependence &
  price shock risk, etc.
$3.35



Total Additional Costs (that we don't pay at the pump)
$10.23



A visualization of the Earth Policy Institute's estimated ranges of the True Price of Gasoline is seen below based on four categories of hidden costs (as shown above). An aggressive estimate is seen in red, a conservative estimate in orange and the average in green. The blue bar represents the average retail price Americans currently pay ($3.59).












Exploring prices in other countries offers additional perspective on estimates of gasoline's true cost. For example, Norway pays close to $10 per gallon (despite being a major oil producer), while the Netherlands pays around $9. Europe on the whole averages $7.44 per gallon.
Moving further east, Australia and New Zealand hover around $6.50, the Japanese and South Koreans pay around $6.75, while Hong Kong pays a full $8.15 per gallon of gas.
On the other end of the spectrum, it's primarily the Middle East and Venezuela that pay less than the average price in the United States. The mere six cents per gallon paid by Venezuelans demonstrates just how subjective gasoline prices have become. 

A Few Examples of Potential Recipient Organizations Funders Vote For:





Transparency
All funders will receive formal documentation that 90% of the campaign's total funds raised were provided to the three organizations you help choose within 15 days after the close of the campaign (we are happy to make such documentation publicly available). Formal documentation of the 10% of the campaign's total funds being utilized to scale up FullGallon will be provided within 60 days of the campaign's close.




FullGallon, nor anyone involved in FullGallon, has any pre-existing relationships with any of the organizations that will be offered as potential recipient organizations (relative to the 90% of the campaign's funds being allocated to recipient organizations).
Please don't hesitate to reach out with any questions of any kind! Thanks for your support!

story:
Ride for life, Ride for rivers

       UPDATED LINK FOR LIVE CAMPAIGN        http://www.indiegogo.com/projects/ride-for-life-ride-for-rivers--4

              We are two international students studying in UK: Dragos Hrituleac (2nd year Conservation Ecology, Worcester University) & Tiberiu Patras (3rd year Motorcycle Engineering, Coventry University). We are both passionate about cycling and outdoors experience and therefore decided to challenge ourselves through a 3000 km ride, over 30 days in June 2013 cycling back home as we are both from the same hometown (Botosani, Romania).

                Both being aware of current enviromental issues, we decided to take this on board and to mitigate for it. We established a partnership with World Wide Fund for Nature (http://wwf.panda.org/) . The project has been shaped in such a way to raise awarness of one of the issues WWF-Romania (http://romania.panda.org) is facing at the moment: THE RIVERS -  source of water and food, biodiversity and a source of life in itself.

                                      Romanian rivers

                   More than 90% of the settlements in Romania are located close to water courses. Freshwater's key roles are ranging from keeping a natural balance during draughts and floodings to recreational purposes and biodiversity richness; Romanian rivers have an immense potential in delivering all these ecoservices.

                  However pollution, dam building and infrastructure works, the excessive fishing has led to a decresed level of sustainability.

                 Given the Conservation Ecology background we have, our aim is to cycle and raise international awarness of the potential of these habitats, as well as, highlighting a few key problems.

1) Danube Sturgeon  --  One of the oldest families of bony fish in existence,

             they are listed as critically endangerend by the IUCN

             (http://www.iucnredlist.org) WWF has on going campaigns to tackle the

              situation and to help these native species under decline  http://wwf.panda.org/what_we_do/where_we_work/black_sea_basin/danube_carpathian/our_solutions/freshwater/danube_sturgeon/

2) Wetlands and river habitats  -- legal designations such as Ramsar sites, 

            Natura 2000 sites, UNESCO world heritage sites, as well as the legislation 

            which offers protection to natural habitats and the wildlife within are not 

            known and therefore not valued by the public.

3) Small scale hydropower plants  --  over 400 projects for small power plants 

          are planned to be build along rivers of high biodiversity importance. Many 

          are within Natura 2000 designated areas. WWF's work is in progress

          regarding the problem, but they need more support.

http://awsassets.panda.org/downloads/wwf_seven_sins_of_dam_building.pdf

 

         

                     What We Need & What You Get

            As you can see, we aim to make a difference in community at international level. We want to travel as sustainable as possible and this is why we choose to ride over and sleep under the clear sky for a month.

           This is where you step in. Although we have most of the basic equipemnt and kit, we are in need for some more help. Firstly, your support will be spent on food (2 hungry cyclists riding 30 days in a row, this might be somewhere around 400- 500 pounds). Secondly, none of us have the camping kit, so a fair amount will  go on camping gear.

          In terms of cyclig kit, we are in need of full waterproof equipment. Rain jackets and tights which will keep us dry and warm in rainy days are a must and they tend to be quite expensive. Last but not least, a GPS and an outdoors camera are on the priority list.

          Having said that, we will also contribute with money to cover the costs of: bike maintenance and repairs, bike trailers, cycling clothing, first aid kit, bags, maps, ferry, lights, toiletries, spare money for unpredicted situations.

          Have a look at the perks and decide how much you would like to contribute in the project. We have invested time, passion, money, training for it. How much can you do for us? Every little helps, even a simple share. Thank you for your time and support.

Here you can see our route; feel free to join in for a few kilometres: http://www.bikemap.net/route/2055607#lat=48.282485786461&lng=14.246771874999&zoom=5&maptype=ts_terrain

       Also we are happy to accept any of the mentioned bits instead of money. For instance, a spare GPS which you can give away...and not to mention, any piece of advice is welcomed.

      Donation on indiegogo.com can be made in any currency.

       Additionally, donation directly into a bank account from Romania can be done at: Dragos Hrituleac / RO 64 BTRL 0070 1201 W980 91XX (Banca Transilvania) and into the UK bank account at:  MR DRAGOS HRITULEAC  /  account number 69913268  /  sort code 30-99-90  (LLoyds TSB)

story:
Who Are We?

George Mason Engineer's for International Development (EfID) is a student organization that is housed in the Department of Civil, Environmental and Infrastructure Engineering (CEIE) at George Mason University.    We exist for Civil Engineering Students to participate in community-driven development programs worldwide through the design and implementation of sustainable engineering projects. We work both internationally and locally to build and educate communities about their basic infrastructure systems such as drinking water and sanitation. 

EfID was founded in 2010 as a Recognized Student Organization at GMU.  EfID has accomplished significant work in Honduras, the Peruvian Andes, and the Amazon addressing small communities' concerns over water shortages, clean water access, sanitation, and hygiene.  Please visit our website for more information about EfID. 

 

The Need !

This year we have several projects that we are working on, however we have one particular project that is in dire need of additional funding.  The project that is in dire need of funding is our Grande Sabana, Nicaragua project. 

Grande Sabana is a small community nestled in the mountains of northern Nicaragua.  The community has one failing water well that is in desperate need of repairs.  Many of the community's children currently walk a great distance to the well to retrieve a small amount of water.  This failing well is the primary source of water for drinking, cooking and cleaning and is not an efficient means of meeting the needs of the community regarding quantity or quality.

 

Moving Forward...

EfID has scheduled a trip in January 10, 2013 to assess the scope of the project, and material availability. On this trip, a team made up of GMU students and Professional Engineers will investigate the well and water storage location options and alternatives for the community, as well as the availability of materials locally for installation.

Based on the scope developed as a result of the assessment trip, a team of students will design a new well and water distribution system to meet the needs of the community. The assessment trip report will be available in February 2013.  

The team will make a second trip to Nicaragua during the summer of 2013 to install the well, and water system. EfID plans to work with and involve the community to ensure the proposed solutions satisfy their needs. Educating the community about the system, the sustainable solar powered pump, and how it will improve their lives will enable them to successfully continue to operate the water storage and distribution system and provide sufficient water for all residents.

 

The Funding Situation.

To fully fund the Grande Sabana, Nicaragua project we need $30,000.  Since August 2012, we have been able to raise about $15,000 from various sources.   (We are half way!) 

 

The break down.

 

-        Pipes and Fittings                         $7,000

-        Well Excavation                           $5,000

-        Transportation for Team               $5,000

-        Water Storage Tank                     $4,000

-        Solar Power System                     $3,000

-        Structures                                   $3,000

-        Well Pumping System                   $1,000

-        Lodging and Food for Team           $1,000

-        Unforeseen Conditions                  $1,000

-        Tools                                           $   500

 

 

Our Previous Track Record.

 

2011 San Isidro, Peru:        EfID successfully installs two water storage tanks. 

2012 San Isidro, Peru:        EfID successfully upgrades the water distribution system.

2012 Maijuna, Peru:            EfID successfully installs a pilot water filtration system.

2012 Honduras:                  EfID successfully provides water quality upgrades.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

You should also know that besides Indiegogo taking a 6% cut of any donation all remaining parts of the donation will go directly to the project and the community members of Grande Sabana, Nicaragua.

Your support and donations are essential for continuing work in developing regions of the world. We have the student involvement. We need your support to aid us in purchasing materials and travel to implement our projects and work with communities in need.

Donations may be made to EfID through the George Mason University Foundation. The foundation is a 501(c)(3) non-private foundation and a private corporation organized and operated exclusively for the benefit of George Mason University. As such, donations to EfID may be tax-deductible. The Foundation's Tax ID number is 54-1603842 and donations should be earmarked for EfID.

 

If you want to donate via a check, please make sure the check is made payable to GMU Foundation EfID.

 

EfID

George Mason University

4400 University Drive, MS 6C1

Fairfax, VA 22030-4444

 

Within a few weeks, you will receive a Thank You letter from EfID which will include a receipt for your records. This receipt will allow you to file your donation when doing your taxes, as it will be tax deductible. Please realize that GMU EfID is not able to file this for you.

story:
Thanks to the internet, the world can finally, after 25 years, hear a victim's story of Prince William Sound's destruction.  This film will expose a cover up.  A cover up of what really happened to cause the Exxon Valdez to end up on Bligh Reef.  It was not just a drunk skipper.  It was a conspiracy between Big Oil, Alaska regulators, and the US Coastguard to flaunt the rules in order to keep the tankers running on schedule - no matter what.  It is a story of ice bergs and speed.  Sound Familiar?  Why can't we ever learn? Twenty five years later we can learn, for the first time,  the real story of the Old Steamer Channel and why the Exxon Valdez hit the reef going 11 knots.  This film will tell the world what the commercial fishermen of Prince William Sound have always known.  The world was told a lie.  Here is the truth.

       Getting out into the wilderness of Alaska to do the filming and to collect the information is very costly.  When the Supreme Court cut our losses down to $.10 on the dollar it still gave me enough to get started as a film maker.  Although that pittance is long gone I will never stop working to expose the truth and seek justice.

       Funding is not all that is needed, you can also help by spreading the word about this important film and this campaign by using indiegogo share tools. Any extra funds will be used to start work on Rugged Island's next film which will probably be about the aging pipeline itself.  The Trans Alaska Pipeline Service Corp. (TAPS) contingency plan for a spill on the Copper River tributary crossings is completely inadequate.

        Please check out my first film, Alaska Women Mariners ~ Then  & Now, a TV pilot that won the Moondance film fest. 2012.  (vimeo.com:62635831)

       As a salmon gillnetter in Prince William Sound (PWS) whose life, as it was, ended March 24, 1989. Sense then it's been a battle just to survive the horrendous longterm effects of TOO MUCH crude oil for human survival. Big industry in the form of multinational corporations continue to threaten our habitat and reek physical as well as finical havoc in the Alaska Wilderness. While the multitudes are force to be addicts of fossil fuel forbidden a choose at the pumps by our own government mandates making industrial hemp the only viable alternative for Alaska, illegal. 

  Let us never forget, the beginning of the end for our wonderful wild salmon and the end of our once great Pacific Herring fisheries in PWS Alaska. 

        Let us learn, from the mistakes made as addicts of fossil fuel, allowing complacency to prevail in the industry's that have the biggest potential to distort the very habit required to support human life as we know it.

        Loosing just one spices that you depend on for your families survival is divesting.  A part of you dies every April now that you don't get to go out fishing for herring which was our first fisheries every spring after a long hungry winter. That gives you the $ and a jump start on summer when you will need the stamina it takes to harvest the 5 different spices of wild Alaska Salmon over the next 5 months. 

        Besides herring there are four other spies listed as not recovered including Harbor seal and Orcas.  Shellfish, are listed as recovery unknown, although there has never been another crab fisheries opener and shrimp was'n opened until almost 20 years afterwards. 

         Contributing to this campaign will help to finally pull the curtain on what really happened on March 24 in PWS and the true results of what 30+ million gallons of heavy Alaska crude oil are on life.  

         Thanks for your interest and help, Capt. Anna Young and the wildlife of the world.

         Contributing to this campaign will help to finally pull the curtain on what really happened on March 24 in PWS and the true results of what 30+ million gallons of heavy Alaska crude oil are on life.  
         Thanks for your interest and help, Capt. Anna Young and the wildlife of the world.

story:
A NURSERY FOR OUR SEED

  and complementary equipment

 

   for autonomy in the nursery heating

 

 (Î“Î¹Î± Ï„Î± ÎµÎ»Î»Î·Î½Î¹ÎºÎ± Ï€Î±ÏÎ±ÎºÎ±Î»Ï‰ Ï€Î·Î³Î±Î¹Î½ÎµÏ„Îµ ÏƒÏ„Î¿ Gallery  

1)  Î±Î½Î¿Î¹Î¾Ï„Îµ Ï„Î¿   nursary.htm

2)   download  Ï„Î¿  nursery.dotm

3)  Î· Î´Î¹Î±Î²Î±ÏƒÏ„Îµ Ï„Î±  images   greek 1  ÎµÏ‰Ï‚  greek 6 ) 


 

Hello! We have started this campaign to raise funds in order to construct a nursery and buy the necessary equipment and machinery for watering, heating and producing biomase. Biomase produced from spare wood and used to make pellets for the nursery heating system. 

 

We are a family(Thalia, Yannis and small Anthi)and some friends who have decided to change their way of life. Itâ€™s been some months now that we have started putting all our efforts in the process of creating an eco retreat center in Evia , Greece.

We have the land and for the moment we are looking for the best eco solutions as energy , waste management , toilets , healthy houses , food production â€“sustainable living in general-are concerned.

 

For the near future we must build a yoga area in order for thai massage and other workshops to run throughout  summer.

Our wish is to create a place where people will have the chance to live sustainably and experience at first hand the eco solutions in everyday life, to enjoy natural food from our cultivations , to take part in workshops, to help with the maintenance of the farm and with the camping running in general as semi-permanent residents, visitors, wwoofers and other volunteers.

The farm will also accept school kid groups and other groups of people or individuals who want to educate themselves on sustainable living and its applications.

All the facilities in the farm are designed to be usable from people with special needs.

And now letâ€™s pass to this campaignâ€™s special interest which is the NURSERY for our seeds:

Major part of the farming and agroturistic activities shall be the cultivation of medicine plants and herbs and super - nutritional foods(fruits in our case). Specifically: 4 different varieties of cornus , hippophaes , Aronia(black chokeberry), Goji( the original Tibetan variety). We hope that these cultivations will allow us to earn some money because they are supposed to be much wanted and easily absorbable from the market, especially from the organic food market. We would also like to make a small food processing unit.

Apart from the cultivations above we will plant of course everything we need for our personal everyday consuming and there we are going to use exclusively seeds from traditional varieties in order to help save bioversity. Eventually we are going to make a seed bank and become seed preservers. Those seeds we have acquired from cultivators and seed-keepers, members of the Peliti community(http://www.peliti.gr/). Check out what they are doing!

Following is an overview of the project:

We are going to grow the plants right from the crop that is why we need to build our own nursery. We already have the crops, we just need a nursery and all the necessary equipment for watering, warming the nursery etc. We will put the plants into the earth as soon as they are ready for this transition (super-foods when they are around 1 year-old, ordinary vegetables much sooner). 

But before that we need to clean and prepare the land area where the nursery is going to be build which at the moment is almost a jungle. The final planting area is already formed. We would like to use the spare wood from the land cleaning in a way that could benefit the nursery. How is that? It will be clear on next paragraph.

As the plants will start growing and requiring their regular pruning we will want to use all the wood out of the pruning -instead of throwing it away or burning it as people use to do in the countryside- in order to make pellets for the stove which in its turn will be used as a means for heating the nursery. But, to make pellets we need first a branch destroyer which will produce the wood biomass and then a pellet press machine to produce pellets out of the biomass. So, the spare wood from the grown-up plants will promote the growth of the new ones by warming their â€˜wombâ€™, the nursery.

 

So, specifically we will need:

 

A water tank in order to collect the rain water for watering the plants. 20mÂ³  -  2.650â‚¬

 

Wood material for the structure of the greenhouse  the floor and  shelves where the pots will stand.

â€“ 16â‚¬/mÂ². So, the cost for 40mÂ² is around 640â‚¬ for the floor. As for the shelves and the structure the cost is around 2.500â‚¬ . - Total  3.140â‚¬

 

 

Plastic tubes for watering -  

Electrical pumps for watering -                      1.596â‚¬                                                                   

Electrical valves for watering. â€“

 

Appropriate solar panels for the electrical needs of the watering system.

 

Small  and medium pots  for the plants. â€“ pot with dimensions 7cm internal diameter x 7cm external diameter x 8cm high  (0,25 lit)  costs 0,083â‚¬/unit, so for 1000 units  83â‚¬ .Pot with dimensions  15cm internal diameter x 15cm external diameter x  20cm high   (3,40 lit) costs 0,512â‚¬/unit, so for 1000 units  512â‚¬.  - Total  595â‚¬

 

A branch destroyer by which spare wood from cleaning the land and pruning will turn to wood biomass  â€“ 1.968â‚¬

 

A pellet press machine to produce pellets out of the wood biomass. â€“ 1.100â‚¬

 

A pellet stove with air tubes, controlled pellet consumption and temperature , for warming the greenhouse when necessary. â€“ around 2.150â‚¬

 

Total amount :    13.289â‚¬

 

Of course we will continue using the nursery system even after those first plants will have moved into the earth. We will grow plants right from the crop in order for us first to cover our farmâ€™s constant needs(personal consumption) and second to be able to earn an extra income from selling grown-up plants and thus helping financially to complete the whole retreat project.

Also if anyone has already all this equipment or parts of it and wishes to offer them for the project (even offer them for a specific period of time) we are open to listen to any proposition.

How much work needs to be done! But of course this is life and we love the challenge of all of this! We are confident that as soon as we have made a good start only good things shall come to support us on this magic trial of our life.

If we donâ€™t raise the goal money and depending on the amount raised we will buy some of the equipment f.e. the nursery only or the pellet stove only or the branch destroyer and so on and will try to collect the rest of the amount with various ways. Of course by starting a new campaign, and then by saving a small amount monthly from our family income in order to buy one at a time the parts of the equipment. And of course we will accept the fact that things will evolve on a much slower pace. 

Our only income which is roughly 1000euros per month comes from the renting of our appartments in Athens. We rented our house in order to be able to quit our jobs and have moved on a small cottage house close to the farm. There we are happier because we are growing up all together with our 3 year-old daughter who is having a great time with a garden to play and animals and earth and a smiling mamma and papa. There we have more time to organise the creation of our farm and center. That would have been impossible to do if we had to go to work too. It would have been impossible for us now to write this text. It is a big deal this change and with our (no) budget it needs also a lot of courage to keep believing in it. So, we are in a transitional phase. We are happy though, because now we are working for a purpose WE have set for ourselves, a purpose that doesnâ€™t betray our consiousness and on which we can place our faith and efforts. We are not considering ourselves as poor, but we definitely donâ€™t have the money to go further on our own, unless we do it in a very very slow pace. We hope also that in the meantime before this campaign ends more people will have joined our team. 

Remember, we have just started talking about our project to other people and I have to say that it is very moving to see people living on big cities and working full time responding immediately by offering their help for the weekends and their encouragement. Here in Greece almost everybody, especially those living in the big cities like Athens, has realized that it is time to change their living standards in a different way than they used to think about it before, meaning not by making more money, but by having more time for a meaningful life and relationships, living closer to nature, cultivating their own food, reducing their carbon footprint and pursuing sustainability and as much self-sufficiency as they can achieve. But, when your life is settled somewhere or you have family and kids to take care of, it is very hard to do the big step to change lifestyle, especially when there is no capital to start with. Our family was just like that. We want to change our life and we have just made the beginning by deciding to leave our permanent jobs and city and to use a piece of land we owned in order to create our base there and to find alternative ways of earning a small income from activities that will satisfy us on the whole, such as cultivating the earth, organising events and workshops, producing essential oils and food products, offering healing sessions(Yannis is a certified sound massage healer and a tai-chi devoted student), teaching music and yoga in the nearby community(Thalia is a pianist, singer and a certified yoga teacher).

 

Now,what can we offer back to you? Of course grown-up plants, dry fruits and any other fruit product we may prepare(jams, juices) and for those who want to visit Greece accommodation(how many days depending to your contribution), participation to any of our activities that will be offered at the time of your visit and priority in case you want to join us in the future as a volunteer. And although we are not experienced healers, we would be happy to offer healing sessions( tibetan bowls sound massage and thai massage) as well as yoga and chen tai-chi( small 11 moves form). Finally you are welcome to come and stay with us for a weekend (or any other day that suits all of us) on our peaceful cottage house at Oropos. Most welcome people with kids!

Thank you for your participation in our dream.

story:
Short summary

I am an international student at Mt. Hood Community College  in the United States. I am part of the SEED program: Scholarships for Education and Economic Development program. I am an inspirational leader in my community, a skilled conservationist, willing to help and apply everything I have learned to act as an effective agent of change, back in my home-country of El Salvador. 

In El Salvador, the concept of composting is still relatively new, especially in the rural community of  “Jardines de la Nueva”, where few people know how to compost and the abundance of benefits that it brings. My project, in addition to being a distinct and exceptional plan, will be the first attempt to improve soil fertility in the community.

Your contribution empowers people in this rural community help themselves. Every dollar goes directly to help people learn new techniques of soil enrichment and other benefits that go beyond the home garden.  Once we’ve introduced composting techniques, this inexpensive and effective practice will spread to neighboring communities, and, eventually, throughout the country.

What we need and what you get:

Our project goal is a modest sum of $2000. The budget includes labor, volunteer work, project management, lime, soil tester kits, pH kits, gardening tools for the composting maintenance and materials to build the bins.

The impacts:

The impact of my composting project will be truly groundbreaking, achieving changes in my community members’ lives: advancements in knowledge, skills, behavior, health and the economy.

This project will help us by accomplishing the following objectives:

  • Educating community members about how composting is an important element of organic gardening and agriculture, and that it provides many environmental benefits.
  • Improving soil productivity through three composting methods in order to replenish nutrient-poor soils, which have diminished plant growth, increased erosion, and disrupted natural runoff.
  • Recycling organic materials such as kitchen waste that make garbage bins smell bad and attract pests like flies and other insects.
  • Teaching families in the community the basic procedures for home composting.
  • Helping people create a system that best fits their plants’ needs and space availability. Helping families to find a suitable outdoor site to locate the compost.
  • Obtaining economic benefits: using compost will reduce the need for water, fertilizers, and pesticides.
  • Being an example for others. The concept of composting is going to be a great example for other neighboring communities which will result in benefits to even more people. 
  • Extending composting benefits beyond the garden, motivating even those without a green thumb to take up this efficient and age old agricultural practice.

In my native country of El Salvador and here in the United States, I have always participated in planting campaigns, volunteer work which includes gardening, cutting weeds and protecting trees.

Because of my proven ability in planning activities and accepting responsibilities and challenges as well as empowering others, I am certainly capable of seeing this project through. I have the desire and motivation to demonstrate to my people that, together, we can bring significant change to improve our wellbeing.

“Jardines de la Nueva” is an undeveloped small community that is suffering serious consequences such as erosion due to poor garden soils. Just that fact of not being able to harvest cripples the local economy and weakens the community.

Other ways you can help:

Please spread the word! I need your support! Let’s help turn things around! Even if you can’t help us with a donation, consider contributing your time! You can make all the difference in the world!

story:
Shelter Box

My name is Chelsea and together with my friends Sarah and Brady, we make up Team Asterism. We are players of an ARG on Tumblr called Sbarg. A lot of you seeing this page are very likely also Sbarg players.

What we are trying to do is raise enough funds to sponsor a shelter box! What that is, is a box of emergency supplies that can be used by a family of up to 10 people while they are displaced or homeless as the result of a disaster.

Each box contains:

  • A custom-designed disaster relief tent that can accommodate up to 10 people
  • Water containers and purification system
  • Stove and cooking utensils, pots, plates, cups, etc
  • Gloves and hats
  • Blankets, ground sheets, mosquito nets
  • Toolkit
  • Children’s activity pack

What We Need & What You Get

What we need is to raise is 1100$

This covers the total cost of sponsoring one shelter box (the cost of which is 1000$), plus offsetting the fees that will be incurred through indiegogo, paypal and the exchanging of currency. This is to make sure that we can sponsor 100% of the cost of a shelter box.

We’ve picked the flexible funding plan so that even if we don’t make our goal, 100% of donations (minus any fees charged by indiegogo, paypal and exchanging of currency) will still be able to be donated to help shelter box campaigns.

If we do reach our goal and go above and beyond it, 100% of extra donations will still go towards shelter box funding. For every 1000$ we raise, that’s 1 whole box!

Because we’re Sbarg players, if you are too then donating here and supporting our campaign is going to earn us grist while helping a very worthy cause!

The Impact

These boxes are delivered where ever aid is needed the most. Whether that be the site of an earthquake, a tsunami or a man-made disaster, ground teams respond and bring aid to those who have lost or are unable to reach their homes.

Shelter boxes have been deployed all over the world! So far this year boxes have been deployed to help those affected by floods in Louisiana, an earthquake in Italy, conflict in Sudan, drought in Somalia and many other places since the organization’s first recipient in 2001.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t help by giving a monetary donation, that’s okay! Maybe you want to volunteer to do artwork or some other thing that we can add to our campaign as perks!

If you don’t want to or can’t volunteer, that’s okay too! Spread the word around! You don’t have to be a player to want to support people in need. Pass it around, maybe you know someone who is able to donate! Everything helps us and the more people know, the more we’re able to help!

What we need is to raise is 1100$
This covers the total cost of sponsoring one shelter box (the cost of which is 1000$), plus offsetting the fees that will be incurred through indiegogo, paypal and the exchanging of currency. This is to make sure that we can sponsor 100% of the cost of a shelter box.
We’ve picked the flexible funding plan so that even if we don’t make our goal, 100% of donations (minus any fees charged by indiegogo, paypal and exchanging of currency) will still be able to be donated to help shelter box campaigns.
If we do reach our goal and go above and beyond it, 100% of extra donations will still go towards shelter box funding. For every 1000$ we raise, that’s 1 whole box!
Because we’re Sbarg players, if you are too then donating here and supporting our campaign is going to earn us grist while helping a very worthy cause!
The Impact
These boxes are delivered where ever aid is needed the most. Whether that be the site of an earthquake, a tsunami or a man-made disaster, ground teams respond and bring aid to those who have lost or are unable to reach their homes.
Shelter boxes have been deployed all over the world! So far this year boxes have been deployed to help those affected by floods in Louisiana, an earthquake in Italy, conflict in Sudan, drought in Somalia and many other places since the organization’s first recipient in 2001.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you can’t help by giving a monetary donation, that’s okay! Maybe you want to volunteer to do artwork or some other thing that we can add to our campaign as perks!
If you don’t want to or can’t volunteer, that’s okay too! Spread the word around! You don’t have to be a player to want to support people in need. Pass it around, maybe you know someone who is able to donate! Everything helps us and the more people know, the more we’re able to help!

story:
Announcing New Perks!!!

You asked for more perks and you got 'em! Some of the new goodies you can get in exchange for supporting ClimateStore on Indiegogo include a super-handy collapsible water bottle, a bamboo kitchen composter, our sleek Pixio solar bike lights, and the very versatile Scrubba washbag. These are some of our favorite products we’ve found over the past year, and we can’t wait to bring you 1,000 more innovative, carbon-lowering tools and resources. 


Our Vision

Climate change is real. The debate is over and it's time to act! The problem is that it is not clear what to do and what will make an impact.

Well, no more! Our vision is to build a national sustainable brand that has all the information and products you need to reduce your carbon footprint - all in one place. No more cluttered, overwhelming aisles of light bulbs at Home Depot. We're simplifying the shopping experience for everyone that wants to #kickcarbon! We're all busy people. Shopping with the climate in mind needs to be fun and easy. 

We also have great resources for learning about climate change, how to get involved, and ideas for sustainable living that don't cost a thing. Check out these shots from our current, live website www.climatestore.com!


Our Campaign

A crowdfunding campaign is a great way to sponsor mission driven companies. In exchange for a donation to our project, our supporters not only get to feel good about contributing to a great cause, they also get to be included on updates on our project and may also receive one of the many “perks” that we offer, which are detailed in the right hand sidebar. We offer a bunch of “swag” gear (t-shirt, long sleeve shirts, sweatshirts, tote, mugs, and stickers) with some awesome and original climate themed designs. We also offer several product samplers kits, carbon offsets, and personal climate focused webinars!

Our campaign has received excellent media coverage, including stories by BostInno, a big Boston based start-up blog and on Treehugger, the largest eco blog in North America. We’ve also been featured in several newsletters and green living blogs like CABA, Boston Green Blog and True Moringa.


Our Project

During our first year at ClimateStore, we researched and selected more than 300 carbon-lowering household items for our online store.

Now we want to go big. Climate change is a big problem and it needs big solutions. Our first project is to triple the number of carbon-lowering products in our store. But this takes resources! We need your support so we can discover, qualify and bring you all those cool products that help us down the path to low carbon living.

Our Process - Discover, Qualify and Share 100's of Products

We're not interested in just one cool product, method or technology. Our goal is to discover 1,000 Climate Solutions for Everyday Life: electric bikes, energy efficient lighting, water saving devices, cleaner lawnmowers, home decor, solar and wind solutions, and way more.

Rest assured - we only carry items that have a beneficial link to the climate. We qualify each product to see if it was made in a low carbon manner, requires less energy to use, takes less energy to throw out, or is self powered using renewable resources. We also look for budget friendly items and educational benefit.

Our Icons - We Show You How Each Product is Good for the Climate

If an item passes our tests, we share it by making it available on our website www.climatestore.com. We also include what icons the product achieved, whether the manufacturer is sustainable, videos and information for best use. Our goal is to make it easy!

Our Budget - How We'll Turn $25,000 into 1000 New Products



Our Perks

Let's face it - we all need to get the message out about climate change. So, in addition to having access to a 1,000 cool products, you'll also get some awesome climate change swag!  We have just the right messages to get the conversation started; they'll engage others in the growing movement to #kickcarbon. 

All perks for donations over $100 will include your choice of t-shirt. We'll e-mail you for your preferred design and size after our campaign has closed. 

Stickers, Mugs, and Totes ($10 - $25)


T-shirts ($35)


Long Sleeve Tees ($50)


Zip Hoodies ($100)

Zip hoodies come as part of our Gold Star Carbon Kicker perk. Donate $100 today and we'll reward you with a swag pack, including a hoodie or shirts from with our original, climate-themed designs. Plus you can participate in our an exclusive climate change webinar!

Our outdoor product pack is great for fans of camping, hiking and traveling.

Our Custom Designs

Check out the details on our swag designs for tees, long sleeved shirts and hoodies.


Sampler Packs ($300)

We also have 3 great product packs for our $300 perk: an outdoor pack, a eco-kitchen pack and and energy efficiency pack. The images below show all the products in each pack and a write up is in progress. Stay tuned for updates!

  


  

Our Energy Efficiency Sampler contains 9 great products to help you save energy at home, including:

  • TrickleStar smart power strip and energy meter

  • Feit led light bulbs

  • USBCell rechargeable batteries

  • a Luci outdoor solar lantern

  • a water conserving shower head

  • a water meter 

  • some recycled Preserve tupperware (to help save left overs). 

  • We'll also throw in climate scientist Kerry Emanual's must-read book "What We Know About Climate Change".

The Outdoor Travel Pack is great for fans of camping, hiking and adventure. It includes a hiking backpack made with recycled materials, a solar lantern and USB charger, a Scrubba portable laundering bag, a Bubi collapsible water bottle, and fun, upcycled bracelets from Green Guru.

Our Eco Kitchen Kit includes a full line of dinnerware and tupperware from Preserve Products - a manufacturer of kitchen and personal care products from recycled food safe plastics. It also contains a kitchen compost caddy, compostable liners and two kits to help you grow your own herbs and mushrooms at home.

Our Team

We're a determined group of problem solvers who believe that climate change can be stopped if we all start thinking out of the box. We're concerned about climate forecasts, impacts on the natural world, and peoples around the globe. We need governments and businesses to get on board, but we're also keen on taking personal action - right now. Why? Because we believe in the power of personal example. 

Steve Bushnell - Founder and CEO.

"I founded the company because even though climate change is a serious issue, it really isn't clear what products will have the have the biggest impact. We are all busy people so this needs to be fun and easy!"

Cameron Bruns - Sustainable Products Buyer. Founder of BostonGreenBlog.com, Sustainable Products Expert. 

"We track down and research the coolest and most innovative products to help people reduce their carbon footprint"

Danielle Magrogan - Product Manager. Life Cycle Assessment Expert, Environmental Engineer.

"We also want to have a mission, a brand, and really a whole shopping experience that gets people excited about helping the environment"

Devon DeGrazia - Branding and Design Intern. Graphic Designer.

Please Share

Climate change is real, it's human caused, and it's urgent. But there's good news - there's still time to act. But we need to get moving! Help us #KickCarbon!

Please share our campaign with your friends and colleagues.


#KickCarbon


Thanks for your support!

story:
Bringing Birds Back To Guam

Since 2010 we have been building green roofs in Guam.  During our first project, we learned about the ecological disaster created by the brown tree snake.  Accidently introduced in the early 1950’s by the military, the brown tree snake has literally eaten most of the native birds on Guam.  We want to change that by building minature snake-proof green roof “pods” that can provide safe habitat for nesting birds.  The first step is determining if our idea works and how to best implement this solution.

We have already built three green roof pods in an urban forest centrally located on Guam.  The next phase requires building a larger “container green roof” and turning our research team loose documenting the results and publishing papers.  Two top researchers from the University of Helsinki who specialize in green roofs and zoology are on the team.  This is serious stuff.

For over sixty years the problem has gotten worse on Guam.  We think it’s time to stop looking in the rear view mirror at what’s happened and start looking for ways to allow the birds and snakes to coexist. 

We think we can turn this thing around using an ancient technology – green roofs.  There is a way out of this mess, but we need your help to take the next step.


What We Need

Phase I is complete.  We built three green roof pods and installed three trail cameras to document snake and bird activity 24/7/365.  We paid for Phase I out of our own pocket.  Our sponsor - LMS Guam – helped out with black lava cinders for the green roof soil, native plants, and vehicles and equipment to build the pods.

To complete Phase II we need your help.  Here are the expenses to get Phase II running:

·  Purchase 40’ shipping container and move to site 

·  Purchase and install green roof on container 

·  Install trail cameras                                                           

·  Pay local field researchers to monitor the pod 

Fortunately, our green roof project at the Guam Medical City Hospital puts us back in Guam during March and April 2015.  During that time we hope to build out the shipping container green roof pod and begin analyzing the data.  Our colleagues in Finland are already working on finding funding to cover their travel to Guam.  We hope to publish a paper or two in a scientific journal by the end of the year.

Other Ways You Can Help

Obviously, Phase II is super important to understanding how green roofs can help bring birds back to Guam.  If you aren’t able to contribute right now, please:

·  make some noise about our campaign.

·  keep following our project and see what happens.

·  start reading National Geographic and learn what people are doing everyday to make the world a better place.

What You Get


The Real Impact

Researchers have known for a long time that in order for birds to coexist with brown tree snakes they must be able to nest and roost in locations that are snake –proof (Conry 1987).  Urban areas are especially important since they provide isolation from large forests and vegetated areas that attract snakes (Wiles 2003).  Green roof bird pods designed to maximize the four ideal bird habitat factors of food, cover, water, and space (Shaw 1985 and Fernandez-Canero, 2010), and placed in urban or disturbed areas may be the answer - BINGO!

  Sacred Grove Green Roof Garden at the Singapore Garden


The Team

We are a group of scientists, business leaders, inventors, and outdoors people who love wild places and creatures of all kinds.  When things go wrong in nature – like the accidental introduction of the brown tree Snake on Guam – we look for a way out. 

The team is led by Roger Grothe, President of Aloha Landscaping.  After attending graduate school at San Jose State University and working at Lockheed Martin as a research consultant for 16 years, Roger formed Aloha Landscaping and became a leader in green roof design and construction. 

Dr. Ferenc Vilisics earned his PhD in Environmental Sciences in University of Debrecen in Hungary.  He is a zoologist and ecologist with decade-long experience in anthropogenic (human caused) effects on ecosystems. 

Dr. Susanna Lehvävirta earned her PhD in Urban Ecology from the University of Helsinki. She is keen on finding solutions to complex scientific and societal problems in order to make the life of people as well as other living creatures better on the globe.

Jesse Grothe is a student at the University of Wisconsin studying Sustainable Management.  He has also studied in Helsinki, Finland conducting green roof research.  He loves a good challenge and between coaching wrestling and trail running he operates a state-of-the-art organic tomato farm near Minneapolis. 

Guam Micronesian Kingfisher is our official mascot.  Extinct in the wild due to the brown tree snake, the  last 29 kingfishers were captured between 1984 and 1986.  The Lincoln Park Zoo in Chicago participates in the Guam Micronesian Kingfisher Species Survival Plan®.  In the wild, the Guam Micronesian kingfisher feeds on insects and lizards, catching them with its large beak. It’s large beak is also used to drill holes into trees and rotting wood for nesting. Male and female birds work together to excavate the nest, an activity that may help the pair bond.  There is a hope that one-day pairs of the Guam Micronesian Kingfisher could be returned to the wild – maybe a green roof pod will become their home. 


 

Conry, P. J. 1987. Ecology of the Philippine Turtle-Dove on Guam.Technical report 6. Division of Aquatic and Wildlife Resources,Mangilao, Guam.

Fernandez-Canero, R., Gonzalez-Redondo, P.  Green Roofs as a Habitat for Birds: A Review. Journal of Animal and Veterinary Advances 9 (15): 2014-2052, 2010.

Shaw, J.H., 1985. Introduction to Wildlife Management. McGraw-Hill, New York.

Wiles, G.J, Bart, J., Beck, R.E., Aguon, C.F. Impacts of the Brown Tree Snake: Patterns of Decline and Species Persistence in Guam’s Avifauna. Conservation Biology, Pages 1350–1360 Volume 17, No. 5, October 2003.

story:
Short Summary

“Bikes for you at TRU” has an insightful determination to create a bike share community within the campus at Thompson Rivers University (TRU) in Kamloops, British Columbia.  As simple as it gets, we would like to implement a program where bikes are available free of use to students and staff to commute around campus.  By using the “just take it, ride it, leave it” mentality of the popular “car2go” system, we hope to get a pedal movement happening on campus. 

Simple Steps to get you riding a “Bikes for you at TRU” bike:
*Drop in to the Environmental and Sustainability Office (OM 2691) to read and sign the rider waiver
*Signing the waiver will allow you to get the combination to the lock to unlock bikes around campus
*Find a bike on a campus bike rack, put on the helmet, and ride away!

With a positive outlook, we see these bikes helping students stretch their legs between classes, commute in a timely manner, and spark an interest in the two-wheel movement.  In the future, if you see a green bike with sticker signage promoting “Bikes for You at TRU” don’t just look at it – take it for a ride! 

As a group of geography and science students at TRU, this project is important to us as we see it having a positive and lasting impact on the environment and social well-being on campus at TRU.  We believe that making bikes available for anyone to use can have direct positive impacts on the individual and create a sense of community collaboration and development.

What We Need & What You Get

To get Bikes For You at TRU up and running, or should we say cycling, we are looking to raise $1000. The reason behind this dollar figure being so large is that we want this program to be sustainable and be available for future students to use for years to come. The initial costs will include purchasing bikes, helmets, and locks. The amount of funds raised will influence how many bikes we can purchase. Upon start up, our goal is to have between three and five bikes, adding to our selection as we raise the funds and the program becomes more successful. Funds will also cover paint and signage used on the bikes. While our campaign leaders are volunteering their time to paint the bikes, we need to purchase a good quality paint that will last outside. The noticeable green paint will allow these bikes to be easily recognized, letting everyone know that this bike is available for them to borrow.

Aside from our website, we have chosen to promote Bikes For You at TRU through the use of stickers. Stickers are a fun way to get the word out and by displaying a sticker you can show people that you are a proud supported of a student run initiative to promote cycling as an alternative form of transportation. Raised funds will be used to cover the cost of stickers that will be distributed to students, faculty, and staff, and will also be displayed on the bikes up for borrow. As we mentioned, we want this program to continue, therefore, any unused funds will remain with the program to cover maintenance costs as the bikes experience normal wear and tear. Additional funds may also be used to cover unexpected costs that arise throughout the project, as well as to expand Bikes For You at TRU and collect more bikes in the future.

The Impact

Bikes For You at TRU is more than just about obtaining bikes for student use. The idea of campus bikes has numerous impacts that can positively affect not only the students using them, but the community, and even the environment. First and foremost, campus bikes will help spark an interest in biking. The idea behind this campaign is that this interest in cycling will hopefully turn into something where more and more people begin choosing bikes as an alternative form of transportation, thereby reducing the amount of cars on the road and lowering emissions. By choosing cycling over driving, people will become active in reducing their carbon footprint.  It may also give people the boost they need to develop their own ways in which they can help.

Aside from this huge benefit, cycling saves money. When using a bike, insurance, gas, and parking are essentially free, and the cost of bike maintenance in comparison to that of cars is much more affordable. Even still, there are further benefits of choosing to cycle, including those related to health. Cycling can help you get in shape and stay in shape, which is good for not only your physical health, but your mental health as well. Finally, biking is fun! Cycling is a great way to get outdoors, experience nature, and catch up with friends. As you can see there are many benefits that go hand in hand with using cycling as an alternative form of transportation, we just have to get started!

Risks & Challenges

Our Facebook page and website can be used as a means to keep tabs on all of the bikes.  People will be able to leave comments on both of these sites. Comments may include general inquiries about the program, but can also include the whereabouts of bikes and if any of them need servicing. By doing this, riders can post where they left the bike, making it easy for someone searching for a bike to find, of course, this is no guarantee as someone else might make it there before you do.

We are hoping to work with the Environment and Sustainability Office to keep the bikes regularly serviced.  Riders can also comment about the bikes condition on the Facebook page. As each bike will be labeled with a specific identifiable characteristic (i.e. bike #1 has a flat tire). By doing so, program operators will be able to tend to that bike as soon as possible, ensuring that it’s ready to be rode once again.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t make a dollar donation that’s fine by us! There are plenty of other ways that you can get involved to help promote biking as an alternative form of transportation on our campus. For starters, you can tell your family and friends about our campaign, the more people that know about it the better! We are open to feedback, whether it is suggestions, tips, personal experiences, or letting us know that we are doing a great job. Any comments can be left on our Facebook page and website and we will be sure to address them in any way that we can. If you are looking to take it one step further you can really get involved by helping us carry out our project! There is lots of work to be done and any volunteer efforts are greatly appreciated. Furthermore, if you have an unwanted bike in good condition lying around that you are willing to donate, we would be more than happy to come take it off your hands. Again, you can contact us through our Facebook page or website. Any contributions, no matter what form or how small are greatly appreciated and can help us get Bikes For You at TRU.
story_txt:
Short Summary
“Bikes for you at TRU” has an insightful determination to create a bike
share community within the campus at Thompson Rivers University (TRU) in
Kamloops, British Columbia.  As simple as
it gets, we would like to implement a program where bikes are available free of
use to students and staff to commute around campus.  By using the “just take it, ride it, leave
it” mentality of the popular “car2go” system, we hope to get a pedal movement
happening on campus.  
Simple Steps to get you riding a “Bikes for you at TRU” bike:
*Drop in to the Environmental and Sustainability Office (OM 2691) to read and
sign the rider waiver
*Signing the waiver will allow you to get the combination to the lock to unlock
bikes around campus
*Find a bike on a campus bike rack, put on the helmet, and ride away!
With a positive outlook, we see these bikes helping students stretch
their legs between classes, commute in a timely manner, and spark an interest in
the two-wheel movement.  In the future,
if you see a green bike with sticker signage promoting “Bikes for You at TRU”
don’t just look at it – take it for a ride! 

As a group of geography and science students at TRU, this project is
important to us as we see it having a positive and lasting impact on the
environment and social well-being on campus at TRU.  We believe that making bikes available for
anyone to use can have direct positive impacts on the individual and create a
sense of community collaboration and development.

What We Need & What You Get
To get Bikes For You at TRU up and running, or should we say cycling, we
are looking to raise $1000. The reason behind this dollar figure being so large
is that we want this program to be sustainable and be available for future
students to use for years to come. The initial costs will include purchasing bikes,
helmets, and locks. The amount of funds raised will influence how many bikes we
can purchase. Upon start up, our goal is to have between three and five bikes,
adding to our selection as we raise the funds and the program becomes more
successful. Funds will also cover paint and signage used on the bikes. While
our campaign leaders are volunteering their time to paint the bikes, we need to
purchase a good quality paint that will last outside. The noticeable green
paint will allow these bikes to be easily recognized, letting everyone know
that this bike is available for them to borrow. 
Aside from our website, we have chosen to promote Bikes For You at TRU
through the use of stickers. Stickers are a fun way to get the word out and by
displaying a sticker you can show people that you are a proud supported of a
student run initiative to promote cycling as an alternative form of
transportation. Raised funds will be used to cover the cost of stickers that
will be distributed to students, faculty, and staff, and will also be displayed
on the bikes up for borrow. As we mentioned, we want this program to continue,
therefore, any unused funds will remain with the program to cover maintenance
costs as the bikes experience normal wear and tear. Additional funds may also
be used to cover unexpected costs that arise throughout the project, as well as
to expand Bikes For You at TRU and collect more bikes in the future.

The Impact
Bikes For You at TRU is more than just about
obtaining bikes for student use. The idea of campus bikes has numerous impacts
that can positively affect not only the students using them, but the community,
and even the environment. First and foremost, campus bikes will help spark an
interest in biking. The idea behind this campaign is that this interest in
cycling will hopefully turn into something where more and more people begin
choosing bikes as an alternative form of transportation, thereby reducing the
amount of cars on the road and lowering emissions. By choosing cycling over
driving, people will become active in reducing their carbon footprint.  It may also give people the boost they need
to develop their own ways in which they can help. 
Aside from this huge benefit, cycling saves
money. When using a bike, insurance, gas, and parking are essentially free, and
the cost of bike maintenance in comparison to that of cars is much more
affordable. Even still, there are further benefits of choosing to cycle,
including those related to health. Cycling can help you get in shape and stay
in shape, which is good for not only your physical health, but your mental
health as well. Finally, biking is fun! Cycling is a great way to get outdoors,
experience nature, and catch up with friends. As you can see there are many
benefits that go hand in hand with using cycling as an alternative form of
transportation, we just have to get started!
Risks &
Challenges
Our Facebook page and website can be used as a means to keep tabs on all
of the bikes.  People will be able to
leave comments on both of these sites. Comments may include general inquiries
about the program, but can also include the whereabouts of bikes and if any of
them need servicing. By doing this, riders can post where they left the bike,
making it easy for someone searching for a bike to find, of course, this is no
guarantee as someone else might make it there before you do. 
We are hoping to work with the Environment and Sustainability Office to
keep the bikes regularly serviced.  Riders
can also comment about the bikes condition on the Facebook page. As each bike
will be labeled with a specific identifiable characteristic (i.e. bike #1 has a
flat tire). By doing so, program operators will be able to tend to that bike as
soon as possible, ensuring that it’s ready to be rode once again. 
Other Ways You Can Help
If you
can’t make a dollar donation that’s fine by us! There are plenty of other ways
that you can get involved to help promote biking as an alternative form of
transportation on our campus. For starters, you can tell your family and
friends about our campaign, the more people that know about it the better! We
are open to feedback, whether it is suggestions, tips, personal experiences, or
letting us know that we are doing a great job. Any comments can be left on our
Facebook page and website and we will be sure to address them in any way that
we can. If you are looking to take it one step further you can really get
involved by helping us carry out our project! There is lots of work to be done
and any volunteer efforts are greatly appreciated. Furthermore, if you have an unwanted bike in good condition lying
around that you are willing to donate, we would be more than happy to come take
it off your hands. Again, you can contact us through our Facebook page or
website. Any contributions, no matter what form or how small are greatly
appreciated and can help us get Bikes For You at TRU.

story:
Marsh and Sky, San Francisco Bay © Bruce Hodge

Why EARTH & EROS?

Our bodies and the earth are intimately connected. But because so many of us live more online than on the land, it’s easy to forget this connection.

In this state of forgetfulness, we don’t feel pain when we see the earth abused—like when mountaintops in West Virginia are blown up for coal or when huge parts of the forest in Alberta, Canada, are ripped out to make way for tar sands mining. If we’re fully inhabiting our animal bodies, if we’re receptive to the sensory pleasures the earth can offer when it’s whole and healthy, we just know that stuff is wrong. We don’t have to do the carbon footprint calculations.

That’s what motivated me to gather the most vivid sensual writing about people in relation to nature I could find—short poems and prose pieces by more than seventy writers—and pair it with beautifully sensual photographs of nature taken by fine art photographer Bruce Hodge. I also invited prolific nature writer and lepidopterist Robert Michael Pyle to write the foreword. My intention was to create a powerful testament to the connection between pleasure, desire, and the health of our bodies and the earth.

The result is Earth & Eros: A Celebration in Words and Photographs. The book portrays our bodies and the earth as sacred, and celebrates eros as the life force that drives roses to bloom and salmon to swim upriver to spawn—and that attracts us to each other and to nature. The book expresses my conviction that eros is the only force strong enough to move us to imagine and create the new world that is crying to be born out of our current environmental predicament.

"Simply by opening our senses and feeling ourselves to be part of the natural world around us, we can begin to heal, to regain wholeness, to take communion." — from the Preface

Flower Sanctum, Palo Alto © Bruce Hodge

Why I need your help

Earth & Eros is now complete and will be published by White Cloud Press in October 2015. My previous anthology Sisters of the Earth: Women's Prose and Poetry About Nature  was published by Vintage Books (1991, second edition 2003), and the textbook I co-edited entitled Literature and the Environment: A Reader on Nature and Culture was published by Longman (1999) and Pearson (second edition, 2013).

The process of getting Earth & Eros published is a little different because White Cloud uses a collaborative publishing model. That means I don't get an advance but instead pay a big chunk of the up-front costs in return for a larger percentage of royalties down the road than traditional publishers offer. I’m paying these costs out of my self-employment income, and I could use a little help. The permissions fees to reprint the writing in the book come to more than $4,000, and I'd like to raise at least that much.

Whatever you can afford to contribute will really help. I believe this book can make a difference for nature—and I know your support will make a difference to me.

Thank you!

"Let this book open your eyes to the possibilities for deep pleasure everywhere around you. Read it out loud to yourself, to your lover. Let the words inspire you to infuse your wild, precious life with the primal gifts of love offered by the earth and to honor the earth in all your actions." — from the Preface

Kelp Tableau, Point Lobos © Bruce Hodge
Special thanks to Holly Crosson for videography
